ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 2102 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting the Code of Ordinances of the of West Monroe, Louisiana and Providing for the Effect Thereof. 
    Section 1. Be it ordained by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, in legal session convened, that pursuant to Article VI, Section 10 of the Louisiana Constitution of 1974 and Section 214 of the Charter of the City of West Monroe, a codification of the ordinances of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana is hereby adopted as "The Code of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana," which codification shall supersede the prior 1976 codification, and all amendments thereto. 
    Section 2. Be it further ordained by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, in legal session convened, that this adoption and enactment of this Code shall not affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this adoption and enactment; nor shall such adoption and enactment affect any ordinance heretofore validly in force and effect, the provisions of "The Code of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana" being considered as continuations of the previously enacted Code of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana and ordinances of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana and not as new enactments thereof. 
The above ordinance was read in full, considered by sections and upon a vote being taken, the following result was had: 
Yea: 5 
Nay: 0 
Absent: 0 
Not voting: 0 
Whereupon the Mayor of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana declared said ordinance to be duly adopted on the 11th day of June, A.D., 1985. 
ATTEST:

CHARTER[1] 
PREAMBLE 
    We the body politic of the corporation of West Monroe, Louisiana, beseeching the supreme power of God for wisdom and judgment, do herewith establish and maintain a form and document of government for the maintenance and enhancement of our essential human rights, dignity and freedom. Regarding form and substance as only manifestations of the essential democratic consideration of man's relations with his fellow man, may we willingly sacrifice our individual desires to the greater good of our community. To this end and for these purposes our individual and corporate efforts are dedicated. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The home rule charter was ratified on March 13, 1971. A copy is recorded in the records of Ouachita Parish, Louisiana. Article and section catchlines and numbers from the 1976 Code of the city are maintained in the charter, except that the prefix number of section numbers has been dropped; e.g., § 3-302 becomes § 302. 
State Constitution reference- Home rule charter, La. Const., Art. VI, § 4. 
State Law reference- Adoption of home rule charter, R.S. 33:1395 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - INCORPORATION; FORM OF GOVERNMENT; BOUNDARIES; POWERS 

Sec. 101. - Incorporation. 
    The inhabitants of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, within the corporate limits as now established or as hereafter established by law shall be and continue a body politic and corporate to perpetuity, under the name of the "City of West Monroe, Louisiana," hereinafter referred to as the "city." 
Sec. 102. - Form of government. 
    The municipal government provided by this charter shall be known as the mayor-board of aldermen form of government. It shall consist of an elected board of aldermen that shall constitute the legislative branch of the government and an elected mayor who shall be the chief executive officer and head of the executive branch. 
Sec. 103. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, shall be those as presently set forth in Ordinance No. 1388. Changes in the boundaries of the city shall be made by ordinance in accordance with applicable state general law. 
State Law reference- Extension of corporate limits of municipality by means of petition and election, R.S. 33:151 et seq. 
Sec. 104. - Powers. 
    The city shall have all powers possible for a city to have under the constitution and laws of this state as fully and completely as though they were specifically enumerated in this charter, except as expressly modified or changed by this charter. The powers of the city under this charter shall be construed liberally in favor of the city, and the specific mention of particular powers in the charter shall not be construed as limiting in any way the general powers stated in this charter. The city may exercise any of its powers or perform any of its functions and may participate in the financing thereof, jointly or in cooperation, by contract or otherwise, with any one or more states or civil divisions or agencies, thereof, or the United States or any agency thereof. 
State Law reference- Intergovernmental functions, R.S. 33:1321 et seq. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF ALDERMEN 

Sec. 201. - Governing authority and legislative power. 
    The board of aldermen shall be the governing authority of the city for purposes of legislation and policy-making. 
Sec. 202. - Election; size. 
    The board of aldermen of the city shall consist of five (5) members elected at large for four-year terms concurrent with that of the mayor. 
Sec. 203. - Qualifications. 
    Members of the board of aldermen shall be qualified electors of the city and shall hold no other public office for which they shall be entitled to receive any remuneration or per diem compensation, except that of notary public or membership in the national guard or reserve defense establishment. Members of the board of aldermen must be twenty-one (21) years of age and shall have been a resident of the city for one (1) year and a resident of Ouachita Parish for at least two (2) years. Members of the board of aldermen shall not have been convicted of a felony. Any member of the board of aldermen ceasing to possess these qualifications or who is convicted of a felony shall immediately become disqualified, creating a vacancy in the office. 
State Law reference- Felony defined, R.S. 14:2. 
Sec. 204. - Salary. 
    The annual salary of members of the board of aldermen shall be one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00) until changed by ordinance. Any ordinance increasing the salary or granting any other monetary compensation to members of the board of aldermen shall be effective only after the next regular mayoralty election and must have been passed at least six (6) months prior to said election. 
Sec. 205. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies in the office of alderman shall be filled by mayoralty appointment with the concurrence of the board of aldermen if the term of office to be filled is less than one (1) year. If the term is greater than one (1) year a special election to be held within ninety (90) days of the creation of the vacancy shall be called by the mayor. 
Sec. 206. - Officers. 
    At the first regular meeting of a newly elected board of aldermen, a mayor pro tempore shall be elected from among the membership of the aldermen. The mayor pro tempore shall perform all duties delegated to the mayor in this charter in the absence of the mayor and shall serve for a term of four (4) years. In the event of temporary absence and/or disability of both the mayor and mayor pro tempore, then the remaining board of aldermen shall elect a temporary mayor from their membership who shall perform the duties of the mayor. 
Sec. 207. - Meetings. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen shall hold not less than one (1) regular meeting in each month on a date, and at a place and hour, to be fixed by ordinance. Each newly elected council shall at its first regular meeting set, by ordinance, a date, place and hour for its regular monthly meeting and shall retain this date throughout its term of four (4) years. 
(b)  Special meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen may be called for the transaction of important business at the instance of the mayor or any alderman. 
(c)  The notice for a special meeting must specify in detail the objects and purposes for which the meeting is called; must be signed by the officer calling the meeting, and must be served by any police [officer] of the municipality, on the mayor and a majority of the members of the board. The notice may be served either personally or at the domicile of the officer to be notified, and shall be served in either event at least twelve (12) hours prior to the hour fixed in the call for the special meeting. The police officer making such service shall make a diligent effort to make either personal or domiciliary service on the mayor and each member of the board of aldermen. The police officer serving the notice shall make his return on the back of a copy of the call, reciting the time and manner of service thus made by him upon the mayor and each member of the board. This return, together with the call for the special meeting, shall be transcribed upon the minutes of the special meeting by the clerk. The mayor or any member of the board may waive notice of this meeting in writing. 
(d)  No business, except such as is specified in the call for the special meeting, shall be transacted at the meeting except by unanimous consent of the board. 
(e)  In all cases it shall require a majority of the aldermen elected to constitute a quorum. 
(f)  Meetings, whether regular or special, may be continued over to another specified date upon [the] unanimous consent of the aldermen. If any meeting, regular or special, [fails] for want of a quorum, any number of the aldermen less than a quorum may adjourn the meeting to another specified date, but in no case shall adjourned meetings be prolonged beyond the end of the month in which they are scheduled to take place, or be continued or adjourned more than once, or to any date except that specified at the continuance or adjournment. 
(g)  All meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen shall be public; however, the mayor and board of aldermen may recess for the purpose of discussing in a closed or executive session limited to its own membership[,] and such other persons as the governing body may deem necessary, any matter which would tend to defame or prejudice the character or reputation of any person, or any other matter which the mayor and board of aldermen, in [their] discretion, should best be preliminarily discussed in executive session. 
(h)  All official action of the mayor and board of aldermen shall be taken only in open public session at duly constituted meetings. 
Sec. 208. - Policies and employees. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen shall adopt policies not inconsistent with this charter, governing its own organization, business and employees. Such policies shall be kept in written form and in the form of a "policy manual." This manual shall further include a listing of duties of the various department heads and the functions of their department as defined by this charter, ordinance or administrative ruling. A copy of this manual shall be made available to the mayor and each member of the board of aldermen. The responsibility for keeping the "policy manual" current shall be that of the city clerk. 
(b)  The mayor, subject to the approval of the board of aldermen, shall at the first regular meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen appoint a city clerk who shall serve at his pleasure. The clerk shall give notice of meetings, keep records of proceedings, record and authenticate actions of the mayor and board of aldermen and do and perform all other actions required by state law, this charter and direction of the board. 
(c)  The board of aldermen shall provide for an independent annual audit of all city accounts and may provide for such more infrequent audits as it deems necessary. Such audits shall be made by a certified public accountant or firm of such accountants who have no personal interest, direct or indirect, in the fiscal affairs of the city government or any of its officers. The contractee shall not be a public officer, official, or employee of the city nor shall he hold any political office or be an officer or employee of any political party or organization. The audit shall be conducted in all respects in accordance with state law, and the report shall be tendered to the mayor and board of aldermen through the city clerk and shall be published in the official journal. 
(d)  The board of aldermen shall have the right to employ special legal counsel by written contract should the need arise. 
State Law reference- Duties of clerk, R.S. 33:421; annual audit, R.S. 24:517. 
Sec. 209. - Actions. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, actions may be taken either by ordinance, resolution or motion at the discretion of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(b)  All actions having the force and effect of law; or any action that creates a contractual obligation of the city; or any action establishing a fine or other penalty; or any action that requires an expenditure of funds either immediately or in the future; or any action making an appropriation; authorizing the borrowing of money; levying a tax; license or other revenue measure; creating a district; establishing a rule, regulation or law for the violation of which a fine or imprisonment can be imposed; granting or revoking a franchise, or placing any burden upon or limiting the use of private property, shall be by ordinance. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, it is hereby provided that all actions that must be taken pursuant to a general statutory law for the issuance of bonds or other evidences of indebtedness or for the construction of sewerage, street paving, water and drainage improvements that are to be financed by local or special assessments, are excepted from the provisions of this section requiring the adoption of an ordinance if a resolution is the form of action prescribed by the general statutory law pursuant to which the bonds or other evidences of indebtedness are being issued or the construction and financing of the aforesaid improvements are being undertaken. It is hereby further provided that if an ordinance is the form of action required by general statutory law for the issuance of bonds or other evidences of indebtedness or for the construction of sewerage, street paving, water and drainage improvements to be financed by local or special assessments, the requirements of section 2.14 hereof shall not apply insofar as it requires ordinances to be read in full prior to their adoption. 
Editor's note- Section 2.14 of the charter, referred to above, is codified herein as section 211. 
Sec. 210. - Emergency action. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen may waive the procedural requirements of this charter for the passage of ordinances which are necessary for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety. An emergency ordinance shall be adopted by the affirmative vote of four-fifths of the entire authorized membership of the board of aldermen, and the nature of the emergency shall be specifically stated in the minutes of the meeting of the governing body. Emergency legislation may be vetoed by the mayor immediately after its passage, but another four-fifths vote of the board of aldermen[,] immediately after the mayor's veto, shall override the mayor's veto. Emergency legislation shall be effective upon passage. 
(b)  Emergency ordinances shall be effective for no longer than thirty (30) days. The board of aldermen, however, upon a vote of four-fifths of its membership may extend the life of an emergency ordinance for an additional thirty (30) days, but no such ordinance may be extended beyond that period. 
Sec. 211. - Ordinances. 
    The style of all ordinances shall be: "Be it ordained by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana ...." All ordinances shall, within fourteen (14) days after they are passed, be published once in the official journal of the municipality or if there be none, in some newspaper of general circulation therein. Ordinances shall not be enforced, unless for a cause the contrary be ordered, until the day after their publication. All ordinances and resolutions shall be read and considered by sections at a public meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen, and, if adopted shall be signed by the mayor or other officer presiding in his absence. The vote on their final passage shall be taken by "yeas" and "nays" which shall be entered on the minutes by the clerk. A vote shall never be taken on an ordinance not previously reduced to typewritten form. An ordinance shall contain only one (1) subject, which shall be indicated in its title. An ordinance which is amended or revised shall set forth in full the section as amended or revised. The clerk shall keep a book to be styled "Ordinances, City of West Monroe, Louisiana," in which he shall file the original of every ordinance which has been adopted immediately after its passage; he shall append to each a note stating the date of its passage and cite therein the book and page of the minutes containing the record of its passage. The ordinances to be so recorded are those which are in their nature laws of the municipality, and not mere orders or decrees temporary in their nature. 
Sec. 212. - Veto of ordinances by mayor. 
    Any ordinance vetoed by the mayor in accordance with the provisions of this charter shall not be overridden until the next regular meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen. At the next regular session, a simple majority vote shall be sufficient to override the mayor's veto. This section shall not apply to emergency ordinances which must be immediately vetoed by the mayor and which veto by the mayor can be then subsequently at the same meeting overridden by another four-fifths vote of the board of aldermen all as provided hereinabove in this charter. 
Sec. 213. - Investigation and removal. 
    The board of aldermen may investigate the operation of any department or agency of the city government or any department or agency which derives support from appropriations made by the board of aldermen. In any such investigation the board of aldermen may administer oaths, subpoena witnesses and compel the production of records. 
Sec. 214. - Code. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the codification of all ordinances of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, the authority being granted that the mayor and board of aldermen shall provide for the codification of the ordinances and laws of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, at such time when sufficient funds are available. 
    At such time when the codification of ordinances becomes a reality as provided for herein, the classification and arrangement of all ordinances of general applicability shall be in accordance with The Code of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana. The city attorney shall keep the Code current. The mayor and board of aldermen shall in its discretion decide upon periodic published revisions of the Code. 
ARTICLE III. - MAYOR 

Sec. 301. - Executive authority. 
    The mayor shall be the executive officer of the city. All executive and administrative authority shall be exercised by and through the mayor except as set forth in this charter. The mayor will be responsible for conducting and administering all business and affairs of the city, employing and terminating the employment of all personnel except those positions specifically named herein that require the approval of the board of aldermen, expending all funds as provided for in the budget, collecting all revenues due the city and all other duties not specifically delegated to the board of aldermen or other officer by this charter. The mayor shall be permitted to cast a vote at meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen in case of a tie. 
Sec. 302. - Election and term. 
    The next general election for the mayor and board of aldermen of the city shall be held on the Tuesday next following the second Monday of June, 1974 and every four (4) years thereafter. The officials elected shall qualify and enter the discharge of their duties on the first day of July after their election. The terms of office for the mayor and members of the board of aldermen shall be concurrent and shall be for four (4) years. The provisions of state law with regard to municipal primary elections, etc., shall govern insofar as they are not inconsistent with the provisions of this charter. 
State Law reference- Elections, R.S. 18:1 et seq. 
Sec. 303. - Qualifications. 
    The mayor shall be a qualified elector of the city and shall hold no other public office for which he shall be entitled to receive any remuneration or per diem compensation, except that of notary public or membership in the national guard or reserve defense establishment. The mayor must be twenty-one (21) years of age and shall have been a resident of the city for one (1) year and a resident of Ouachita Parish for at least two (2) years. The mayor shall not have been convicted of a felony. Any mayor, ceasing to possess these qualifications[,] or who is convicted of a felony shall immediately become disqualified, creating a vacancy in the office. 
Sec. 304. - Salary. 
    The annual salary of the mayor shall be nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00) and in addition the mayor shall be entitled to be furnished a suitable vehicle and a monthly expense account of one hundred dollars ($100.00). The mayor's salary and other compensation, remuneration or expenses set forth in this section shall be changed only by ordinance. Any ordinance increasing the salary or granting another monetary compensation for the mayor shall be effective only after the next regular mayoralty election and must have been passed at least six (6) months prior to said election. 
Sec. 305. - Vacancy. 
(a)  During a temporary absence from the city or temporary inability to perform the duties of the office of the mayor the vacancy shall be filled by the mayor pro tempore. The mayor pro tempore shall not participate in the capacity of an aldermen in regular meetings of the mayor-board of aldermen during his period as acting mayor. 
(b)  In the event of a vacancy in the office of mayor when the term will expire in less than one (1) year, the mayor pro tempore shall succeed to the mayoralty. A vacancy shall then have been created on the board of aldermen to be filled in accordance with the terms of this charter. If the term of office of the mayor shall be for a period greater than one (1) year, a special election to be held within ninety (90) days shall be called by the board of aldermen. 
Sec. 306. - Office. 
    The mayor shall maintain his office in the city hall of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana. 
Sec. 307. - Authority and responsibility. 
    The mayor in his executive capacity shall supervise and direct the operations of all departments of government. He shall appoint and remove all personnel and employees of the city except those positions that specifically require the approval of the board of aldermen. He shall be ex officio a nonvoting member of all boards and commissions and shall coordinate their efforts with other agencies of the city government. He shall appoint and remove all city officials[,] subject to the provisions of state law and this charter. He shall appoint all members of boards and commissions, except those which specifically require the approval of the board of aldermen. He shall be charged with the enforcement of applicable state law, this charter, ordinances of the city, and with the general enforcement of the law. He shall prepare and submit to the board of aldermen the pay plan, the operating and capital budgets and the capital plan. He shall execute all contracts, agreements, instruments of debt and the like for which the city is obligated, except such instruments as the director of finance may be authorized to execute as herein provided. He shall be the custodian of the seal of the city. 
Sec. 308. - Veto. 
(a)  All ordinances passed by the board of aldermen shall be dated and delivered no later than the day following the meeting in which said ordinances were passed to the office of the mayor by the city clerk. The mayor shall have five (5) calendar days from the date of the meeting in which said ordinance or ordinances were passed either to sign the ordinance or veto it. After action by the mayor within the required time he shall immediately return the ordinance to the city clerk, together with his written reasons in the event of veto. This section shall not apply to emergency ordinances[,] which are specifically covered elsewhere in this charter. 
(b)  An ordinance vetoed by the mayor shall be vetoed in full. The veto of the mayor cannot be over-ridden by the board of aldermen until the next regular meeting of the mayor-board of aldermen following the veto. At the next regular meeting, a simple majority vote by the board of aldermen shall be sufficient to over-ride the mayor's veto. This section shall not apply to the veto of emergency ordinances[,] which is provided for elsewhere in this charter. 
Sec. 309. - Relation to board of aldermen. 
    The mayor may present to the board of aldermen messages and requests for action. The mayor shall preside at all public meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen, unless for cause he is unable to do so, and be heard on matters currently before that body. The mayor shall have no power of vote except in case of a tie and the mayor shall be unable to introduce ordinances or resolutions that have the effect of law. 
Sec. 310. - Report. 
    At the close of each fiscal year the mayor shall render to the board of aldermen and the public a financial and administrative report on activities of the preceding year. 
ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 401. - Organization and control. 
(a)  The administrative branch of the government shall be under the direction, control and supervision of the mayor. The mayor shall carry out the policy direction of the board of aldermen and shall be responsible for the over-all enforcement of the law. 
(b)  The mayor or his designee may investigate the administration and actions of any agency of the city government under his direction. The mayor may prescribe administrative standards and regulations not inconsistent with policy established by the board of aldermen, which shall be applicable for all agencies of the administrative branch. Such administrative rules and regulations shall be reduced to writing and attached to the "policy manual" referred to elsewhere in this charter. 
Sec. 402. - Administrative officer. 
    There is hereby created the position of chief administrative officer of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana. This position shall be under the direct supervision of the mayor. The chief administrative officer shall be appointed by the mayor and shall assume such duties as the mayor may assign to him. He shall be granted such powers and duties in the area of administration that the mayor shall see fit to grant to him that are not inconsistent with the laws of this state and this charter. The administrative officer shall serve at the mayor's pleasure. 
Sec. 403. - Departments and department heads. 
(a)  At such time as this charter shall go into effect there shall be in existence the following departments: 
(1)  Legal department; 
(2)  Department of community services and recreation; 
(3)  Fire department; 
(4)  Police department; 
(5)  City clerk; 
(6)  Utilities and maintenance department. 
The head of the legal department shall be the city attorney; the head of the department of community services and recreation shall be the director of community services and recreation; the head of the fire department shall be the fire chief, the head of the police department shall be the police chief; the city clerk shall head the city clerk's office; and the head of the utilities and maintenance department shall be the supervisor of utilities and maintenance. 
(b)  The mayor is charged with the responsibility of employing and terminating all personnel of the city and department heads except those department heads or employees which specifically require the approval of the board of aldermen under the provisions of this charter and applicable state law. 
Sec. 404. - Legal department. 
(a)  The head of the legal department shall be the city attorney. He shall be appointed by the mayor and shall be responsible to the mayor and board of aldermen only and shall not be directly responsible to department heads and other city employees. The city attorney shall be a licensed attorney with at least a minimum of five (5) years experience in the practice of law. The city attorney shall not hold any other public office[,] either appointive or elective, except that of notary public. The city attorney shall be required to represent and advise the elected mayor and board of aldermen in all legal matters of the city. The city attorney shall be the head of the legal department and his salary and that of any member of the legal department shall be fixed by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(b)  The city attorney shall supervise the conduct of the legal affairs of the city; shall prepare ordinances upon request of the mayor or an alderman and shall render written opinions as to the legality of all contracts, franchises, and other legal instruments, and generally perform all legal duties connected with the affairs of the city. The city attorney, or one of his assistants, shall be the prosecutor in the West Monroe city court. 
(c)  Assistant city attorneys may be appointed by the mayor and their salaries fixed by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
Sec. 405. - Department of community services and recreation. 
(a)  The head of the department of community services and recreation shall be the director of community services and recreation. The director shall be appointed by the mayor and serve at his pleasure. The director shall have a broad and comprehensive background in this field. 
(b)  The director of community services and recreation shall direct and be responsible for programs of athletics, recreational activities, cultural and any other leisure time activities. 
Sec. 406. - Fire department. 
(a)  The head of the fire department shall be the fire chief who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of aldermen in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  The fire chief shall direct and be responsible for fire-fighting apparatus, fire stations and all equipment including fire hydrants, fire extinguishment and salvage operations, inspection and recommendations concerning the fire code of the city, investigation of fires and their causes, and the conduction of fire safety, rescue and prevention programs. 
State Law reference- Fire department, R.S. 33:1961 et seq. 
Sec. 407. - Police department. 
(a)  The head of the police department shall be the police chief who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of aldermen in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  The police chief shall direct and be responsible for the prevention of crime, law enforcement, assistance to the courts and other law enforcement agencies, peace of the city, and the maintenance and welfare of the police department and its facilities. The police department shall not be responsible for administrative duties that would normally be the function of any other department or agency of the city as provided for in this charter or by state law. 
(c)  Unless otherwise provided for by state or federal law, no persons shall exercise police authority in the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, except regularly constituted law enforcement officers of the city, parish, state or federal government. Limited special police powers may be granted by permit by the police chief if authorized by ordinance. 
State Law reference- Police department, R.S. 33:2191 et seq.; arrest by private person, Code of Crim. Proc., Art. 214 et seq. 
Sec. 408. - Office of city clerk. 
    The head of the city clerk's office or department shall be the city clerk of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana. The city clerk shall keep a book to be labeled "Municipal Minutes, City of West Monroe[,]" in which shall be recorded the proceedings of the mayor and board of aldermen, and keep the same fully indexed alphabetically, so that all entries on the minutes can be easily found. The clerk shall be the custodian of the municipal seal. The clerk shall keep a book to be styled "Municipal Docket, City of West Monroe[,]" upon which he shall enter each claim against the municipality, and each subject matter to be acted upon by the mayor and board of aldermen. He shall examine the statutes of the state and the ordinances of the municipality to ascertain subject matter required or proper to be acted upon at the following meeting and shall docket or place on the agenda all such matters. He shall keep such other books and records as may be provided for by ordinance and shall file in his office and preserve all records and papers appertaining to the business of the municipality. The city clerk shall bill and collect all real estate and movable property taxes, collect occupational licenses, bill and collect water and sanitation fees, bill and collect street paving assessments and maintain all accounting records relating thereto. The clerk shall be responsible for all accounting including payrolls, accounts receivable and accounts payable. The clerk shall prepare a monthly financial statement for the mayor and board of aldermen. He shall publish all legal notices in the official journal of the city. The clerk shall keep a record of the bonded indebtedness, make payments, keep cancelled bonds and coupons in bond books all as prescribed by state statute. The city clerk shall be the treasurer of the City of West Monroe. 
State Law reference- Bonded indebtedness, R.S. 39:551 et seq. 
Sec. 409. - Utilities and maintenance department. 
(a)  The head of the department of utilities and maintenance shall be the supervisor of the department of utilities and maintenance and this department shall be responsible for the functions which provide and maintain public works, utilities and services. The supervisor shall be appointed by the mayor and serve at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(b)  This department shall be responsible for all city properties and service functions, supervise contract constructions, supervise and maintain the water and sewerage systems, storm sewers, their collection and disposal. The responsibilities of this department shall include streets and sidewalks, their construction, cleaning and maintenance, drainage ditches, canals, bridges, cemetery operation and maintenance, garbage collection and disposal, general sanitation, control of weeds, grass, trees, shrubbery, maintenance of all city owned movable and immovable property and any related activities. This department shall also, in the area of utilities control, be responsible for the water supply to the community, its equipment, facilities and supplies, sewerage, the collection and disposal of sewage, installation and maintenance of street lights and all other supplies and equipment owned or operated by the city which facilitate the service of utilities, and any other related activities. 
Sec. 410. - New departments authorized. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen of the city shall at such time as they deem necessary provide for the revision and reorganization of existing departmental units and may provide by ordinance for the creation of additional departmental units as follows: 
(1)  Public works department, the head of which shall be the director of public works; 
(2)  Utilities department, the head of which shall be the director of utilities; 
(3)  Juvenile department, the head of which shall be the juvenile officer; 
(4)  Finance department, the head of which shall be the finance director; 
(5)  Any other departments and departmental heads as may be deemed necessary. 
(b)  In the event and at such time as the mayor and board of aldermen of this municipality shall deem it necessary to provide for the creation of a public works department, utilities department, juvenile department, or finance department, the following shall be a general guide as to the functions of said specifically named departments, which general guide is intended to be inclusive and not exclusive. 
(1)  Public works department. 
a.  The head of the public works department shall be the director of public works. This department shall be responsible for all aspects of the function of the public works of the city. The director shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. At the time of appointment, the director shall have at least five (5) years experience in a responsible managerial and/or administrative field related to public works. Recommendations attesting to his ability and proficiency should be available. 
b.  The department of public works, under the supervision of the director, shall direct and be responsible for the street, drainage and engineering services for all city agencies. This department will maintain all city properties of every nature and kind, supervise contract construction, conduct all surveys, maps, and the mapping and describing of city boundaries, construction and maintenance of streets and sidewalks, bridges and drainage systems connected therewith, trash and garbage collection and disposals; street cleaning, control of weeds and grass and any trees, shrubbery or any objects deemed as hazards by the police department which might obstruct line-of-sight clearance at street intersections or which might create hazards that may cause traffic accidents. This department shall supervise and maintain storm water, its collection and disposal facilities. It shall be responsible for licensing and inspections in conjunction with zoning ordinances, building and construction codes, and licensing of trades. This department shall be responsible for any related activities connected with any of the above responsibilities. 
(2)  Utilities department. The head of the utilities department shall be the director of utilities. This department shall be responsible for the maintenance and operation of all city utilities, including but not limited to water, sewerage and sanitation systems and for the performance of such other duties as may be assigned to it by ordinance. 
(3)  Juvenile department. The head of the juvenile department shall be the juvenile officer. The juvenile officer shall be specially trained or experienced in performing case work services in connection with juveniles. The duties of the juvenile officer and this department shall be to investigate, supervise and generally represent the interests of the juvenile offender in his relation to the West Monroe city court and community prior to, and while on probation status. The juvenile officer shall be a duly appointed representative of the West Monroe city court and shall work under the supervision of the West Monroe city judge. This person shall be appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen with the advice and consent of the city judge of the City of West Monroe. 
(4)  Finance department. 
a.  The head of the finance department shall be the finance director. The finance director shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the board of aldermen and after appointment shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. At the time of appointment, the appointee should have a minimum of five (5) years experience in accounting or auditing, managerial and/or administrative experience in fiscal matters. Recommendations attesting to his ability and proficiency should be available. 
b.  The director of finance shall collect all taxes, licenses, permit fees and fines and penalties awarded to the city by the courts and all other monies due to the city as provided by law. The director of finance shall maintain the treasury of the city and negotiate agreements with depository banks subject to the approval of the board of aldermen. As director of finance, he shall procure and account for all property, real and personal, the materials and supplies and services required and authorized by the governing body. He shall maintain perpetual inventory, establish and supervise all accounts for all funds, both operating and capital, trust or otherwise. The director of finance shall prepare and issue all checks for the city[,] permitting no expenditures except those duly authorized in accordance with this charter, city ordinance and/or applicable state laws. The finance director shall be the treasurer of the City of West Monroe. The director of finance shall be responsible for the execution and supervision of operating and capital budgets and provide assistance in budget preparations. He shall provide information on fiscal matters requested by the mayor and shall perform any other duties as directed by the mayor and/or any member of the board of aldermen in accordance with this charter or state laws applicable to municipal finance. 
(c)  Other departments and departmental heads that may be created as authorized by this charter by the mayor and board of aldermen shall have their respective functions designated by ordinance at the time of their creation. 
Sec. 411. - Planning. 
(a)  A planning commission shall be established as authorized by LRS 33:102 et seq., which shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen and shall serve terms as specified by state law. 
(b)  A planning commission chairman shall be elected by the commission members from among its membership. The term of chairmanship shall be set by the commission. 
(c)  The planning commission shall be responsible for preparation and administration of a master plan and zoning plan for the city; shall make recommendations on the capital program and capital budget; shall hear requests and decide disputes arising from zoning, building, and other codes; and shall exercise all other responsibilities affecting the physical development of the city. Any person not satisfied with a decision of the planning commission over disputes arising from zoning, building and other codes may appeal the decision of such commission to the mayor and board of aldermen by filing a written notice of appeal with the office of the mayor within fifteen (15) days from the date of the decision of the commission. The mayor and board of aldermen shall hear and decide these appeals at the earliest convenient date. 
(d)  A planning director may be appointed by the planning commission with the approval of the mayor and board of aldermen. The duties and responsibilities of the planning director shall be established by the planning commission in keeping with its own duties and responsibilities. The mayor and board of aldermen may budget funds for the operation of the planning director's office. 
Sec. 412. - Advisory boards and committees. 
    Advisory boards and committees may be appointed and dissolved as needed by the mayor and board of aldermen and shall submit reports when requested by said body in the form requested by said body. 
ARTICLE V. - PERSONNEL 

Sec. 501. - Policy. 
    The policy of the City of West Monroe shall be to employ from those available the persons best qualified to perform the functions of the city in the capacity for which these persons are employed. 
Sec. 502. - Merit. 
    Except as otherwise provided for by state law, appointments and promotions shall be made on the basis of merit and fitness as demonstrated by examination and/or other evidence of competence. 
Sec. 503. - Director. 
    A personnel director shall be appointed by the mayor and serve at the pleasure of the mayor to administer the personnel system of the city. The chief administrative officer may serve also in the capacity as personnel director. 
Sec. 504. - Rules and procedures. 
    The personnel director shall prepare from time to time personnel rules and procedures in writing for submission to the mayor and board of aldermen. Upon approval of the mayor and adoption by the board of aldermen, either with or without amendment, such rules and procedures shall be administered by the personnel director. These rules and procedures shall be as comprehensive as possible and shall be kept in pamphlet or booklet form and shall be made available to all city employees and officers. 
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE 

Sec. 601. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin July first and end on June thirtieth until changed by ordinance, which ordinance shall also make provision for appropriate change in the affected time schedules as set forth in this charter. 
Sec. 602. - Operating budget form. 
    The operating budget form shall be a detailed listing of proposed expenditures by all applicable departments, agencies, and offices of the city all as the mayor shall deem advisable. The operating budget of revenues shall list in detail each item of revenue. 
Sec. 603. - Submission for study and adoption. 
    The mayor shall be responsible for the preparation of the operating budget. Prior to the submission of the budget to the board of aldermen, the budget shall be reviewed by the finance committee of the board of aldermen for recommendations. The budget shall be submitted to the board of aldermen no less than forty-five (45) days prior to the beginning of the new fiscal year. The budget as submitted or altered by the board of aldermen shall be adopted no later than fifteen (15) days prior to the beginning of the fiscal year. If the board of aldermen fail[s] to act upon and formally adopt a budget ten (10) days prior to the new fiscal year, it shall be presumed to have adopted the budget as submitted by the mayor and the finance committee. 
Sec. 604. - Budget amendments and reporting. 
    Passage of a budget ordinance shall constitute revenue levies and appropriations within the terms of the budget classifications. There shall be no changes in the budget or fund transfers without amendment of the budget ordinance. Quarterly, at the regular meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen, a detailed current financial status report shall be presented to the members of the board of aldermen. The mayor or his designee shall be responsible for presenting this quarterly report. 
Sec. 605. - Unexpended funds. 
    All appropriations shall be for one fiscal year. At the end of the fiscal year, the unexpended appropriated funds shall remain in the general fund for a proper allocation during the ensuing year. 
Sec. 606. - Capital program. 
    The mayor shall submit for a consideration to the board of aldermen any capital budget request or program deemed advisable; provided, however, that any such capital budget request or program submitted to the board of aldermen by the mayor shall be first submitted to the planning commission accompanied by substantiating information concerning need and cost. The planning commission shall review and make its written recommendations to the mayor not later than thirty (30) days after receipt of the mayor's request. The mayor then shall submit to the board of aldermen the capital budget request with his recommendations, together with those recommendations of the planning commission not later than thirty (30) days after receipt of same from the planning commission. The board of aldermen may enact through ordinance such capital programs as it deems appropriate for the general welfare of the city. 
Sec. 607. - Bonded debt. 
    The City of West Monroe is empowered to incur bonded and other types of indebtedness in accordance with the constitution and the laws of this state. 
Sec. 608. - Procurement. 
    Procurement of all property, supplies, materials, services, etc., shall be under a system of central purchasing, shall be in accordance with applicable state law, the policy of the mayor and board of aldermen, administrative requirements and shall be in accordance with established standards and specifications. 
State Law reference- Public contracts, R.S. 38:2181 et seq. 
Sec. 609. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  All franchise or indeterminate permits shall be awarded only after properly advertised [sic] and public hearings. Franchises and indeterminate permits shall be awarded only for monetary or valuable consideration. 
(b)  The city clerk and such other employees as the mayor and board of aldermen may require shall be bonded in such amounts as required by state law. Employee bonding shall be a city expense. 
ARTICLE VII. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 701. - Legal process. 
    Legal process against the city shall be served upon the mayor. 
Sec. 702. - Appointments. 
    All appointments of officers, officials, or employees unless provided for otherwise herein or by applicable state law shall be made by the mayor. 
Sec. 703. - Appointment approval. 
    Appointments and approval of appointments recommended by the mayor which require board of aldermen action shall be by majority vote of the board of aldermen. 
Sec. 704. - Board and commission pay. 
    All members of the [boards] and commissions provided for by this charter or by ordinance shall serve without pay or compensation, except that by ordinance the board of aldermen may authorize reimbursement of members for actual expenses incurred on official business of the city. 
Sec. 705. - Prohibitions. 
    Any officer, official, board member, or employee of the city who has a substantial financial interest, direct or indirect, or by reason of ownership of stock in any corporation, in any contract with the city or in the sale of any land, material, supplies or services to the city or to a contractor supplying the city shall make known that interest and shall refrain from voting upon or otherwise participating in his capacity as a city officer, official, board member or employee in the making of such sale or in the making of performance of such contract. Any city officer, official, board member or employee who willfully conceals such a substantial financial interest or willfully violates the requirements of this section shall be guilty of malfeasance in office or position and shall forfeit his office or position. Violation of this section with the knowledge express or implied of the person or corporation contracting with or making a sale to the city shall render the contract or sale voidable by the mayor and the board of aldermen. 
Sec. 706. - Facsimile signature. 
    Facsimile signatures are authorized for negotiable instruments and multiple certificates of indebtedness and those cases where an official is required to sign by law. 
State Law reference- Use of facsimile signatures and seals, R.S. 39:98.1; certificates of indebtedness, signing, R.S. 33:481, 39:1176. 
Sec. 707. - Continuation in office. 
    Any appointed or elected official or officer of the city shall continue in office until his successor has been appointed or elected and qualified. This section shall not prohibit a valid resignation of an elected official or a valid resignation or dismissal of an appointed official or officer. 
Sec. 708. - Recall. 
(a)  The mayor or any member of the board of aldermen may be removed from office by the electors of the city through a recall process. The procedure for a recall shall be the same as is provided in the general laws of this state. 
(b)  If[,] in a recall election, the majority of those voting vote for recall, the officer named in the recall petition shall be ipso facto removed from office and the vacancy thereby created shall be filled as is the case of ordinary vacancies in accordance with this charter. 
State Constitution reference- Recall, La. Const., Art. X, § 26. 
State Law reference- Recall elections, R.S. 18:1300.1 et seq. 
Sec. 709. - Reconstitution of government. 
    In the event of war or public disaster that incapacitates the mayor and a majority of the board of aldermen, the remaining members of the government may act on an emergency basis and appoint such other officials as [are] necessary to reconstitute a government of the city. It shall be the intent of this section that these emergency powers shall subsist only so long as an emergency exists and that regularly constituted elections shall be held as soon as it is judicially determined that conditions permit their being held. 
State Law reference- Emergency Interim Local Executive Succession Act, R.S. 33:1401 et seq. 
Sec. 710. - Transitional provision. 
    Nothing in this charter shall affect or impair the rights, privileges, or employment of persons who are city officers, department heads, or employees at the time of its adoption. 
Sec. 711. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  If any provision of this charter or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is for any reason held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, the remainder of this charter and its applicability shall not be affected thereby. 
(b)  All actions of the mayor and board of aldermen, or its predecessors, and all administrative rules and regulations not inconsistent with this charter[,] shall remain in full force and effect until changed or repealed. 
(c)  Legal actions, proceedings, contracts, obligations due the city and all allied, kindred and associated matters shall continue unaffected and remain pending regardless of the adoption of this charter. 
(d)  This charter shall not govern the city court of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, which said court shall operate under applicable state, general and special laws affecting said court. 
State Law reference- City courts, R.S. 13:1871 et seq.; fines, forfeitures, costs, penalties, R.S. 13:2010; city court of West Monroe generally, R.S. 13:2089 et seq. 
ARTICLE VIII. - AMENDMENTS 

Sec. 801. - Popular vote. 
    This charter may be replaced or amended, modified or repealed only by a majority vote of the qualified electors of the city voting at a referendum called for such purpose pursuant to applicable state law regarding "home rule charters." 
Editor's note- In the event of repeal of the home rule charter, the city reverts to the "Lawrason Act," R.S. 33:321-33:481, which is a general legislative charter. 
State Constitution reference- Amendment or repeal of home rule charter, La. Const., Art. VI, § 5. 
State Law reference- Amendment of charter, R.S. 33:1395.4. 
ARTICLE IX. - SCHEDULE 

Sec. 901. - Effectiveness of provisions. 
(a)  This charter shall become effective thirty (30) days after official promulgation of the results of the referendum approving the charter. 
(b)  At the time this charter goes into effect all elected public officials of the city shall continue to hold their office throughout the remainder of their term until the next scheduled election or until or unless a vacancy in their respective position occurs. 
(c)  All boards and commissions or other agencies of the city government not provided for in this charter shall be abolished on the effective date of this charter. 
Sec. 902. - Referendum ballot. 
    The ballot for the referendum on this proposed charter shall be: 
"Shall the plan of Government for the City of West Monroe, prepared and submitted by the duly appointed Charter Commission, said plan being prepared according to Article XIV, Section 40 of the Constitution of Louisiana, and Louisiana Revised Statutes Title 33:1381, 1390, and other applicable law be adopted." ?Yes 
?No  
State Constitution reference- Home rule charters, La. Const., Art. VI, § 4 et seq.; compensation of officials, Art. VI, § 12. 
State Law reference- Home rule charters, R.S. 33:1395 et seq. 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 
;adv10; The original charter, §§ 101 through 902, is set out as adopted on March 13, 1971. The following table shows the disposition of amendments adopted at subsequent elections. 
Date of 
Election Section 
Amended  
Part 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapter 1 - USE AND CONSTRUCTION OF CODE 

Sec. 1-1001. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The provisions embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of West Monroe, Louisiana," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1001) 
Charter reference- Actions taken by mayor and board of aldermen, § 209; codification of ordinances, § 214. 
State Constitution reference- Codification of ordinances, La. Const., Art. VI, § 10. 
State Law reference- Adoption of local codes, R.S. 33:1361 et seq. 
Sec. 1-1002. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of aldermen. 
    Board. Whenever the words "the board" or "the city board" are used, they shall mean the board of aldermen of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of West Monroe, Louisiana," followed them. 
    Computation of time. In computing a period of time allowed or prescribed by ordinance, the date of the act, event or default after which the period begins to run is not to be included. The last day of the period is to be included. A legal holiday is to be included in the computation of a period of time allowed or prescribed, except when: 
(1)  It is expressly excluded; 
(2)  It would otherwise be the last day of the period; or 
(3)  The period is less than seven (7) days. 
A half-holiday is considered as a legal holiday. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Civ. Proc., Art. 5059; legal holidays, R.S. 1:55. 
    Gender. A word importing one gender only shall extend and be applied to other genders and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 1:8. 
    Health officer. The term "health officer" shall mean any city, parish or state health officer or his duly authorized representative. 
    Joint authority. All words giving "joint authority" to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be read with their context and shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language. Technical words and phrases, and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 1:3. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person or thing. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 1:7. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:2. 
    Officials, officers, etc. Whenever reference is made to officers, agencies, boards, commissions or departments by title only, i.e., "mayor," "clerk," "city attorney," "chief of police," etc., they shall mean the officers, agencies, boards, commissions or departments of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana. 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Parish. The words "the parish" or "this parish" shall mean the Parish of Ouachita, Louisiana. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include any natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust or organization of any kind. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:2. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include both public and private property, real, personal and mixed, movable and immovable, and corporeal and incorporeal property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:2, 47:1702, Code of Civ. Proc., Art. 5251(13). 
    R.S. The term "R.S." or "Louisiana Revised Statutes" or other words to that effect shall mean the official revised laws of Louisiana, as amended. 
    Signature or subscription. A signature or subscription shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Louisiana. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way or place of whatever nature publicly maintained and open to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel, including bridges, causeways, tunnels and ferries; the word "street" is synonymous with the word "highway." 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:1. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1976, §§ 1-1002, 12-3002; Ord. No. 2093, § 1, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 1-1003. - Catchlines of sections; history notes. 
    The catchlines of sections in this Code printed in boldface type and citations included at the end of sections are intended to indicate the contents of the section and the original historical source respectively, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles and official sources of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines or citations, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1003) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 1:13. 
Sec. 1-1004. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(c)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1004; Ord. No. 2093, § 2, 3-12-85) 
State Law reference- Effect of repeal of law, R.S. 1:15. 
Sec. 1-1005. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code and of any act or code adopted by reference herein are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this Code or of any act or code adopted by reference herein shall be declared unconstitutional, illegal or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code or of any act or code adopted by reference herein. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1005; Ord. No. 2093, § 3, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 1-1006. - Amendments; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion hereof, the repealed portions may be excluded from this Code by omission from reprinted pages. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending the provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "Be it ordained by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, that section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of West Monroe, Louisiana is hereby amended to read as follows." (The ordinance shall set out the new provisions in full.) 
(c)  When the board desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature on a subject not heretofore existing in this Code, which the board desires to incorporate into the Code, a section in substantially the following language shall be made a part of the ordinance: 
    "Section ___________. Be it ordained by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made a part of the Code of Ordinances, City of West Monroe, Louisiana, and the sections of this ordinance may be re-numbered to accomplish this intention." 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1006; Ord. No. 2093, § 4, 3-12-85) 
Charter reference- Ordinances, § 211. 
Sec. 1-1007. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with this Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1007) 
Sec. 1-1008. - General penalty. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by applicable state law, whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in the Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall aid, abet or assist in the violation of any provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in this section. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1008) 
Cross reference- City court, § 2-5002. 
State Law reference- Penalties for operating vehicle while intoxicated, R.S. 13:1894.1, 14:98; penalty for attempt to commit crime, R.S. 14:27; remittance or abatement of fine or imprisonment, R.S. 15:301. 
Sec. 1-1009. - Fines recoverable by civil action. 
    All fines shall be recoverable by civil action before any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1976, § 1-1009) 
Sec. 1-1010. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions of this Code, insofar as they are the same as those of the former city Code, or of ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Ord. No. 2093, § 5, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 1-1011. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
(a)  This Code shall be treated and considered as a new and comprehensive Code of Ordinances of the city which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances enacted by the board prior to the date specified in the adopting ordinance, except such as by references thereto are expressly saved from repeal or continued in force and effect for any purpose. 
(b)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance not provided for herein, on the following subjects: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Any ordinance fixing rates, charges or fees for garbage, water or sewer services or any combination of such services; 
(3)  Any ordinance fixing salaries or compensation of officers or employees of the city; 
(4)  Any appropriation or budget ordinance; 
(5)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(6)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(7)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city or vacating any such plat; 
(8)  Any ordinance annexing property to the city; 
(9)  Any taxation ordinance of the city other than on the subjects covered herein; 
(10)  Any ordinance providing for zoning or any ordinance rezoning property or granting special uses; 
(11)  Any ordinance relating to local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2093, § 6, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 1-1012. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  A supplement to this Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Ord. No. 2093, § 7, 3-12-85) 
Chapter 2 - CORPORATE LIMITS 

Sec. 1-2001. - Map of city designated as official map. 
    The official corporate limits of the city shall be as identified by written legal description or as drawn upon a map of the city, as now or hereafter amended, which is on file in the office of the city clerk and which is hereby incorporated herein by reference. 
(Code 1976, § 1-2001) 
Charter reference- Boundaries, § 103. 
Sec. 1-2002. - Annexation of territory-State law adopted. 
    The city hereby adopts and enacts Louisiana legislation pertaining to annexation of territory to the corporate limits of a municipality specifically as set forth in Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 33, Subpart B (R.S. 33:151 et seq.) and Subpart C (R.S. 33:171 et seq.), together with all revisions and amendments as same hereafter may be enacted by the Louisiana Legislature. 
(Ord. No. 1646, § 1, 6-14-77) 
Sec. 1-2003. - Same-Duties of planning commission. 
(a)  The planning commission shall be vested with authority to perform any and all acts necessary and proper to fulfill the following responsibilities in connection with annexation of territory to the corporate limits of the city: 
(1)  To accept and review petition(s) and/or application(s) for annexation and make such investigation(s) deemed necessary by the planning commission; 
(2)  To hold public hearings and to give notice thereof all in accordance with law; 
(3)  To prepare a record of the proceedings of each petition and/or application for annexation, said record to be filed in the office of the planning commission as a public record; 
(4)  To furnish the mayor and board of aldermen a certified copy of the record of the proceedings of each petition and/or application for annexation as needed; 
(5)  To submit to the mayor and board of aldermen the recommendation of the planning commission as to each petition and/or application for annexation; 
(6)  To take whatever action is necessary to comply with the Voting Rights Act of 1965, section 5 (42 U.S.C. 1973c) or any other federal and/or state law; 
(7)  To notify the supervisor of municipal protection of the Louisiana rating and fire prevention bureau of the adoption by the city council of any ordinance extending the boundaries of the city; 
(8)  To do and perform any and all other acts necessary and proper to fulfill the responsibilities to comply with the procedure for annexation enumerated in R.S. 33:151 et seq. and R.S. 33:171 et seq. in addition to any other state and/or federal law and/or city charter and/or ordinances. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall be construed to delegate from the board of aldermen the responsibility to act on the question of whether or not an ordinance concerning annexation shall be adopted nor shall anything herein be construed to delegate from the board of aldermen any authority and/or responsibility which by law must be performed by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 1646, § 2, 6-14-77) 
Cross reference- Planning commission, § 2-6001 et seq. 
State Law reference- Louisiana Insurance Rating Commission and rate regulation, R.S. 22:1401 et seq.
