Sec. 2-4033.1. - Imposition of additional tax. 
(a)  In addition to the taxes otherwise imposed by this code, there is hereby levied from and after January 1, 1997, for a period of ten (10) years from said date, for the purposes stated in Resolution No. 296 of the city, as adopted on January 9, 1996, and as approved by the electorate of the city on March 12, 1996, an additional tax upon the sale at retail, the use, the lease or rental, the consumption and the storage for use or consumption of tangible personal property and upon the sale of services within the city, all as defined in Part 2, Chapter 4, Article C of the Code of Ordinances of the city, and the levy of such tax shall be as follows: 
(1)  At the rate of one percent of the sales price of each item or article of tangible personal property when sold at retail in this city, the tax to be computed on gross sales for the purpose of remitting the amount of tax due the city and to include each and every retail sale. 
(2)  At the rate of one percent of the cost price of each item or article of tangible personal property when the same is not sold, but is used, consumed, distributed, or stored for use or consumption in this city, provided there shall be no duplication of the tax. 
(3)  At the rate of one percent of the gross proceeds derived from the lease or rental of tangible personal property, as defined herein, where the lease or rental of such property is an established business or the same is incidental or germane to the said business. 
(4)  At the rate of one percent of the monthly lease or rental price paid by the lessee or renter, or contracted or agreed to be paid by the lessee or renter to the owner of the tangible personal property. 
(5)  At the rate of one percent of the gross proceeds derived from the sale of services, as defined in section 2-4023 of this Code. 
(b)  This tax, and any applicable penalties or costs, shall be calculated, levied, administered, reported, assessed, paid and collected as provided for and as determined in Part 2, Chapter 4, Articles C and D of the Code of Ordinances of the city, it being the intent that the calculation, levy, administration, reporting, assessment, payment and collection of this tax shall be identical with that tax established and levied by Ordinance No. 1631 of the city, except as to the term of imposition and purposes to which it is dedicated. 
(c)  The tax shall be collected from the dealer and/or wholesaler, as defined in this article, and paid at the time and in the manner provides, shall be in addition to all other taxes, whether levied in the forms of sales, excise, license, privilege or property taxes levied by any other ordinance or resolution of the city, and particularly in addition to those taxes levied by Ordinance No. 1631 of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2173, 11-11-86; Ord. No. 2732, 3-20-96) 
Editor's note- The tax imposed by Sec. 2-4033.1 was renewed for an additional 10 years, through December 31, 2016, by Ord. No. 3588, adopted August 8, 2006. 
Sec. 2-4033.2. - Same-From and after December 1, 1991. 
(a)  In addition to the tax imposed by Ordinance No. 1463 adopted on July 18, 1972 and that imposed by Sec. 2-4033.1, there is hereby levied from and after December 1, 1991, for the purposes stated in Resolution No. 235 of the City of West Monroe, as adopted on September 10, 1991, and as approved by the electorate of the City of West Monroe on November 16, 1991, an additional tax upon the sale at retail, the use, the lease or consumption and the storage for use or consumption of tangible personal property and upon the sale of services within the city, all as defined in Part 2, Chapter 4, Article C of the Code of Ordinances, City of West Monroe, Louisiana, and the levy of such tax shall be as follows: 
(1)  At the rate of one percent of the sale price of each item or article of tangible personal property when sold at retail in the city, the tax to be computed on gross sales for the purpose of remitting the amount of tax due the city and to include each and every retail sale. 
(2)  At the rate of one percent of the cost price of each item or article of tangible personal property when the same is not sold, but is used, consumed, distributed, or stored for use or consumption in this city, provided there shall be no duplication of the tax. 
(3)  At the rate of one percent of the gross proceeds derived from the lease or rental of tangible personal property, as defined herein, where the lease or rental of such property is an established business or the same is incidental or germane to the said business. 
(4)  At the rate of one percent of the monthly lease or rental price paid by the lessee or renter, or contracted or agreed to be paid by the lessee or rental to the owner of the tangible personal property. 
(5)  At the rate of one percent of the gross proceeds derived from the sale of services, as defined in section 2-4023 of this Code. 
(b)  This tax, and any applicable penalties or costs, shall be calculated, levied, administered, reported, assessed, paid and collected as provided for and as determined in Part 2, Chapter 4, Articles C and D of the Code of Ordinances of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, it being the intent that the calculation, levy, administration, reporting, assessment, payment and collection of this tax shall be identical with that tax established and levied by Ordinance No. 1631 of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, except as to the term of imposition and purposes to which it is dedicated. 
(c)  The tax shall be collected from the dealer and/or wholesaler, as defined in this article, and paid at the time and in the manner provided; shall be in addition to all other taxes, whether levied in the form of sales, excise, license, privilege or property taxes levied by any other ordinance or resolution of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2442, § 1, 11-21-91) 
Sec. 2-4033.3. - Additional sales tax. 
(a)  Imposition. Pursuant to the authority of a special election held in the city on December 6, 2014, the tax is hereby levied upon the sale at retail, the use, the lease or rental, the consumption, and the storage for use or consumption, of tangible personal property, and upon the lease or rental of tangible personal property and on the sales of services in the City of West Monroe, State of Louisiana, as defined by law. The Uniform Local Sales Tax Code, as enacted by Act 73 of the 2003 Regular Session of the Louisiana Legislature and as it may be amended, shall apply in the assessment, collection, administration and enforcement of the tax, the provisions of which are hereby incorporated by reference. 
(b)  Rate of tax. The tax is levied at the rate of forty-nine hundredths of one percent (.49%) of the sales price of each item or article of tangible personal property when sold at retail in the city, the tax to be computed on gross sales for the purpose of remitting the amount of tax due to the city, and to include each and every retail sale. The tax is levied at the rate of forty-nine hundredths of one percent (.49%) of the cost price of each item or article of tangible personal property when the same is not sold but is used, consumed, distributed, or stored for use or consumption in the city, provided there shall be no duplication of the tax. The tax is levied at the rate of forty-nine hundredths of one percent (.49%) of the gross proceeds derived from the lease or rental of tangible personal property, as defined by law, where the lease or rental of such property is an established business, or part of an established business, or the same is incidental or germane to the said business, or of the monthly lease or rental price paid by lessee or rentee, or contracted or agreed to be paid by lessee or rentee to the owner of the tangible personal property. The tax is levied at the rate of forty-nine hundredths of one percent (.49%) of the amount paid or charged for taxable services, as defined by law, performed in the city. 
(c)  Effective date. The tax shall be effective on April 1, 2015. 
(d)  Term. The tax shall remain in effect without limit as to term or duration. 
(e)  Purposes. The proceeds of the tax shall be used for the purposes set forth in the proposition approved by the voters in the special election held in the city on December 6, 2014, authorizing the tax, which proposition is set forth in the preamble hereto. 
(f)  Vendor's compensation. For the purpose of compensating the dealer in accounting for and remitting the tax levied by this ordinance [section], each dealer shall be allowed one percent (1%) of the amount of tax due and accounted for and remitted to the city's collector in the form of a deduction in submitting its report and paying the amount due by the dealer, provided the amount due was not delinquent at the time of payment, and provided the amount of any credit claimed for taxes already paid to a wholesaler shall not be deducted in computing the commission allowed the dealer hereunder. 
(g)  Exclusions and exemptions. Except as provided below, the city adopts none of the optional exclusions or exemptions allowed by state sales and use tax law, nor does the city adopt any exclusions or exemptions authorized by legislation enacted under Article VI, Section 29(D)(1) of the Constitution of the State of Louisiana of 1974, that are not allowed as an exclusion or exemption from state sales and use tax. Included within the base of the tax is every transaction, whether sales, use, lease or rental, consumption, storage or service, with no exclusions or exemptions except for those mandated upon political subdivisions by the Constitution or statutes of the State of Louisiana, including the Act. Notwithstanding the above, the city provides for the following exceptions: 
(1)  That exception adopted by the city pursuant to ordinance 3276, enacted October 31, 2002, authorized by R.S. 47:337.10F, which provides: 
Charges for the furnishing of repairs to tangible personal property shall be excluded from sales of services when the repaired property is delivered to the customer in another state either by common carrier or the repair dealer's own vehicle (or as to aircraft, by the best available means). 
(h)  Interest on unpaid amount of tax due. As authorized by R.S. 47:337.69, the interest on unpaid amounts of the Tax which are due shall be at the rate of one and one-fourth percent (11/4%) per month. 
(i)  Delinquency penalty. The delinquency penalty, as provided by R.S. 47:337.70, shall be five percent (5%) per month on the unpaid amount of the tax due for each thirty-day period, not to exceed five (5) thirty-day periods. 
(j)  Penalty for false, fraudulent or grossly incorrect return. The penalty as authorized by R.S. 47:337.72 shall be fifty percent (50%) of the amount of the tax found to be due. 
(k)  Negligence penalty. The penalty as authorized by R.S. 47:337.73 shall be five percent (5%) of the unpaid amount of the tax found to be due, or ten dollars ($10.00), whichever is greater. 
(l)  Penalty for insufficient funds check. The penalty as authorized by R.S. 47:337.74 shall be an amount equal to the greater of one percent (1%) of the check or twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(m)  Attorney fees. The collector is authorized to employ private counsel to assist in the collection of any taxes, penalties or interest due under this ordinance [section], or to represent him in any proceeding under this ordinance [section]. If any taxes, penalties or interest due under this ordinance [section] are referred to an attorney at law for collection, an additional charge of attorney fees, in the amount of ten per centum (10%) of the taxes, penalties and interest due, shall be paid by the tax debtor. 
(n)  Penalty for costs incurred. As provided by R.S. 47:337.75, and under the circumstances set forth therein, a penalty shall be added to the amount of tax due in an amount as itemized by the collector to compensate for all costs incurred in making an examination of books, records or documents, or an audit thereof, or in the holding of hearings or the subpoenaing and compensating of witnesses. 
(o)  Distraint penalty. The penalty as provided by R.S. 47:337.76 in cases where the distraint procedure is used in the collection of the tax shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(p)  Limits on interest, penalty and attorney fees. Should the interest, penalties or attorney fees herein, or the combined interest, penalties and attorney fees, be declared to be in excess of limits provided by other law, including relevant jurisprudence, then the maximum interest, penalties and attorney fees allowed by such other law shall apply. 
(q)  Collector. The tax levied by this ordinance [section] is authorized to be collected by a "collector" which term shall mean the City of Monroe, until such time as a successor collector is designated for collection of sales taxes in Ouachita Parish. 
(r)  Powers of collector. The collector is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to carry into effect the provisions of this ordinance [section], to appoint deputies, assistants or agents to assist it in the performance of its duties, and in pursuance thereof to make and enforce such rules as it may deem necessary. 
(s)  Agreement to collect tax on vehicles. With regard to the collection of the tax on any motor vehicle, automobile, truck, truck-trailer, trailer, semi-trailer, motor bus, home trailer, or any other vehicle subject to the vehicle registration license tax, this governing authority, acting through the mayor of the city, is authorized to enter into an agreement or agreements with the vehicle commissioner, department of public safety and corrections, for the collection of the tax on such vehicles, as provided by R.S. 47:303(B). 
(t)  Revenues of tax. All taxes, revenues, funds, assessments, moneys, penalties, fees or other income which may be collected or come into the possession of the collector under any provision or provisions of this ordinance [section] relating to the tax shall be promptly deposited by the collector for the account of the city in a special fund to be established and maintained for the deposit of such proceeds, which fund shall be a separate bank account to be maintained with the regularly designated fiscal agent of the city; provided, however, any amount which is paid under protest or which is subject to litigation may be transferred to a separate account established by the collector with said fiscal agent pending the final determination of the protest or litigation. 
In compliance with the said special election of December 6, 2014, authorizing the tax, after all reasonable and necessary costs and expenses of collecting and administration of the tax have been paid as provided for above, the remaining balance in said special fund shall be available for appropriation and expenditures by this governing authority solely for the purposes designated in the applicable proposition authorizing the levy of the tax. 
(u)  Uniform sales tax controlling. If any provision of this ordinance [section] shall be in conflict with the provisions of the Uniform Local Sales Tax Code, the provisions of the Uniform Local Sales Tax Code shall be controlling. 
(Ord. No. 4239, § 1, 1-13-15) 
Sec. 2-4034. - Collections by dealer. 
(a)  Required. The tax levied by this article shall be collected by the dealer from the purchaser or consumer, except as provided for the collection of the tax on motor vehicles in subsection (f) of this section. The dealer shall have the same right in respect to collecting the tax from the purchaser, or in respect to nonpayment of the tax by the purchaser, as if the tax were a part of the purchase price of the property, or charges for services and payable at the time of the sale; provided, however, that the board shall be joined as a party plaintiff in any action or proceeding brought by the dealer to collect the tax. 
State Law reference- Treatment of tax by dealer, R.S. 47:304. 
(b)  Dealers outside city. Every dealer located outside the city making sales of tangible personal property for distribution, storage, use, or other consumption, in this city shall, at the time of making sales, collect the tax imposed by this article from the purchaser. 
(c)  Tax as debt. The dealer shall, as far as practicable, add the exact amount of the tax imposed under this article, or the average equivalent thereof, in conformity with the rules and regulations to be issued by the collector, to the sale price or charge, and when added, such tax shall constitute a part of such price or charge and shall be a debt from the purchaser or consumer to the dealer, until paid, and shall be recoverable at law, in the same manner as other debts. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:304. 
(d)  Certificate of registration. In order to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article, and to collect all of the taxes imposed by this article, on or before December 1, 1976, or in the case of dealers commencing business after December 1, 1976, or opening new places of business after such date, within three (3) days after such commencement or opening, every dealer purchasing or importing tangible personal property for resale shall file with the collector a certificate of registration in a form prescribed by him. The collector shall, within five (5) days after such registration, issue without charge to each dealer who purchases or imports for resale a certificate of authority empowering such dealer to collect the tax from the purchaser, and the duplicates thereof, for each additional place of business of such dealer. Each certificate or duplicate shall state the place of business to which it is applicable. Such certificate of authority shall be prominently displayed in all places of business of the dealer. A dealer who has no regular place of doing business shall attach such certificate to his cart, stand, truck or other merchandising device. Such certificate shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and shall be surrendered immediately to the collector upon the dealer's ceasing to do business at the place therein named. 
(e)  Duty of wholesalers. A manufacturer, wholesale dealer, jobber or supplier shall refuse to accept a certificate that any property upon which a tax is imposed by this article is purchased for resale, and shall collect the tax imposed by this article, unless the purchaser shall have filed a certificate of registration and received a certificate of authority to collect the tax imposed hereby; provided, however, that the payment of the tax by such purchaser shall not relieve the purchaser of the duty herein imposed upon such purchaser to collect the tax upon any resale made by him; but such purchaser who shall thereafter file a certificate of registration and receive a certificate of authority to collect the tax may, upon application therefor, receive a refund of the taxes paid by him upon property thereafter resold by him, and upon the receipts from which he shall have collected and paid over to the board the tax herein imposed. 
(f)  Vehicles. The tax imposed by this article upon the sale or use of any motor vehicle, automobile, motorcycle, truck, truck-tractor, trailer, semi-trailer, motor bus, house trailer, or any other vehicle subject to the vehicle registration license tax of the state shall be collected as provided in this subsection. 
(1)  The tax levied by this article on any such vehicle shall be paid to the state vehicle commissioner as the agent of the state collector of revenue at the time of application for a certificate of title or vehicle registration license and such tax shall be administered and collected by the vehicle commissioner in compliance with rules and regulations issued by the collector of revenue and in compliance with the law as construed by the collector of revenue. No certificate of title or vehicle registration license shall be issued until this tax has been paid. The collector of revenue shall be the only proper party to defend or to institute any legal action involving the tax imposed by this article on the sale or use of any motor vehicle, automobile, motorcycle, truck, truck-tractor, trailer, semi-trailer, motor bus, house trailer or any other vehicle subject to the vehicle registration license tax (R.S. 47:451 et seq.). 
a.  The tax levied by this article on the sale of any such vehicle shall be due at the time of registration or any transfer of registration as required by the Vehicle Registration License Tax Law of the State of Louisiana (R.S. 47:451 et seq.). 
b.  The tax levied by this ordinance on the use of any such vehicle in this city shall be due at the time the first registration in this city is required by the Vehicle Registration License Tax Law (R.S. 47:451 et seq.). 
(2)  Every vendor of such a vehicle shall furnish to the purchaser at the time of sale a sworn statement showing the serial number, motor number, type, year and model of the vehicle sold, the total sales price, any allowance for and description of any vehicle taken in trade and the total cash difference paid or to be paid by the purchaser between the vehicles purchased and traded in and the sales or use tax to be paid, along with such other information as may be required. All labor, parts, accessories and other equipment which are attached to the vehicle at the time of the sale and which are included in the sale price are to be considered a part of the vehicle. 
(3)  It is not the intention of this section to grant an exemption from the tax levied by this article to any sale, use, item or transaction which has heretofore been taxable and this section shall not be construed as so doing. It is the intention of this section to transfer the collection of sales and use tax on vehicles from the vendor to the vehicle commissioner as agent for the collector of revenue of the state, and to provide a method of collection of the tax directly from the vendee or user by the vehicle commissioner as agent of the collector of revenue in accordance with an agreement by and between the collector of revenue or the vehicle commissioner as agent therefor and the board, the execution of which agreement is hereby authorized. Said tax so collected for said collector of revenue shall be paid to the board and sent to the collector as soon as possible, and in any event at least once each quarter, all in accordance with the agreement. 
(4)  The provisions contained in the definition of "retail sale" in section 2-4023 which exclude isolated or occasional sales from the definition of a sale at retail are not to apply to the sale of vehicles which are the subject to this subsection. Isolated or occasional sales of vehicles are hereby defined to be sales at retail and as such are subject to the tax. 
State Law reference- Collection of tax on vehicles, R.S. 47:303. 
(g)  Payment by seller. A person engaged in any business taxable under this article shall not advertise or hold out to the public, in any manner, directly or indirectly, that he will absorb all or any part of the tax, or that he will relieve the purchaser from the payment of all or any part of the tax. The dealer shall state and collect the tax separately from the price paid by the purchaser, but his failure to do so shall not be available as a defense to the purchaser in any proceedings brought under this article. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, penalty, R.S. 47:304. 
(h)  Tax over one percent. Where the tax collected for any period is in excess of one percent, the total tax collected must be paid over to the collector, less the commission to be allowed the dealer as set forth in this section. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:304. 
(i)  When tax unpaid. Where the purchaser has failed to pay and a dealer has failed to collect a tax upon a sale, as imposed by this article, then in addition to all other rights, obligations and remedies provided, such tax shall be payable by the purchaser directly to the board, and it shall be the duty of this purchaser to file a return thereof with the collector and to pay the tax imposed thereon to the board within fifteen (15) days after such sale was made or rendered. 
State Law reference- Failure to collect or pay tax, R.S. 47:304, 47:314. 
(j)  Commission. For the purpose of compensating the dealer in accounting for and remitting the tax levied by this article, each dealer shall be allowed one percent of the amount of tax due and accounted for and remitted to the collector in the form of a deduction in submitting his report and paying the amount due by him, provided if the amount due was not delinquent at the time of payment. 
(Ord. No. 1631, §§ 4.01-4.10, 10-12-76; Ord. No. 2092, § 6, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 22-93, § 1, 5-9-89) 
State Law reference- Cost of collection of state tax, R.S. 47:317. 
Sec. 2-4035. - Collection from dealer. 
(a)  Generally. The tax imposed by this article shall be collectible by the collector on behalf of the board from all persons engaged as dealers. 
(1)  The collector is duly authorized and empowered to carry into effect the provisions of this article, and in pursuance thereof to make and enforce such rules as he may deem necessary. Such regulations when promulgated shall have the full force and effect of law. Promulgation shall be accomplished by publication at least one time in the official journal of the city. 
(2)  The collector may employ such personnel, including legal counsel on a fee or salary basis, as are necessary to assist in the collection of the taxes imposed hereunder. 
(3)  Any duly authorized representative or deputy of the collector, when acting under his authority and direction, shall have the same power as if conferred upon the collector by this article. 
(4)  The collector may conduct hearings and administer oaths, and examine under oath, any dealer and the directors, officers, agents and employees of any dealer, and any other witness, relative to the business of such dealer in respect to any matter incident to the administration of this article. 
State Law reference- Regulations of collector of revenue for the state, R.S. 47:304. 
(b)  Imports. On all tangible personal property imported, or caused to be imported, from other states or other political subdivisions of this state, or any foreign country, and used by him, the dealer shall pay the tax imposed by this article on all articles of tangible personal property so imported and used, the same as if said articles had been sold at retail for use or consumption in this city. For the purpose of this article, use or consumption, or distribution, or storage of tangible personal property shall each be equivalent to a sale at retail, and the tax shall thereupon immediately be levied and be collected in the manner provided herein, provided there shall be no duplication of the tax in any event. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:303. 
(c)  Credit. A credit against the use tax imposed by this article shall be granted to taxpayers who have paid a similar tax upon the sale or use of the same tangible personal property in another city or parish in the state, or city or county in a state other than Louisiana. The credit provided herein shall be granted only in the case where the city or parish in the State of Louisiana, or the city or county in a state other than Louisiana to which a similar tax has been paid grants a similar credit as provided herein; provided that members of the armed forces who are citizens of this state and whose orders or enlistment contracts stipulate a period of active duty of two (2) years or more and who purchase automobiles outside of this state while on such tour of active duty shall be granted such credit in connection with the purchase of such automobiles whether or not the state to which such tax thereon has been paid grants a similar credit as herein provided. The proof of payment of the similar tax to another city or parish in the State of Louisiana, or to a city or county in a state other than Louisiana shall be made according to rules and regulations promulgated by the collector. In no event shall the credit be greater than the tax imposed by this city upon the particular tangible personal property which is the subject of the use tax imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 1631, §§ 5.01-5.03, 10-12-76; Ord. No. 2092, § 7, 3-12-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:303. 
Sec. 2-4036. - Returns; payment. 
(a)  When paid. The tax levied under this article shall be due and payable by all dealers monthly on the first day of the month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:306. 
(b)  Submission of returns. For the purpose of ascertaining the amount of tax payable under this article, it shall be the duty of all dealers on or before the twentieth day of the month following the month in which this tax shall become effective to transmit to the collector, upon forms prescribed, prepared and furnished by him, returns showing the gross sales, purchases, gross proceeds from lease or rental, gross payments for lease or rental, gross proceeds derived from sales of services, or gross payments for services, as the case may be, arising from all taxable transactions during the preceding calendar month. Thereafter, like returns shall be prepared and transmitted to said collector by all dealers, on or before the twentieth day of each month, for the preceding calendar month. Said returns shall show such further information as the collector may require to enable him to correctly compute and collect the tax herein levied. Such returns shall be signed by the dealer filing the same, and his signature thereon shall constitute a warranty on the part of the dealer that he has read and examined said returns and that, to the best of his knowledge and belief, the same are true, correct and complete. Every dealer, at the time of making the return required hereunder, shall compute and remit to the board the required tax due for the preceding calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:306. 
(c)  Delinquency; remittance. Failure to so remit such tax shall cause said tax to become delinquent. All taxes, interest and penalties imposed under this article shall be paid to the board in the form of remittance required by the collector. 
(d)  Rentals, leases. Gross proceeds from rentals or leases of tangible personal property where the lease or rental is part of a regularly established business, or the same is incidental or germane thereto shall be reported and the tax shall be paid with respect thereto, in accordance with such rules and regulations as the collector may prescribe. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:306. 
(e)  Extensions. The collector, for good cause, may extend, for not to exceed thirty (30) days, the time for making any returns required under the provisions of this article. 
(f)  Dealer as agent. For the purpose of collecting and remitting to the board the tax imposed by this article, the dealer is hereby declared to be the agent of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1631, §§ 6.01-6.06, 10-12-76) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:306. 
Sec. 2-4037. - Records; inspection. 
(a)  General duties of dealers. It shall be the duty of every dealer to make a report and pay any tax under this article, to keep and preserve suitable records of the sales or purchases or sales of services, as the case may be, taxable hereunder, and such other books of account as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax due hereunder, and other information as may be required by the collector; and it shall be the duty of every such dealer, moreover, to keep and preserve, for a period of three (3) years, all invoices and other records of goods, wares and merchandise or other subjects of taxation under this article; and all such books, invoices and other records shall be open to examination at all reasonable hours, by the collector or any of his duly authorized agents. 
State Law reference- Dealers required to keep records, penalty, R.S. 47:309. 
(b)  Records of sales, etc. Each dealer shall secure, maintain and keep, for a period of three (3) years, a complete record of sales of services and tangible personal property received, used, sold at retail, distributed or stored, leased or rented within this city by said dealer, together with invoices, bills of lading and other pertinent records and papers as may be required by the collector for the reasonable administration of this article, and all such records shall be open for inspection to the collector at all reasonable hours. 
(c)  Wholesalers. In order to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article, and to collect all of the tax imposed by this article, all wholesale dealers and jobbers in this city are hereby required to keep a record of all sales of tangible personal property made in this city, whether such sales are for cash or on terms of credit. The record required to be kept by all wholesale dealers and jobbers shall contain and include the name and address of the purchaser, the date of the purchase, the article or articles purchased and the price at which the article is sold to the purchaser. These records shall be open to inspection of the collector or his duly authorized assistants or deputies at all reasonable hours. 
State Law reference- Wholesalers and jobbers required to keep records, penalty, R.S. 47:310. 
(d)  Inspections generally. For the purpose of administering this article, the collector, whenever he deems it expedient, may make or cause to be made by an employee of the department engaged in the administration of this article, an examination or investigation of the place of business, if any, the tangible personal property, and the books, records, papers, vouchers, accounts and documents of any dealer. It shall be the duty of every dealer and every director, official, agent or employee of every dealer, to exhibit to the collector or to any such employee of his department charged with the collection of the tax imposed by this article, referred to in this article as a "deputy," the tangible personal property and all of the books, records, papers, vouchers, accounts and documents of the dealer and to facilitate any such examination or investigation as far as it may be in his power so to do. 
(e)  Transportation companies. For the purpose of enforcing the collection of the tax levied by this article, the collector is hereby specifically authorized and empowered to examine, at all reasonable hours, the books, records and other documents of all transportation companies, agencies or firms operating in this city whether said companies, agencies or firms conduct their business by truck, rail, water, airplane or otherwise, in order to determine what dealers, as provided in this article, are importing or are otherwise shipping articles of tangible personal property which are liable for said tax. 
State Law reference- Collector's authority to examine records of transportation companies, R.S. 47:311. 
(f)  Collector's records. The collector shall keep a record of all of his official acts and shall preserve copies of all rules, decisions and orders made by him or by any deputy of his department in charge of the collection of the tax imposed by this article. Copies of such rules, decisions or orders and of any paper or papers filed in any office maintained by him in the administration of this article may be authenticated under his official signature, and when so authenticated, shall be evidence in all courts of the state of the same weight and force as the original thereof. 
(g)  Confidentiality. The records and files of the collector respecting the administration of this article shall be considered confidential and privileged and neither the collector nor any employee engaged in the administration thereof or charged with the custody of any such records or files shall divulge or disclose any information obtained from such records or files or from any examination or inspection of the premises or property of any dealer. Neither the collector nor any employee engaged in such administration or charged with the custody of any such records or files shall be required to produce any of them for the inspection of any person or for use in any action or proceeding except: 
(1)  In an action or proceeding under the provisions of this article; and 
(2)  When the records or files or the facts shown thereby are directly involved in such action or proceedings. 
(h)  Interpretation. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prevent: 
(1)  The delivery to a dealer or his duly authorized representatives of a copy of any return, report or other paper filed by him pursuant to the provisions of this article; 
(2)  The publication of statistics so classified as to prevent the identification of any return or report and the items thereof; 
(3)  The inspection by the legal representative of the board of the returns, reports or files relating to the claim of any dealer who shall have brought an action to review or set aside any tax imposed under this article or against whom an action or proceeding has been instituted in accordance with the provisions hereof; 
(4)  The examination of the records and files by the collector or by his duly authorized agents; or 
(5)  The furnishing, in the discretion of the collector, of any information disclosed by the records or files to any official person or body of any other state or of the United States who shall be concerned with the administration of any similar tax by that state or the United States. 
(Ord. No. 1631, §§ 7.01-7.08, 10-12-76) 
Sec. 2-4038. - Refunds; reimbursements. 
(a)  Property returned. In the event tangible personal property sold is returned to the dealer by the purchaser or consumer after the tax imposed by this article has been collected or charged to the account of the consumer or user, the dealer shall be entitled to reimbursement of the amount of tax so collected or charged by him, in the manner prescribed by the collector and in case the tax has not been remitted by the dealer to the board, the dealer may deduct the same in submitting his return. Upon receipt of a sworn statement of the dealer as to the gross amount of such refunds during the period covered by such sworn statement, which period shall not be longer than ninety (90) days, the board, through the collector, shall issue to the dealer an official credit memorandum equal to the net amount remitted by the dealer for the tax collected. Such memorandum shall be accepted by the board at full face value from the dealer to whom it is issued, in the remittance for subsequent taxes accrued under the provisions of this article. In cases where a dealer has retired from business and has filed a final return, a refund of tax may be made if it can be established to the satisfaction of the collector that the tax paid was not due. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:315. 
(b)  Claim for refund. If any dealer shall have given to the collector notice within the time provided in subsection (a), such dealer thereafter, at any time within two (2) years after the payment of any original or additional tax assessed against him, may file with the collector a claim under oath for refund, in such form as the collector may prescribe, stating the grounds thereof. However, no claim for refund shall be required or permitted to be filed with respect to a tax paid, after protest has been filed with the collector as provided in this article, or after the proceeding on appeal has been finally determined. 
(c)  Credit. If, upon examination of such claim for refund, it shall be determined by the collector that there has been an overpayment of tax, the amount of such overpayment shall be credited against any liability of any dealer under this article, and if there is no such liability, the dealer shall be entitled to a refund of the tax so overpaid. If the collector shall reject the claim for refund in whole or in part he shall make an order accordingly and serve notice upon such dealer. 
(d)  General authority for refund. Where no question of fact or law is involved, and it appears from the records of the board that any moneys have been erroneously or illegally collected from any dealer, or have been paid by any dealer under a mistake of fact or law, the collector may, at any time within two (2) years of payment, upon making a record in writing of his reasons therefor, certify that any dealer is entitled to such refund and thereupon the collector shall authorize the payment thereof from any appropriation available for such purposes. 
(e)  Return of deposit. When, to secure compliance with any of the provisions of this article, any moneys shall have been deposited with the board by any dealer, and shall have been paid over to the board and the collector shall be satisfied that such dealer has fully complied with all such provisions, the collector shall so certify and authorize repayment from any appropriations available for such purpose to such dealer of such moneys, or such part thereof as the collector shall certify has not been applied by him to the satisfaction of any indebtedness arising under this article. 
(Ord. No. 1631, §§ 10.01-10.05, 10-12-76; Ord. No. 2092, § 8, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 2-4039. - Applicability of the Uniform Local Sales Tax Code. 
    Except to the extent not expressly required by law, the provisions of the Uniform Local Sales Tax Code, as enacted by Act 73 of the 2003 Regular Session of the Louisiana Legislature, as it may be from time-to-time amended, shall supercede the provisions of sections 2-4023 to 2-4032 and sections 2-4034 to 2-4038, except that the following provisions are hereby specifically continued in effect: 
(1)  That exception adopted by the city pursuant to ordinance 3276, enacted October 31, 2002, authorized by R.S. 47:337.10F, which provides: 
Charges for the furnishing of repairs to tangible personal property shall be excluded from sales of services when the repaired property is delivered to the customer in another state either by common carrier or the repair dealer's own vehicle (or as to aircraft, by the best available means). 
(Ord. No. 3632, § 1, 12-12-06) 
Sec. 2-4040. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - NONPAYMENT OF TAX 

Sec. 2-4041. - Penalty. 
    Upon local taxes not paid and delinquent thirty (30) days after the date upon which the tax is due, there shall be an interest penalty of one and one-quarter (11/4) percent per month on the amount of the tax due, which shall be collected by the tax recipient body, together with and in the same manner as the tax. 
(Ord. No. 1955, § 1, 11-9-82) 
State Law reference- Penalty for nonpayment of tax, R.S. 33:2746. 
Sec. 2-4042. - Approval of mayor. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no credit, refund, or similar adjustment decreasing the sales tax payable by any person which is in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for a taxable year, or in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for all taxable years under review, shall be authorized without the express written approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 4091, § 1, 10-9-12) 
Secs. 2-4043-2-4060. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 1716, § 1, 2-27-79) 
Sec. 2-4062. - Acceptance of interest. 
    The board of aldermen accepts the beneficial interest of the trust on behalf of the city as co-beneficiary with the city and does hereby empower, authorize and direct the mayor to execute an acceptance on behalf of the city of the beneficial interest in the trust created by the trust indenture. 
(Ord. No. 1716, § 2, 2-27-79)

    The initial trustees of the trust and their respective terms of office shall be:

(Ord. No. 1716, § 5, 2-27-79) 
Chapter 5 - CITY COURT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Prosecutor in city court, § 404; assistance to courts by police department, § 407. 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-1008; fines recoverable by civil action, § 1-1009; demonstrations in or near certain buildings, § 11-4017; contraband in correctional facilities, § 11-4025; perjury, § 11-4026. 

Sec. 2-5001. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-5002. - Voluntary manual labor by convicted persons. 
(a)  Any person convicted in the city court and who is sentenced to a jail term therefor who voluntarily performs manual labor on public works of the city shall have an equal number of days taken off or removed from his sentence corresponding with the number of days during which he shall have performed work. The days shall be computed at the rate of eight (8) hours work per day. 
(b)  The chief of police shall keep a record of the time each prisoner performs labor on public works of the city, and the chief of police shall be charged with the duty to see that all prisoners coming within the provisions of this section receive credit for all labor performed. 
(Code 1976, § 2-5002) 
State Law reference- Labor by state correctional institution inmates, R.S. 15:832. 
Sec. 2-5003. - Pre-trial diversion program. 
(a)  The city attorney shall be authorized to establish, operate and maintain a pre-trial diversion program which shall be applicable to any and all crimes and offenses established in this Code, including, but not limited to, being authorized to establish guidelines, requirements and limitations for participation; to establish costs and fees to be imposed upon participants; to pay such costs and expenses as are necessary or desirable to the Office of the West Monroe City Judge, West Monroe City Marshal and to such other persons as may be necessary or desirable in conjunction with the program; and to take any and all such other action necessary or appropriate in order to establish, operate and maintain a pre-trial diversion program. 
(b)  The city attorney shall be authorized to establish a program whereby a schedule of administrative/amendment fees of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) may be imposed by his office (in addition to any fine or court cost imposed by the Court) in those circumstances determined appropriate by the city attorney, where a person charged with any motor vehicle violation requests the city attorney undertake an amendment of the originally charged violation. 
(Ord. No. 3050, § 1, 9-14-99; Ord. No. 4023, § 1, 9-13-11) 
Chapter 6 - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
ARTICLE A. - MUNICIPAL PLANNING COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Annexation of territory, § 1-2002 et seq.; planning and development, Part 12; flood damage prevention, Part 12, Ch. 6; planning commission review of park plans, § 12-3003. 
State Law reference- Planning commission, R.S. 33:101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-6001. - Established. 
(a)  There is hereby created the West Monroe Municipal Planning Commission under the authority granted in R.S. 33:101 et seq. 
(b)  Said commission shall also be the municipal zoning commission, as provided in R.S. 33:4726. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6001) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, R.S. 33:102. 
Sec. 2-6002. - Membership. 
(a)  The municipal planning commission shall consist of five (5) members, all to be appointed by the mayor. The mayor may remove any member of the commission, after public hearing, for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. All members of the commission shall serve without compensation and shall hold no other public office. All members of the commission shall be residents of the city. 
(b)  All members of the commission shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years, from and after the expiration of the terms of their predecessors in office. The terms of the members of the commission shall be such that the term of one member of the committee shall expire each year. 
(c)  If a vacancy occurs other than by an expiration of the term, it shall be filled by appointment of the original appointing authority for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6002; Ord. No. 2093, § 9, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 2068, 3-12-85) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2068, adopted Mar. 12, 1985, amended § 2-6002 to read as herein set out in order to conform the municipal planning commission to Charter requirements (see Char. § 44(a)). 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 33:103. 
Sec. 2-6003. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the municipal planning commission shall be as provided by law, particularly as provided by R.S. 33:101 et seq., and in accordance with the law the commission shall make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6003; Ord. No. 2093, § 10, 3-12-85) 
State Law reference- Adoption of plan, R.S. 33:108. 
Sec. 2-6004. - Appeals. 
    All final decisions of the municipal planning commission, including those relating to uses requiring approval of the municipal planning commission and special exceptions requiring approval of the municipal planning commission, may be appealed to the board by any person aggrieved by the decision, including the city. 
(Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 10-14-14) 
Secs. 2-6005-2-6010. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - CENTRAL BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT 

Sec. 2-6011. - Name. 
    There is hereby established a downtown development district for the City of West Monroe, Louisiana, to be known as the City of West Monroe Central Business Development District, hereinafter sometimes referred to as the "district". 
(Ord. No. 2797, § 1, 12-10-96) 
Sec. 2-6012. - Area. 
    The area to be encompassed by the district shall be defined as all areas contained within the areas described below, as follows: 
Census Tract Block Group(s) 54 .001 55 .001, .002, .003 56 .001  
Sec. 2-6013. - Governing authority. 
    The governing authority of the district shall be comprised of the board of aldermen of the city, who shall be voting members, and the mayor of the city, who shall be the presiding officer but who shall not vote except to resolve a tie vote by the remaining members. In the absence of the mayor, the mayor pro tem of the city shall serve as presiding officer. The terms of all members shall be contemporaneous with their terms as alderman or mayor for the city. The city clerk of the city shall serve as secretary of the district. 
(Ord. No. 2797, § 1, 12-10-96) 
Sec. 2-6014. - Rules and regulations. 
    The district shall adopt such rules and regulations and take such actions as it deems necessary or appropriate, and shall have such specific authority as is provided in R.S. 33:4625F, such authority to be exercised by the district only within the boundaries of the district. 
(Ord. No. 2797, § 1, 12-10-96) 
Sec. 2-6015. - Development plan. 
    The district shall formulate a building development plan or plans for the district and submit such plans to the mayor and board of aldermen of the city for review and approval, and shall formulate a program or programs to implement any development plans so approved, and shall implement the various plans in such a manner as to aid and encourage private development within the district and to promote and coordinate public development within the district. 
(Ord. No. 2797, § 1, 12-10-96) 
Secs. 2-6016-2-6020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - "KEEP WEST MONROE BEAUTIFUL" BOARD[9] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-6021. - "Keep America Beautiful" system. 
    The city endorses the "Keep America Beautiful" system, and supports the participation of the City of West Monroe in this system. 
(Ord. No. 3065, § 1, 11-9-99) 
Sec. 2-6022. - "Keep West Monroe Beautiful" board. 
    There is hereby established the "Keep West Monroe Beautiful" board, which shall be an official board of the city and accountable to the mayor of the city. The "Keep West Monroe Beautiful" board shall prepare and submit for approval by the mayor a set of by-laws which shall contain, among other provisions, the authority and purpose of the board, the nature and classes of its membership, its meetings and procedures, its officers and their duties, its committees and other provisions which shall assist in its coordination, promotion, support, encouragement and advancement of efforts within the community to improve the quality of life as it relates to beautification and reduction of litter. 
(Ord. No. 3065, § 1, 11-9-99) 
Chapter 7 - RESIDENTIAL ANTIDISPLACEMENT AND RELOCATION ASSISTANCE PLAN[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2303, adopted June 13, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, its inclusion as Ch. 7 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Part 12. 

Sec. 2-7001. - Background. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of recent federal law, the city has adopted this formal antidisplacement and relocation assistance (ARA) plan for all of its activities involving the use of federal funds. The city's adopted plan complies with all requirements of 49 CFR 24, 24 CFR 570, and 24 CFR 511. This plan takes affect on April 2, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 2303, 6-13-89) 
Sec. 2-7002. - General goals. 
    The law requires the city's ARA plan to accomplish three (3) general goals: 
(1)  To provide reasonable moving expenses to those who would be forced to move permanently as a result of federally assisted activity; 
(2)  To provide adequate advisory services to them including information on their rights under law; and 
(3)  To offer assistance to those lower income tenants forced to occupy rental units that have significantly higher rental charges as a result of the federally funded activities. 
(Ord. No. 2303, 6-13-89) 
Sec. 2-7003. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Affordable rent is a monthly rental rate, including utility allowances, which does not exceed: 
(1)  The greater of the rent plus utility allowance the tenant paid prior to initiations of the federally assisted project, or 
(2)  Thirty (30) percent of the tenant's monthly income adjusted for family size (24 CFR 511.10(h)(1)(ii)(A)). 
    Displacement occurs when a tenant is required to move permanently and involuntarily as a direct result of the federally assisted project to another dwelling unit: 
(1)  In the same complex where the rent is not "affordable," or 
(2)  To a replacement unit beyond the complex regardless of affordability (24 CFR 570.606(g)). 
    Replacement dwelling means a unit selected by a displaced tenant that is: 
(1)  Adequate according to 24 CFR 882.109; 
(2)  Functionally equivalent according to 49 CFR 24.2(d)(2); 
(3)  In a location not less desirable than the unit displaced from; and 
(4)  Leasable at an affordable rent (49 CFR 24.2(d)). 
    Tenant means any family or person residing in a dwelling unit owned by another. 
    Utility allowance is the amount calculated as reasonable monthly utility expenses for tenant families according to 24 CFR 882.116. 
(Ord. No. 2303, 6-13-89) 
Sec. 2-7004. - Displacement protection. 
    Under federal law, all tenants occupying rented dwellings about to be rehabilitated using federal funds shall be protected from involuntary displacement. If no suitable replacement dwelling can be found (as defined above) the tenant cannot be displaced. Further, all tenants must be given information on their rights under law (24 CFR 570.606(c)(2)). Tenants will not qualify for protection or assistance under the ARA plan if they: 
(1)  Are evicted by the owner for cause; 
(2)  Voluntarily leave prior to initiation of the project; 
(3)  Move into the project after initiation and were informed of the planned project; 
(4)  Have a legal interest in the property; or 
(5)  Voluntarily choose to leave the project after being fully informed of their rights and benefits under the ARA plan (49 CFR 24.2(g)(2)). 
    Under the city's ARA plan, all tenants residing in proposed rehabilitation projects will be given the informative material entitled "To Move or Not To Move: Your Rights as a Tenant." Basically, this brochure explains this ARA plan in easy-to-read form. 
(Ord. No. 2303, 6-13-89) 
Sec. 2-7005. - Relocation assistance. 
    A tenant who is "displaced" is eligible for relocation assistance, if applied for on RRP form 17, which includes moving expenses, advisory services, and expenses for temporary relocation as appropriate. 
(1)  Moving expenses: Displaced tenants are entitled to recover the actual costs of their physical relocation including the costs for: 
a.  Transporting furniture and possessions (fifty (50) miles maximum). 
b.  Packing and unpacking. 
c.  Disconnecting and reconnecting, disassembly and reassembly of appliances, etc. 
d.  Storage related to the move. 
e.  Insurance up to the value of possessions moved. 
f.  Replacement of property lost or stolen during the move. 
g.  Other justifiable and reasonable expenses (49 CFR 24.301). 
These costs must be documented. Alternatively, a displaced tenant may choose to receive a fixed payment according to the most recent approved schedule, minimum fifty dollars ($50.00) (49 CFR 24.302). The most recent schedule, approved by the department of transportation, federal highway administration, was published on March 2, 1989, (FR 54:40, p. 8951) specifying the following rates for the state: 
_____ 
Occupant owns furniture Occupant does not own furniture Number of rooms of furniture ea. add. 
  1st each 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 room room addn'l room 250 350 450 550 625 700 775 850 75 200 25  
_____ 
(2)  Other relocation provisions: The city may approved advance payment to reduce or avoid hardship (49 CFR 24.207(c)). Multiple occupants who choose separate replacement dwellings are entitled to reasonable prorated shares of relocation payments (49 CFR 24.207(e)). All claims for relocation payments must be submitted within eighteen (18) months of the displacement (49 CFR 24.207(d)). Relocation payments are not considered as income when filing income tax returns (49 CFR 24.208) or when calculating income for housing assistance levels (24 CFR 813.106(c)(8)(iii)). 
(3)  Advisory services: Displaced families are entitled to advice (24 CFR 570.606(c)) and (24 CFR 511.10(h)) which, at a minimum, informs them of: 
a.  Their fair housing rights under federal law; 
b.  All known rental opportunities in the area where a suitable replacement dwelling may be found; 
c.  Assurance that they will not be forced to relocate if no replacement dwelling can be obtained (49 CFR 24.204(a)). 
Advisory services will include a personal interview (49 CFR 24.205(c)(2)(i)). 
(4)  Temporary relocation: A tenant is not considered displaced if only required to relocate temporarily during the projects construction phase; however, all such tenants must be: 
a.  Provided with decent, safe, and sanitary temporary accommodations; 
b.  Compensated for moving expenses (as in part (1) above); and 
c.  Compensated for any increased housing costs during the temporary relocation (49 CFR 24.2(g)(2)(iv), Appendix A and 24 CFR 570.606(g)(3)). 
(5)  Source of relocations assistance funds: Permanent or temporary relocation assistance will be included as part of the overall RRP project costs; therefore, in most cases costs will be shared equally by the city's rental rehabilitation program and by the private investor or in larger measure by the investor (24 CFR 511.10(g)(2)(iv)). 
(Ord. No. 2303, 6-13-89) 
Sec. 2-7006. - Appeals. 
    Decisions will be rendered in writing to all claimants along with notice of their right to appeal. Claimants may appeal the city's decisions concerning displacement or relocation compensation in writing within ninety (90) days of the decision. The planning director will designate a hearing officer not involved in the decision appealed from. The claimant will be informed of his or her: 
(1)  Right to legal counsel; 
(2)  Right to inspect pertinent file contents; and 
(3)  Right to judicial review (49 CFR 24.10). 
    Further, lower income tenants (i.e., tenants with incomes below one hundred twenty (120) percent of the area median) will be informed of their right to appeal directly to the New Orleans Area Office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) any decision concerning displacement or relocation assistance made by the city (24 CFR 570.606(e)). The hearing officer will inform the claimant of the decision and the reasons for that decision in writing to the claimant within thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 2303, 6-13-89) 
Chapter 8 - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 2-8001. - Smoking prohibition. 
(a)  The following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
(1)  Municipal buildings and facilities means and includes all buildings and facilities owned, leased, or otherwise occupied by the municipality. 
(2)  Smoke or smoking means and includes the carrying of a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or any other form of tobacco or the inhaling of and exhaling of smoke by a person from any form of lighted tobacco. 
(b)  Smoking is prohibited in all municipal buildings and facilities. No-smoking signs shall be conspicuously posted in all municipal buildings and facilities by the department head or other person having control of such buildings and facilities. 
(c)  Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 2530, § 1, 8-10-93)
