Trespassing-R.S. 14:63-Sec. 11-3004 
Underaged Driving under the Influence-R.S. 14:98.1, Sec. 11-4027.1 
Underaged Purchase or Public Possession of an Alcoholic Beverage-R.S. 11-5009.2; 14:93.12 
Unnecessary Noise-Sec. 11-5020; R.S. 14:103.1; 14:103.2 
Unauthorized Use of a Moveable-R.S. 14:68, Sec. 11-3010 
Vandalism-R.S. 14:59-Sec. 11-4009 
** The descriptions of offenses above are for simplicity of understanding only, and the citations to the Code of Ordinances, City of West Monroe, the Louisiana Code of Criminal Procedure, and the Revised Statutes of the State of Louisiana shall define the actual offenses which are the subject of this provision. 
(5)  Nuisance residence means: The residence (including a multi-family dwelling, as defined below) of a violator, or the residence at which an invitee/permittee violator (as defined by section 4-1020(2)b.) commits a Class A violation or Class B violation. 
Nonprofit residential treatment programs, nursing homes, group homes for specialized rehabilitation programs, schools, any hotel or motel which is not defined below as a multifamily dwelling, and retail businesses shall not be considered as a residence for purposes of this article, and shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
The term "nuisance residence" shall encompass the full extent of the lot or lots or other parcel or tract of immovable property upon which a "nuisance residence" is located. 
(6)  Multifamily Dwelling means: A multifamily dwelling shall include boardinghouses, duplex apartments, single residences divided into multiple apartments, apartment complexes and all other dwellings which house more than one family. For the purpose of this article, each apartment in any multi-family dwelling shall be considered as a separate residence. 
Any hotel or motel which routinely rents to the same tenant(s) for fourteen (14) consecutive days or more will be considered for the purposes of this article to be a multifamily dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 3181, § 1, 7-10-00; Ord. No. 3241, § 1, 5-14-02; Ord. No. 3770, §§ 1-3, 9-9-08; Ord. No. 3828, § 1, 6-9-09) 
Sec. 4-1021. - Pre-imposition notice of violations to owner. 
(a)  A service charge, in the amount provided by section 4-1022, will be imposed upon an owner for excessive calls for police service, measured by the occurrence of Class A violations and Class B violations by a violator. 
(b)  Upon the occurrence of one class a violation or two (2) Class B violations, whichever shall first occur, an owner shall be given notice of the occurrence(s) of the offenses at the address of the owner then reflected on the tax rolls of the City of West Monroe. The mailing of notice by U.S. mail to that address shall be deemed sufficient notice for all purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3181, § 1, 7-10-00) 
Sec. 4-1022. - Imposition of service charge; opportunity for pre-imposition hearing; amount of service charge. 
(a)  A service charge shall be preliminarily imposed upon an owner upon the occurrence of the first of the following events: 
(1)  Two (2) Class A violations occurring within a six-month period of time by one or more violators; or 
(2)  Three (3) Class B violations occurring within a six-month period of time by one or more violators; or 
(3)  One Class A violation and one Class B violations occurring within a six-month period of time, by one or more violators, regardless of the order of the violations; 
(4)  For purposes of (1)-(3) above, a six-month period of time shall be any period of six (6) months beginning with the occurrence of a Class A violation or a Class B violation, and is referred to as the "time period". 
(b)  Upon the occurrence of an event giving rise to the preliminary imposition of a service charge, as set forth in subsection (a) above, the owner shall be given notice of the preliminary imposition of the service charge in the same manner set forth in section 4-1021(b). The owner shall be given notice of the right to request a pre-imposition hearing by completing a standard pre-imposition hearing form which will be readily available at the West Monroe Police Department, or the West Monroe City Hall. If no pre-imposition hearing is requested within thirty (30) days of the mailing of the notice, or if, after a pre-imposition hearing is held, the service charge is deemed valid, the service charge shall be imposed as set forth below. 
(1)  Following the occurrence of any one of the events described in (a)(1) to (a)(3), the next Class A violation which occurs during the time period shall incur a two hundred dollar ($200.00) service charge, and all subsequent Class A violations during the time period shall incur a three hundred dollar ($300.00) service charge. 
(2)  Following the occurrence of any one of the events described in (a)(1) to (a)(3), all subsequent Class B violations occurring during the time period shall each incur a one hundred dollar ($100.00) service charge, except that any Class B violations occurring after a Class A violation has occurred during the time period, shall be charged at the service charge rates of a Class A violation. 
(d)  A service charge is calculated based upon the occurrences of Class A violations and Class B violations at a particular "nuisance residence", regardless of any change or variance in the identity or number of the occupants of the "nuisance residence", or the identity of the violator. 
(e)  Service charges imposed by this article shall be paid within thirty (30) days of mailing of an invoice itemizing the charges owed. Service charges which are not paid within thirty (30) days of the mailing of the invoice shall additionally incur an administrative cost of collection of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) plus any costs incurred, and shall be recoverable from the owner. Service charges remaining unpaid forty-five (45) days from the mailing of the invoice may, together with the administrative costs, will be added to the water/sewage bill of the nuisance property, at the option of the city, or the city may institute civil collection proceedings as provided by law. The time delays provided above shall be interrupted during the pendency of any appeal pursuant to the provisions of section 4-1023. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this article, should a single incident give rise to more than one violation, only one of the violations shall be used for the purposes of section 4-1021 to 4-1022. If a single incident gives rise to both Class A violations and Class B violations, the Class A violation shall be utilized for the purpose of this article. Any other selection of the applicable violation to be used shall be made in a manner which is most likely to cause imposition of a service charge. 
(g)  There shall be no service charge (or any previously assessed service charge shall be abated) in the event the occupant has been evicted within thirty (30) days after mailing of notice of the service charges, or the owner has initiated eviction proceedings within thirty (30) days after mailing of their notice of the service charge, and those proceedings are promptly and aggressively pursued through to completion; 
(h)  There shall be no service charge (or any previously assessed service charge shall be abated) in the event the owner shows the violator had not been arrested for any offense listed as an offense constituting a Class A violation or a Class B violation within three (3) years prior to the current Class A violation or Class B violation committed by the violator after his or her occupancy of the nuisance premises. 
(Ord. No. 3181, § 1, 7-10-00) 
Sec. 4-1023. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Appeals. 
(1)  An owner who has received notice of service charges owed to the city under this article has the right to appeal the imposition of the service charges based on the grounds that an error has been made in the calculations of violations attributable to a nuisance residence. 
(2)  An owner may also appeal the imposition of service charges based upon the following grounds: 
a.  The occupant incurring the violation has been evicted from the nuisance residence within thirty (30) days after mailing of a notice of service charges, or an eviction proceeding has been initiated within thirty (30) days after mailing of a notice of service charges, and that proceeding is promptly and aggressively pursued through to completion; 
b.  An initial violation, and all subsequent violations within thirty (30) days thereafter, should not be included in the computation because the violator had not been arrested for any offense listed as an offense constituting a Class A violation or a Class B violation within three (3) years prior to occupancy of the nuisance premises by the violator. 
(3)  Any appeal shall be filed in writing, on a form to be readily available, within thirty (30) days of mailing of notice of the imposition of service charges, stating with particularity the grounds for appeal or objection. 
(4)  All appeals or objections will be filed with the office of the Chief of Police of the City of West Monroe. 
(5)  If, after review by the chief of police, the owner wishes further review, owner shall be entitled to a further appeal to an administrative panel composed of a representative from the police department (which may, but need not be, the chief of police), a representative from the Office of the City Attorney, and a representative selected by the mayor (which may, but need not be, the mayor). A request for such further appeal shall be filed in writing, on a form to be readily available, within fifteen (15) days of mailing of notice of the review decision by the chief of police, again stating with particularity the grounds for appeal or objection. 
(b)  Refunds. An owner may file for a refund of service charges, on a form to be readily available, within sixty (60) days after a Class A violation or a Class B violation has been dismissed, prescribed, or resulted in a verdict of not guilty, requesting that service charges paid by or imposed upon the owner be recalculated without consideration of those Class A violations or Class B violations. 
(c)  Measurements of distance. All distances referred to in this article shall be calculated in a straight line from the nearest point of the property line of the nuisance property to the point of the occurrence of an offense. Any reasonable method of computation of distance shall be allowable, but the distance computed by the G.I.S. system of the city shall be presumed to reflect the correct distance. 
(Ord. No. 3181, § 1, 7-10-00) 
ARTICLE D. - INMATE RESPONSIBILITY 

Sec. 4-1030. - Food and clothing provisions for prisoners; payment of incarceration expenses; payment of medical expenses; restitution for damaged property. 
(a)  (1)  The city shall establish a program to obtain reimbursement from an inmate for certain expenses incurred by reason of the inmate's incarceration in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(2)  The city shall collect reimbursement for the costs of room and board from any inmate incarcerated in the city corrections facility, provided such reimbursement is approved by the judge who sentenced the inmate and provided the amount of such reimbursement is a uniform and reasonable amount and not in excess of the amounts of reasonable reimbursement established by the department of public safety and corrections. 
(b)  (1)  The city shall obtain reimbursement from an inmate for his medical and dental expenses. In addition, the city shall require that copayments be made by inmates upon receiving medical or dental treatment. 
(2)  The amount of reimbursement to the city shall be the actual costs, or any portion thereof, of the medical or dental expenses incurred. 
(3)  a.  The city shall establish written rules for the collection of such expenses from the inmate, including freezing assets in his drawing account and prohibiting withdrawals therefrom until the expenses are paid. The drawing account may be frozen regardless of the source of the assets contained therein. Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, the city shall promulgate rules and regulations regarding reimbursement by the inmate for medical expenses incurred by the city for the inmate's treatment, including a requirement that the inmate file a claim with his private medical or health care insurer or any public medical assistance program, under which he is covered and from which the inmate may make a claim for payment or reimbursement of the cost of any such medical treatment. This subsection shall not prohibit the withdrawal of funds for the purpose of payments under the Crime Victims Reparations Act, court costs as authorized by law, and other withdrawals specifically authorized by the chief of police, or his designee, in that order. 
b.  In addition, the city shall establish written rules requiring that copayments be made by inmates upon receiving medical or dental treatment, which may include a sliding scale based on the inmates' ability to pay. These written rules shall include but not be limited to guidelines for payments for inmate visits to doctors, hospitals, psychiatrists, and dentists, and for receipt of prescription or nonprescription drugs. The procedures for collection of copayments shall follow the procedures for collection of other expenses as established above. 
(4)  Any inmate who is transferred to another facility or discharged shall remain liable for any reimbursement authorized under this section. 
(5)  For purposes of this subsection "inmate" means any prisoner confined to the West Monroe Correctional Center, to the extent not otherwise limited by law. 
(c)  (1)  The city shall obtain restitution from any inmate who damages or destroys property while in custody. 
(2)  The amount of restitution shall be the actual costs or any portion thereof of repairing or replacing the property. 
(3)  Until such costs are recovered by the city, the assets in an inmate's drawing account shall be frozen, and withdrawals therefrom shall be prohibited until the expenses are paid, regardless of the source of the assets contained therein. This subsection shall not prohibit the withdrawal of funds for the purpose of payments under the Crime Victims Reparations Act, court costs as authorized by law, other payments required by the sentencing judge, and other withdrawals specifically authorized by the chief of police or his designee, in that order. 
(4)  Any offender who is transferred to another facility or discharged shall remain liable for the restitution authorized under this section. 
(5)  The assets of an inmate's drawing account shall not be reduced below five dollars ($5.00). 
(Ord. No. 3393, § 1, 4-13-04) 
Chapter 2 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Fire department, §§ 403, 406. 
Cross reference- Trash fires, § 11-4006; obstruction of firemen, § 11-4007; obstruction of fire prevention, § 11-4008; fireworks, § 11-4022. 
State Law reference- Fire department, R.S. 33:1961 et seq.; fire prevention or protection, R.S. 40:1491 et seq.; firefighters' retirement system, R.S. 33:2151 et seq.; civil service, R.S. 33:2471 et seq. 

ARTICLE A. - FIRE DEPARTMENT GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-2001. - Officers generally. 
    The fire department shall consist of a fire chief and other officers as the chief and the board may deem necessary for the effective operation of the department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1011) 
Sec. 4-2002. - Chief-Appointment, qualifications, grounds for removal. 
    The fire chief shall be appointed as provided in section 406 of the city charter for an indefinite period of time, and his tenure of office shall depend upon his good conduct and efficiency. The chief shall be technically qualified by training and experience and shall have command ability and shall be able to hold respect and confidence. He shall be removed only for just cause and after a public hearing before the board. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2002) 
Sec. 4-2003. - Same-Accountable to board. 
    The fire chief shall be held accountable to the board and shall make written and verbal reports thereto as the board may require. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2003) 
Sec. 4-2004. - Officers and employees appointed by chief; authority of chief. 
    The fire chief shall appoint the officers and employees of the fire department pursuant to the provisions of the civil service laws of the State of Louisiana. These officers and employees shall be accountable only to the chief, and shall be subject to discipline and/or terminated from employment by him in accordance with law. In pursuance of the obligations and responsibilities of the fire chief, the fire chief shall have all authority granted to the "appointing authority" to initiate inquiries and investigations of the actions of the officers and employees of the fire department, and to impose any and all discipline up to and including termination, and shall be authorized to act as and in the name of the appointing authority as to these matters." 
(Code 1976, §§ 4-2003, 4-2004; Ord. No. 4518, § 1, 4-10-18) 
Sec. 4-2005. - Duties of chief. 
    The duties of the fire chief shall be as follows: 
(1)  The chief shall formulate a set of rules and regulations to govern the fire department and shall be responsible to the board for the personnel, morale and general efficiency of the department. 
(2)  The chief shall determine the number and kind of companies of which the department is to be composed and shall determine the response of these companies to alarms. 
(3)  The chief shall at least once a month conduct: 
a.  Suitable drills or instruction in the operation and handling of equipment, first aid and rescue work and salvage; and 
b.  A study of buildings in the city, fire prevention, water supplies, and all other matters generally considered essential to good firemanship and safety of life and property from fire. 
(4)  The chief is hereby required to assist the proper authorities in suppressing the crime of arson by investigating or causing to be investigated the cause, origin, and circumstances of all fires. 
(5)  The chief is hereby empowered to enter any and all buildings and premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of making inspections and to serve written notice upon the owner or occupant to abate, within a specified time, any and all fire hazards that may be found. 
(6)  Any person so served with a notice to abate any fire hazard or hazards, shall comply therewith and promptly notify the chief. 
(7)  The chief shall see that complete records are kept of all fires, inspections, apparatus and minor equipment, personnel and other information about the work of the department. 
(8)  The chief shall report monthly to the mayor the condition of the apparatus and equipment; the number of fires during the month, their location, cause, date, and loss occasioned thereby; the number and purpose of all other runs made; and the number of members responding to each fire or other run, and any changes in membership. 
(9)  The chief shall make a complete annual report to the board within one month after the close of the fiscal year, the report to include the information specified in paragraph (7) together with comparative data for previous years and recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2005) 
Sec. 4-2006. - Members. 
    The membership of the fire department shall consist of the persons as may be appointed by the chief and shall be able-bodied citizens who have telephones. Determination of whether candidates for appointment are able-bodied shall be made by the chief after a medical and physical examination has been made in a manner prescribed by the chief and approved by the board. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2006; Ord. No. 2093, § 12, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 3702, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 4-2007. - Equipment; recommendations for purchase; housing. 
(a)  The department shall be equipped with apparatus and other equipment as may be required to maintain its efficiency and properly protect life and property from fire. 
(b)  Recommendations of apparatus and equipment needed shall be made by the chief, and after approval by the board shall be purchased in a manner as may be designated by the board. 
(c)  All equipment of the department shall be safely and conveniently housed in places as may be designated by the board. These places shall be heated during the winter season. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2007) 
Sec. 4-2008. - Alarm facilities. 
    Suitable arrangement or equipment shall be provided for citizens to turn in a fire alarm, and for notifying all members of the fire department so that they may promptly respond. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2008) 
Cross reference- Space on poles and underground conduits of telephone company to be available cost-free for fire alarm signaling system, § 3-4003. 
Sec. 4-2009. - Use of apparatus for private purposes; obstruction of hydrants. 
(a)  No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purpose, nor shall any person willfully or without proper authority take away or conceal any article used in any way by the fire department. 
(b)  No person shall in any way obstruct from either clear view or use any fire hydrant or cistern. No person shall locate, cause to be located nor allow any hindrance or obstruction to clear view or to use to be located within ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant or cistern. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2009; Ord. No. 3476, § 1, 6-14-05) 
Sec. 4-2010. - Visitors accompanied by member of department. 
    No person shall enter any place where fire apparatus is housed or handle any apparatus or equipment belonging to the fire department unless accompanied by, or having the special permission of, an officer or authorized member of the department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2010) 
Sec. 4-2011. - Agreements with nearby communities. 
    The fire chief, with the consent and approval of the board, may enter into agreements or contracts with nearby incorporated communities or governing bodies of other organizations to provide the members of other communities or organizations with fire protection or to establish a mutual aid system. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2011) 
Sec. 4-2012. - Calls outside city. 
    No fire apparatus shall be hired out or removed from the city, except in response to a call for aid at a fire in a neighboring community, without the consent of the mayor. The officer in charge of the fire department shall have power to assign equipment for response to calls for outside aid in accordance with section 4-2011, but in other cases only when the absence of the equipment will not jeopardize the protection in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2012) 
Sec. 4-2013. - Personnel. 
(a)  Each member of the fire department shall be issued a badge designating his rank. 
(b)  Each member of the department driving a car shall be issued a suitable insignia to be attached to the car. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2013) 
Sec. 4-2014. - Motor vehicle restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall drive any vehicle over fire hose except upon specific orders from the chief or other officer in charge where the hose is used. 
(b)  All motor equipment and all personal cars of department members shall have right-of-way over all other traffic when responding to an alarm. 
(c)  No person shall park any vehicle or otherwise cause any obstruction to be placed within twenty (20) feet of the entrance to any fire station or other place where fire apparatus is stored, or within ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant or cistern. 
(d)  No unauthorized person with any vehicle shall follow within six hundred (600) feet of any apparatus belonging to the department, nor park any vehicle within three hundred (300) feet of a fire. 
(e)  No person or persons shall approach in any vehicle, within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the scene of a fire that is being combatted by the fire department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2014; Ord. No. 2093, § 11, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 4-2015. - Fire lanes; establishment, maintenance of and penalties. 
(a)  There shall be no parking, standing, stopping or placing of any cars, trucks, trailers, apparatus, vehicles, portable buildings, or any other items deemed as an obstruction by the fire prevention bureau of the fire department of the City of West Monroe ("fire prevention bureau") within fifty (50) feet of any exit, entrance, or fire department connections serving any shopping centers, malls, bowling alleys, theaters, hospitals, institutions, or any other area as deemed necessary by the fire prevention bureau for the protection of life and property from fire or explosions (all such structures, locations or areas being referred to in the aggregate as "facilities"). Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, any car, truck or other vehicle in which the vehicle operator remains and is capable of immediately, and without any delay of any type or nature, removing such car, truck or other vehicle from the designated fire lane, shall not be in violation of this section. 
(b)  Fire lanes shall be designated by the fire prevention bureau and there shall be no parking, standing, stopping or placing of any cars, trucks, trailers, apparatus, vehicles, portable buildings or any other items deemed as an obstruction by the fire prevention bureau within these designated fire lanes. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the owners, of the operators, and of the occupants (but only as to the property occupied and the immediate adjoining areas) of facilities subject to this section to pay for and to have erected signs indicating all areas designated as fire lanes by the fire prevention bureau. 
(1)  Fire lane signing on private property shall contain the following wording: "No Parking - Fire Lane - Tow Away Zone." Said signs shall be a minimum of 12 × 18 inches in size, white background with red lettering and border. Symbol signs may be used in lieu of the above legend if approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau. Signs legend if approved by the fire prevention bureau. Signs shall be located a minimum of fifty (50) feet apart and a maximum of one hundred (100) feet apart with signs facing in both directions, or outward only, (if wall mounted), and shall be pole mounted (or wall mounted, if desired, if within fifteen (15) feet of the fire lane), clearly visible to any potential violator, and the bottom of the signage shall be no less than five (5) feet nor more than seven (7) feet from the top of the curbing or sidewalk. Signs indicating the amount of the fines provided in this section may be required to be placed by the fire prevention bureau if considered necessary in order to deter repeated violations. 
(2)  Fire lane signs on public streets or alleys shall be in accordance and compliance with the current Louisiana Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of the owners, operators and occupants of facilities subject to this section to paint lines, outlining the area designated by the fire prevention bureau as fire lanes on private property. The painting of these lines shall be red in color and the width of the stripes shall be four (4) inches wide, and the total length shall be that designated as a fire lane by the fire prevention bureau. Painted lines shall be located five (5) feet from the curb or edge of the pavement. Curb painting may be allowed in place of painted lines if approved by the fire prevention bureau. 
(e)  For a period of five (5) years from adopting this section, all existing fire lanes previously designated and approved by the fire prevention bureau prior to the adoption of this section will remain unchanged until the building is renovated, remodeled or the next occupancy permit is issued. Following such five (5) year period, this section will apply to all applicable facilities. 
(f)  Any owner, operator or occupant of a facility who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days or both. Each day's violation of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(g)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner, operator and occupant of a facility to see that the fire lane striping of the areas designated are maintained according to fire prevention bureau requirements for visibility and that signs are replaced when necessary. 
(h)  Any cars, trucks, trailers, vehicles or portable buildings found parked, standing or placed in a designated fire lane, shall be towed away and impounded by any police officer, fire inspector or authorized representative. The owner of the offending car, truck, trailer, vehicle or portable building shall be responsible for all costs of impounding and storing of the car, truck, trailer, vehicle or portable building. Upon the payment of such costs, the owner shall be entitled to have said property released. 
(i)  In any prosecution charging a violation of this section, proof that the vehicle described in the violation ticket was parked, standing, or placed in violation of this section together with proof that the defendant named in the violation ticket was at the time of such parking, standing or placement, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was, in fact the person who parked, stood or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, the alleged violation occurred. 
(j)  Owners, operators and occupants of the property on which fire lanes are located are hereby charged with the responsibility of notifying the state fire marshal, the fire prevention bureau, or local law enforcement officials of the existence of any vehicles parked in those fire lanes; and in the event that they are unable to contact the state fire marshal, the fire prevention bureau or local law officials, the owner, operator and occupant are hereby charged with the responsibility of and are hereby authorized to remove any vehicle parked in those fire lanes by any means necessary and to assess the cost of same against the owner of said vehicle by storing said vehicle and refusing to release said vehicle until all costs incident to the removal and storage of said vehicle have been paid by the owner. 
(k)  The provisions of this section are supplemental and in addition to all other provisions of this Code, including those regulating fire lanes; the parking, standing or stopping of vehicles, the interference with a fireman or fire prevention, or defining or establishing any other crime or offense. 
(Ord. No. 2590, § 1, 6-14-94) 
Sec. 4-2016. - Enforcement. 
(a)  All regularly appointed members of the fire department are hereby given the necessary special police powers for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(b)  It is hereby made the special duty of the chief of police and/or other peace officers who may be on duty and available for fire duty to respond to all fire alarms and assist the fire department in the protection of life and property, in regulating traffic, maintaining order and in enforcing observance of all sections of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2016) 
Cross reference- Police protection, § 4-1001 et seq. 
Sec. 4-2017. - Local arson investigators. 
    The fire chief shall be authorized to issue a commission to any local arson investigator which allows that local arson investigator to carry and use firearms and to arrest individuals suspected of violating the crimes enumerated in R.S. 40:1563.1; however, the issuance of the commission, the powers granted by those commissions and the use of firearms by the person to whom commissions are issued shall be subject to the following: 
(a)  The local arson investigator shall be certified by the council on Peace Officer Standards and Training (P.O.S.T.) and be qualified by the P.O.S.T. Council, or both; and 
(b)  Possession of a P.O.S.T. certification or P.O.S.T. qualification, or both, by a local arson investigator shall not grant to that arson investigator any authority other than the authority granted by a commission issued pursuant to R.S. 40:1563.1D; and 
(c)  The authority granted by a commission which is issued under these provisions shall be limited to the powers, functions, duties and responsibilities which are set forth for local arson investigators in R.S. 40:1563.1. A commission which is issued pursuant to this section, and under the provisions of R.S. 40:1563.1D shall not grant any authority other than the powers, functions, duties and responsibilities which are set forth for local arson investigators in R.S. 40:1563.1; and 
(d)  The authority to carry and use firearms which is granted by the issuance of any such commission issued pursuant to this section is limited to the power to carry weapons while acting in a course and scope of duties as a local arson investigator. 
(Ord. No. 3778, § 1, 11-11-08) 
Secs. 4-2018-4-2020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Adoption of codes by reference, R.S. 33:1368 et seq. 

Sec. 4-2021. - Adoption of fire prevention code. 
    There is hereby adopted for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the fire prevention code recommended by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc., as from time to time amended, and being the most recent version or edition from time to time thereby promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc., except that to the extent the provisions of section 4-2015 shall differ, the provisions of section 4-2015 shall prevail; and except that to the extent the provisions of section 4-2021.1 shall differ, the provisions of section 4-2021.1 shall prevail; and except such portions as are deleted, modified or amended by section 4-2027 of this article. The provisions of this fire prevention code shall be controlling within the city limits. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2021; Ord. No. 3088, § 1, 3-14-00; Ord. No. 3477, § 1, 6-14-05; Ord. No. 4483, § 1, 9-12-17) 
Sec. 4-2021.1. - Automatic fire sprinklers, standpipes, and fire department connections. 
(a)  Installation of automatic fire sprinklers, standpipe systems, and fire department connections (FDC) shall be in accordance with NFPA standards. 
(b)  The fire department connection (FDC) servicing any life safety system shall consist of two (2) two and one-half (2.5) inch connections using NH standard thread (NFPA 1963), and shall be located within one hundred (100) feet of a fire hydrant which is connected to an approved water supply. The fire prevention bureau shall have authority to approve a modification of these requirements where appropriate. 
(c)  Life safety systems required to have an audible water flow alarm shall also be required to install a visual warning device in proximity to the FDC. This requirement shall be applicable to life safety systems installed after the adoption of this section, and to existing life safety systems which are modified after the adoption of this section. 
(d)  All hotel/motel and apartments that are required to have an automatic sprinkler system shall have all void/attic spaces protected by, at a minimum, a NFPA 13R approved automatic sprinkler system. This requirement shall be applicable to all hotel/motel and apartments on which construction is initiated after the adoption of this section, and to existing hotel/motels and apartments required to have an automatic sprinkler system which are modified after the adoption of this section. The fire prevention bureau shall have authority to approve a modification of these requirements where appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 4483, § 2, 9-12-17) 
Sec. 4-2022. - Establishment and duties of bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention, in the fire department, which is hereby established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the fire chief. 
(b)  The chief in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed by the mayor on the basis of examination to determine his qualifications. 
(c)  The fire chief may detail members of the fire department as inspectors as necessary. He shall recommend to the mayor the employment of technical inspectors who, when the authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department. 
(d)  A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made annually and transmitted to the mayor; it shall contain all proceedings under this article with such statistics as the fire chief may wish to include therein; the fire chief shall also recommend any amendments to the fire prevention code which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2022; Ord. No. 3088, § 1, 3-14-00) 
Sec. 4-2023. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article the following terms, words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except when the context clearly indicates a different meaning.] 
(a)  Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the City of West Monroe, Louisiana. 
(b)  Wherever the term "corporation counsel" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the attorney for the city. 
(c)  Wherever the term "authority having jurisdiction" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the fire prevention bureau of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2023; Ord. No. 3088, § 1, 3-14-00) 
Charter reference- Legal department, §§ 403, 404. 
Sec. 4-2024. - Storage of explosives and blasting agents. 
    The limits referred to in Chapter 38 of the fire prevention code, in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established as the boundaries of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2024; Ord. No. 3088, § 1, 3-14-00) 
Sec. 4-2025. - Storage of flammable liquids in outside above-ground tanks. 
(a)  The limits referred to in Chapter 28 of the fire prevention code, in which storage of flammable liquids in outside above-ground tanks is prohibited, are established as the boundaries of the city. 
(b)  The limits referred to in Chapter 28 of the fire prevention code in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited, are hereby established as the boundaries of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2025; Ord. No. 3088, § 1, 3-14-00) 
Sec. 4-2026. - Bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases. 
    The limits referred to in Chapter 30 of the fire prevention code, in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are hereby established as the boundaries of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2026; Ord. No. 3088, § 1, 3-14-00) 
Sec. 4-2027. - Modifications. 
    The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention thereon shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2027) 
Sec. 4-2028. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief to the board within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2028) 
Sec. 4-2029. - New materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
    The mayor, the fire chief and the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the fire prevention code. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall post the list in a conspicuous place in his office and shall distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2029) 
Sec. 4-2030. - Enforcement; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall violate any of the provisions of the fire prevention code adopted in this article, nor fail to comply with all applicable provisions of that fire prevention code, nor shall any person violate or fail to timely comply with any order issued by the bureau of fire prevention thereunder. No person shall construct any structure differing in any manner from the detailed statement of specifications and plans submitted and approved by the office of the fire marshal of the State of Louisiana (if such approval was required), nor differing in any manner from any certificate or permit issued either under the provisions of the fire prevention code or by some other department or agency in reliance on any approval of the fire prevention bureau. The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not excuse that or any other violation, or thereafter allow any violation to continue. All persons shall be required to correct or remedy each violation promptly following notification of the violation by the fire prevention bureau. When not otherwise specified, each fifteen (15) days during which a violation is thereafter maintained shall constitute a separate offense as to each violation. 
(b)  Should a violation be determined by the bureau of fire prevention to have the potential to comprise a significant risk of harm to person or property, the fire prevention bureau shall have the right to require the structure to be immediately vacated, to require all natural gas and electrical service to the structure be immediately halted, and to require the structures remain vacated by all persons until those violations have been corrected, except for those persons as the fire prevention bureau shall allow entry in order to undertake any and all necessary actions to eliminate the violation(s). 
(c)  The failure of the owner of the structure and of any person utilizing the structure as a tenant or other occupant to have fully and properly corrected any violation within the deadline provided in the second notice of the violation shall result in the following costs to the responsible person: 
i.  Fifty dollar ($50.00) fee, for the fire prevention bureau then providing the owner and any occupant with an updated written notification and listing of all remaining violation(s); and 
ii.  One hundred dollar ($100.00) fee, for each subsequent re-inspection and written notification, until all violations are corrected. No more than one re-inspection shall occur each fifteen (15) days. 
    The determination of the responsible person, whether the owner or tenant or other occupant, shall be determined by the fire prevention bureau based upon the standards set out in the fire prevention code, and the particular facts and circumstances of the violation. 
(d)  Notifications shall be sufficient to an owner if presented personally, or to any shareholder, registered agent, partner, member, manager of a limited liability company, officer, director, trustee, or to any managerial or supervisory person of the owner on the premises at the time of delivery. Notifications shall be sufficient to a tenant or other occupant if presented personally, or to any shareholder, registered agent, partner, member, manager of a limited liability company, officer, director, trustee, or to any managerial or supervisory person of the tenant or occupant on the premises at the time of delivery. 
(e)  Penalty for violations. [Reserved.] 
(Code 1976, § 4-2030; Ord. No. 4462, § 1, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 4-2031. - Nuisance fire alarms. 
(a)  A nuisance alarm is any unwanted activation of a signaling system or an alarm initiating device in response to a stimulus or condition that is not the result of a potentially hazardous condition, and which causes the fire department to respond to the alarm service location. 
    An alarm service location that produces five (5) or more nuisance alarms within a three hundred sixty-five-day period shall be classified as chronic nuisance alarm prone system, and the alarm user shall pay the service fees set out below. The alarm user in a commercial location shall be the operator of the commercial enterprise at that location or, if none, the owner of the building. The alarm user in a residential location shall be the residents or, if none, the residence owner. 
(b)  Service fees for nuisance fire alarm notifications. 
(1)  The alarm user shall be charged a service fee for nuisance alarms pursuant to the following schedule: 
a.  One through four (4), no charge. A warning will be included in the notification to the alarm user. 
b.  Five (5) to eight (8), twenty-five dollars ($25.00) each occurrence. 
c.  Nine (9) to twelve (12), fifty dollars ($50.00) each occurrence. 
d.  Thirteen (13) or more, two hundred dollars ($200.00) each occurrence. 
(2)  Alarms will be counted for the twelve-month period previous to the date of any false alarm. 
(3)  The fire chief shall have the ability to waive any service fee for any false alarm based upon any facts or in any situation he deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 4519, § 1(4-2200), 4-10-18) 
Editor's note- Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 4519, adopted April 10, 2018, enacted provisions to be designated as § 4-2200. In order to maintain the categorical standards of the Code, said new provisions have been redesignated as § 4-2031. 
Sec. 4-2032. - Authorized outdoor burnings. 
    Except as authorized below, all outdoor fires shall be prohibited, and violations are subject to the penalties provided in section 11-4006. 
(a)  Recreational outdoor burning. Recreational outdoor burning shall be allowed only under the following conditions: 
(1)  The burning must occur in a metal, clay, brick, stone or similar fire-proof container which is suitable for the size, type and nature of the burning, and where the area containing the burning material does not exceed five (5) feet by five (5) feet in size; 
(2)  The container shall be at least twenty (20) feet away from any structure or other combustible materials; 
(3)  The container must be monitored throughout the duration of the burning; 
(4)  Only dry wood products may be used as fuel. 
(5)  There shall be a water hose attached to a functional water supply located within thirty-five (35) feet of the burning. 
The limitations above do not apply to any non-commercial cooking pit, cooker, stove, oven, or similar container, or to any device fueled solely with natural gas, butane, propane, kerosene or similar commercially-provided product, when used by the manufacturer as intended for cooking or heating purposes, nor to any appropriately licensed commercial pit, cooker, stove or oven. 
(b)  Commercial outdoor burning. Commercial outdoor burning is allowed only at the discretion of the fire department, and shall be based upon the size, nature and type of materials to be burned, the method to be utilized, the location of the site, the proposed hours during which there shall be burning, the weather and conditions existing and such other factors as the fire department shall determine appropriate. All commercial burning shall require a burning permit from the LA. Department of Environmental Quality and from the fire department of the city. The cost of the burning permit from the fire department shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  Nuisance. Even if otherwise allowed or approved as provided above, no outside burning can be or create a nuisance, such as with the smoke or odor produced, to the surrounding occupants (unless specifically provided in a commercial outdoor burning permit). 
(Ord. No. 4520, § 1(4-2500), 4-10-18) 
Editor's note- Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 4520, adopted April 10, 2018, enacted provisions to be designated as § 4-2500. In order to maintain the categorical standards of the Code, said new provisions have been redesignated as § 4-2032. 
Chapter 3 - DISASTER EMERGENCIES[6] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference- Emergency powers of mayor, § 2-2002; flood hazard prevention, Part 12, Ch. 6.

Sec. 4-3001. - Civil defense organization created. 
    There is hereby created a local organization for civil defense, pursuant to the provisions of R.S. 29:601 et seq. and related laws. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3001) 
Sec. 4-3002. - Mayor may execute agreements. 
    The mayor, as the city's chief executive officer, may enter into or execute agreements between the city and the parish, and municipalities located therein, to establish a joint action civil defense organization under the provisions of R.S. 33:1324. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3002) 
Charter reference- Mayor as executive officer of city, § 3-301; mayor to execute agreements, § 3-307. 
State Law reference- Regional organizations for civil defense, R.S. 29:608(B). 
Sec. 4-3003. - Director to be appointed; responsibilities. 
    The local organization for civil defense created under this chapter shall have a director who shall be appointed by the state civil defense director on the recommendation of the mayor and the board of aldermen and who shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of the local organization for civil defense subject to the direction and control of the board under the general direction and control of the governor, and the secretary of the state department of public safety and corrections. The director shall execute and enforce the orders, rules and regulations as may be made by the governor through the secretary of said state department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3003) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of Louisiana Civil Defense Agency transferred, R.S. 36:409(F). 
Sec. 4-3004. - Aid or assistance from federal or state governments authorized. 
    When the federal or state government or any agency or officer thereof shall offer to the city, services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift, grant or loan for purposes of civil defense, the director, acting with the consent of the governor, and through the mayor or the board of aldermen, may accept the offer and is authorized to receive the aid and assistance. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3004; Ord. No. 2093, § 13, 3-12-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 29:610. 
Sec. 4-3005. - Director to prepare detailed civil defense plan. 
    The director of the local organization for civil defense is authorized and directed to prepare a detailed plan for civil defense operations in this city and to recruit and train personnel in accordance with the plan to the end that when disaster strikes, each member of this local organization will know his part and his duty. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3005) 
State Law reference- Local disaster emergency plan, R.S. 29:709(G). 
Sec. 4-3006. - Director authorized to use services and equipment of other departments. 
    The director is hereby authorized to utilize the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of this city to the maximum extent practicable, and the officers and personnel of all departments and agencies are directed to cooperate and extend services and facilities to the mayor and board and the director upon request. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3006) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 29:611.

ARTICLE A. - ADMINISTRATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 6 of Ord. No. 2633, adopted Sept. 11, 1990, repealed former Art. A, §§ 5-1001-5-1006, 5-1008, Art. B, §§ 5-1011-5-1013, and § 7 enacted provisions to read as set out in App. A, §§ 5-1001-5-1007, and App. B, §§ 5-1021-5-1028. The repealed provisions pertained to obstructions and to the use and cleanliness of streets, and derived from Code 1976, §§ 5-1001-5-1006, 5-1008, 5-1011-5-1013, and 5-1028. Former § 5-1011 was also repealed by Ord. No. 2368, § 2, adopted Sept. 11, 1990. Sections 5-1007 and 5-1014 were renumbered as §§ 5-1038 and 8-1012(i), respectively, by §§ 4 and 5 of Ord. No. 2366. 

Sec. 5-1001. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to regulate the use of public rights-of-way to protect the safety and general welfare of the public, and to provide for the prompt abatement of violations while protecting individual rights. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1002. - Abatement procedures in general. 
    In the event any person shall fail or neglect to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the city is authorized and empowered to cause the violation to be corrected and to assess all the charges and expenses incurred by the city for abatement and corrective actions against the person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1003. - Abatement notice. 
(a)  If the city undertakes abatement action, the owner of property abutting the area of the violation who is responsible for causing it or other responsible party shall be notified of the city's intent to abate the violation and shall be given no less than ten (10) days to voluntarily abate the violation. The city may serve notice on the owner by registered or certified mail, through personal delivery by any city employee, or as otherwise allowed by law. 
(b)  Notice may also be given by advertising for two (2) consecutive days in the official journal of the city for violations of section 5-1025(c). 
(c)  The city may extend the time limit for compliance or voluntary abatement through the execution of an abatement contract, signed and duly executed, which specifies the actions to be taken and the time limit allowed. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1004. - City to specify conditions. 
    The notice of the city's intent to abate a violation shall identify the nature and location of the violation, description of the property abutting the area of the nuisance and the owner thereof who is responsible or other responsible party, and the length of time allowed for voluntary correction. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1005. - Abatement charges. 
(a)  All charges, costs, and expenses for abatement or correction of the violations incurred by the city shall be assessed to the person responsible; and, if said person refuses to reimburse the city's costs, the amount thereof may be collected through civil proceedings directed against such person. 
(b)  In the case of abated noxious weeds regulated in section 5-1025(c), if after cutting, destruction, or removal by the city, the cost or expense thereof has not been paid within ten (10) days, the tax collector of the city shall furnish the owner, as shown on the last assessment roll, by registered mail, a written statement showing the cost or expense incurred for the work, and the place or property on which the work was done. If the statement is not paid within one month thereafter, the amount thereof shall be included in and form part of the taxes due by the owner of the property and, when collected, shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1006. - Criminal penalties not precluded by abatement. 
    Abatement actions taken by the city under this chapter shall not preclude the imposition of criminal penalties as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1007. - Emergency abatement. 
    Whenever the appropriate municipal official determines that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, he may, without prior notice or hearing issue an order that such emergency exists, requiring that such action be taken as deemed necessary to meet the emergency and such order shall be effective immediately. Failure of the responsible party to immediately abate violations of this section shall be unlawful and subject to the remedies and penalties of this chapter, and the city, without further notice, may institute action to relieve the public of any threat. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Secs. 5-1008-5-1020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - OBSTRUCTIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note- See the editor's footnote to the title of Art. A. 

Sec. 5-1021. - Merchandise. 
    The sale of goods or the placing of merchandise shall be conducted lawfully on private property only as required by section 12-5005. Public alleys, streets, sidewalks, and other public rights-of-way shall not be used for the sale or storage of merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1022. - Structures. 
    The building, erecting or installing of structures, buildings, fences, walls, signs, poles, barricades, ramparts, or other works in public alleys, ditches, or other rights-of-way or any other public property by any person is prohibited, except as provided by section 5-1023. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1023. - Temporary obstructions. 
    The director of public works may issue a temporary permit, not to exceed ninety (90) days in duration, for persons engaged in the construction or repair of buildings or other improvements, to obstruct public rights-of-way, but only to the extent necessary to complete the project. Appropriate measures to assure the safe passage of vehicles and pedestrians, as deemed necessary by the director of public works, shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1024. - Construction near streets or sidewalks. 
    Sidewalk safety tunnels shall be constructed to provide safe passage of pedestrians near structures undergoing construction, repair or restoration in close proximity to public ways. These passages shall be sufficient to allow passage of the physically handicapped, including those in wheelchairs. Tunnel ceilings and walls must be sufficient to protect pedestrians from falling objects. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1025. - Debris, objects and noxious weeds. 
(a)  Except as provided in Chapter 1 of Part 8 concerning refuse collection procedures, no person shall place discarded material, junk, debris, hardware, furniture, boxes, or any other object in any street, alley, gutter, ditch, street median, easement, right-of-way, or other public property. 
(b)  Accumulations of leaves, debris, and other waste which may wash into ditches or drainage systems or otherwise threaten the public health or safety are prohibited. 
(c)  No person shall allow noxious weeds or grass or other deleterious, unhealthful, or noxious growths to grow on any sidewalks or banquettes abutting their property. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1026. - Abandoned motor vehicles. 
    No motor vehicle shall be abandoned on any street, sidewalk, alley, public right-of-way or other public property. Vehicles are considered "abandoned" when left unattended for five (5) or more days. An abandoned motor vehicle may be seized and stored as provided by sections 9-1007 and 9-1008. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1027. - Junk or wrecked motor vehicles. 
(a)  No junk, wrecked or used automobile or motor vehicle, or any part or parts thereof, shall be left unattended on any neutral ground, street, sidewalk, or other public right-of-way or public property. The term "junk, wrecked or used automobile or motor vehicle" shall mean any motor vehicle which is so totally inoperable, damaged, or dismantled as to be a total loss. The term "total loss" shall be applied if the cost to repair said vehicle exceeds the junk value of the vehicle as determined by any recognized national appraisal book. 
(b)  The city shall have the right to remove and dispose of any junk, wrecked or used motor vehicle by selling it for scrap or other means it may deemed appropriate after not less than ten (10) days' notice has either been placed on the vehicle itself or given to the owner, if known. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-1028. - Barricades. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle into or upon any street, alley, or other public way that has been barricaded by an authorized employee of the city. 
(b)  No person other than an employee of the city shall remove any barricade which has been erected by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 7, 9-11-90) 
Secs. 5-1029, 5-1030. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 5-1031. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except as provided by public utility franchises, or employees of the city in the course of their employment, to open, dig into, remove the surface from or excavate any street, sidewalk, alley, public way or place without first obtaining a permit therefore from the city. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1021) 
Cross reference- Franchises, Part. 3. 
Sec. 5-1032. - Application for permit. 
    An application for an excavation permit shall contain such information as is required by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1022) 
Sec. 5-1033. - Regulations authorized. 
    In granting an excavation permit, reasonable regulations may be imposed including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The manner of making the excavation; 
(2)  The location of the excavation; 
(3)  Protection of underground utility installations; 
(4)  The duration of the excavation; 
(5)  Required safety precautions, such as barricades, lights, warning devices, etc.; 
(6)  The extent and size of the excavation; and 
(7)  Steps to be taken to protect nearby property owners. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1023) 
Sec. 5-1034. - Assets; insurance. 
    The applicant for an excavation permit shall submit satisfactory evidence that he has sufficient assets or insurance to indemnify the city for any costs, losses or liabilities that it may incur by reason of such excavation, and to satisfy any judgments or liabilities arising out of the excavation. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1024) 
Sec. 5-1035. - Backfilling and resurfacing. 
    It shall be the duty of the person making any excavation under this article to fill the excavation and restore the surface to a condition in accordance with city specifications. If required, the person making an excavation shall furnish a bond, deposit or other security sufficient to assure compliance with this section; provided, however, that the city may elect to fill and resurface the excavation and charge the cost thereof against the person making the excavation. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1025) 
Sec. 5-1036. - Inspections required; fee. 
    All excavations except those backfilled and resurfaced by the city shall be inspected and approved by the city before and after backfilling and before and after resurfacing. A reasonable fee for each man-hour or portion thereof spent by city employees making such inspections may be charged. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1026) 
Sec. 5-1037. - Public utilities; fee for removal of street surface; boring under streets. 
(a)  The city inspector shall charge the sum fixed by the board of aldermen per square foot of surface area of street or right-of-way removed as a result of installation by any public utility company or other person of public utilities installed underground within the city limits and necessitating the removal of street surface areas or areas adjacent to the streets or other public properties in the city. 
(b)  When it becomes necessary for the city to repair any street surface, right-of-way or public property within the city limits due to the improper installation of underground public utilities by any public utility company or person, the city inspector shall charge the public utility company or person making the improper or defective installation the sum fixed by the board of aldermen per square foot, for all areas repaired as a result of such improper or defective installation. 
(c)  An installation of underground public utilities shall be deemed improper and defective when the installation is not completed in a good and workmanlike manner within ten (10) days of the commencement of work thereon or if it becomes necessary for the city to make any repairs to the surface area of the installation within ninety (90) days of the completion of the installation. 
(d)  The city inspector shall charge the sum fixed by the board of aldermen per street crossing or portion thereof resulting from the installation of public utilities under the city streets where the installation is made by the method of boring instead of excavating through the surface of the street, and the boring is performed by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1027) 
Sec. 5-1038. - Construction of driveways and culverts. 
    No person or his agent shall construct or install any driveway or drainage culvert within the city without first receiving approval of such construction as to size and quality by the mayor or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 2366, § 5, 9-11-90) 
Editor's note- Former § 5-1007, derived from Code 1976, § 5-1007, was renumbered as § 5-1038 by Ord. No. 2366, § 5, adopted Sept. 11, 1990. 
Charter reference- Actions requiring an ordinance, § 209; collection of revenues by mayor, § 301; utilities and maintenance department, §§ 403, 409; collection of street paving assessments by clerk, § 408. 
State Law reference- Municipal powers relative to streets and sidewalks, R.S. 33:401(a)(11), (12), (16)-(21), 33.3301 et seq.; grant of franchises for use of streets, etc., R.S. 33:4401 et seq. 
Secs. 5-1039-5-1050. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - DISPLAY OF MUNICIPAL STREET ADDRESSES 

Sec. 5-1051. - Display of numbering. 
(a)  Each separate residence and business shall display the municipal street number which has been assigned to it in a manner and location whereby it is easily visible from the public street. 
(b)  The municipal street number shall be displayed in lettering no less than three (3) inches in height, and shall be of such a nature, of such coloring or of such a material as to insure it is easily and readily visible. It may, but need not be, of a material which is designed to be reflective of light at night and may, but need not be, illuminated. 
(c)  Should the owner of any structure which is required to be numbered under this article not comply with all provisions relating to numbering contained in this section within fifteen (15) days of notice of noncompliance with these requirements, the city shall be entitled to install or affix such numbering, and to charge the owner of the property or structure the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for such installation. If such amount has not been paid within thirty (30) days from the date of invoice, the city shall be entitled to initiate proceedings in the city court of the City of West Monroe for such amount, plus court costs and reasonable attorney's fees (to the extent allowable by law). 
(d)  The mayor shall from time to time designate the department or departments responsible for compliance with these provisions, and for installation of numbering when undertaken by the city. 
(e)  Intentional removal of required numbering, without reinstallation of that or other numbering which complies with the provisions of this section, is hereby declared to be unlawful, and shall subject the offender to a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense, and up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for any subsequent offense within a five-year period. 
(Ord. No. 2522, § 1, 7-13-93; Ord. No. 2541, § 1, 9-24-93) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2522, adopted July 13, 1993, added provisions designated as § 26-43. For purposes of classification, such provisions have been redesignated as Pt. 5, Ch. 1, Art. D, § 5-1051 at the discretion of the editor. 
ARTICLE E. - VEHICULAR ACCESS ON RESIDENTIAL STREETS 

Sec. 5-1061. - Requests to control vehicular access on residential streets. 
(a)  Filing of application. Any person, organized homeowners association or developer desiring to construct any access gate or other improvement whatsoever which is designed and intended to restrict vehicular access upon, through, or across any residential street or other public access within the limits of the city shall first file an application with the department of planning and zoning requesting a permit to construct and maintain such improvement/encroachment. 
(b)  Petition to accompany application. The application shall be accompanied by a petition signed by ninety (90) percent of the property owners of the area to be affected by the request which indicates the desire and agreement of those owners that the city allow the action requested in the application. That application shall include three (3) copies of a scale plat or sketch which reflects the extent of any publicly owned property or street intended to be used for the encroachment, the proposed design of the improvement to be constructed, a detailed description of the type of material to be used in the construction of the improvement, and such other information as the city may from time-to-time determine desirable, together with the payment of an application fee in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). If the application is approved, failure to construct, install, or maintain the improvements in the manner approved shall be grounds for the revocation of the permit and demolition or removal of the structure at the expense of the applicant. 
(c)  Addition/withdrawal of petition signatures. Any additions or withdrawals of signatures to the petition shall be in writing and filed with the department of planning and zoning within fifteen (15) days of the final receipt of the application, petition and other documentation required by this section. 
(d)  Department comments and recommendations; public hearing. 
(1)  Upon the receipt of all documentation required by this section, the department of planning and zoning shall forward copies of the application to and request comments and recommendations from the department of public works (streets, water, and sewage), fire department, police department, city engineer, city attorney, and any other city department, official or public utility company that would be affected by the approval of the request, and to the mayor and each of the members of the city council. 
(2)  After public notice the planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the requested encroachment. The planning commission shall establish guidelines for giving prior notice to persons in the area affected by the proposed encroachment, including those residing in the area enclosed by the encroachment and those residing near but outside that area. After the public hearing, the planning commission shall thereafter make a recommendation to the board of aldermen regarding the application. 
(3)  In the event of a proposed new subdivision, the request to restrict access may be considered concurrently with the approval of the proposed subdivision. Such concurrent application shall not reduce the fee payable pursuant to subsection (b) for this request. 
(e)  Execution of indemnity. If the application for a restriction is approved by the board of aldermen, the requesting party(ies), shall execute an indemnity and hold harmless agreement in favor of the city relieving the city from liability for all injury or damage occasioned to any person or property as a result of the approval and maintenance of the encroachment, and for the cost of demolition and removal of the structure, if later required. This agreement shall be prepared by the city and shall contain such provisions as the city determines appropriate or desirable in order to protect the interests of the city. 
(f)  Additional requirements. The requesting party(ies) shall also maintain commercial general liability insurance in an amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000.000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate, with a commercially reasonable deductible written by a solvent insurance company or companies authorized to do business in the state, having at least a B+5 Best or equivalent rating, naming the city as an additional named insured, fully protecting both the requesting party(ies) and the city from all claims, suits, judgments, causes of action, and any other matter arising out of the approval or existence of the encroachment, including any expenses of defense of any claim by the city. The requesting party(ies) shall provide the city with the certificate of insurance evidencing the coverage required herein prior to the construction of the encroachment and shall furnish annually thereafter, no later than January 5 of each year, for so long as the encroachment remains, a certificate of insurance evidencing the maintenance of the coverage required herein. The policy and certificate of insurance shall contain a provision whereby the insurance company is obligated to give the city no less than thirty (30) days' written notice of the cancellation or alteration of the policy. A certificate or certificates of the foregoing shall be delivered to the department of planning and zoning prior to the construction of the encroachment and annually thereafter. The department of planning and zoning shall promptly provide copies of those certificates to the city clerk. 
(g)  [Transfers.] At any time during the application process, the applicant (whether an individual, group of individuals, or entity, and whether property owners or developers) may transfer that application to any other individual, group of individuals or other legal entity, who shall thereafter be considered as the applicant under all of the terms, conditions and provisions of this section. Further, any person, group of persons or legal entity who have obtained consent of the city to limit public access may, upon transfer of all immovable property and improvements relating to that restriction, likewise transfer the grant of approval obtained under this section to any other individual, group of individuals, or other legal entity if the transferee has executed the required indemnity, provided the required insurance and otherwise complied with all terms, conditions and provisions of this ordinance and the grant of authority. Any such transfer shall not relieve the transferor of any liability, obligation, debt or expense arising prior to or pending at the time of such transfer. 
(h)  Results of noncompliance with requirements; right to revoke approval. No required permit shall be issued to the requesting party(ies) for the construction of the encroachment until such time as all requirements of this section have been met and approval is granted by the city council. Moreover, the city reserves the right to revoke any approval granted hereunder and to remove such encroachment(s) if the requirements of subsection (f) are not met annually. If the approval is revoked and the improvements are demolished/removed due to noncompliance with subsection (f) above, or for any other grounds set out in this section, neither the applicant/owner nor any other persons shall have any recourse or claim of any type or nature whatsoever against the city for the removal of the encroachment. 
(i)  Exceptions; rights of city provided for, etc. The ordinance authorizing the improvement/encroachment shall provide that the city reserves the right to terminate the rights granted by the approval if a public purpose is found to exist for the public property burdened with the encroachment, or for consideration of public safety, or if for any other reason the city determines the improvement/encroachment is no longer proper or desirable, as determined in the discretion of the city. Additionally, the board of aldermen may condition the approval of the improvement/encroachment upon such other terms and conditions as it deems appropriate. The ordinance granting the encroachment shall also require the party(ies) to whom is granted the encroachment the obligations to establish a method satisfactory to the city to provide access to city personnel, Ouachita Parish Sheriff's personnel, emergency personnel and representatives of public utilities and public franchisees in the performance of their duties in such a manner as the city may determine appropriate. Further, any approval granted which would allow limited vehicular access on any public residential street shall also provide that access to the street shall not be restricted by the requesting party(ies) or any other person or party acting on their behalf between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., seven (7) days a week unless otherwise allowed by the express written consent of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 3613, § 1, 11-14-06; Ord. No. 3618, § 1, 11-14-06) 
Chapter 2 - CEMETERIES[5] 
Footnotes:
