ARTICLE A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-2001. - Cemetery trust-Established. 
    There is hereby established a trust to be known as the "Hasley Cemetery Trust of the City of West Monroe, Louisiana," said trust being more particularly described and outlined in detail as per Article B (Exhibit "A," attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived). 
(Code 1976, § 5-3001; Ord. No. 1637, § 1, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2093, § 14, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2002. - Same-Authority of mayor. 
    The mayor may execute any and all acts and may do and perform any and all things necessary to carry out the trust established in the preceding section. 
(Code 1976, § 5-3001; Ord. No. 1637, § 2, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2003. - Same-Existing obligations. 
    The establishment of the trust mentioned in section 5-2001 shall not terminate, modify or affect any contracts, agreements or obligations presently existing between the city and any person, firm, corporation or other legal entity in relation to the Hasley Cemetery, but, in accordance with the provisions of said trust, the obligations existing between the city and any other person or legal entity in relation to the Hasley Cemetery shall be transferred to and become the responsibility of the trust, whenever possible. 
(Code 1976, § 5-3001; Ord. No. 1637, § 3, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2004. - Rules and regulations. 
    The Mayor of the City of West Monroe shall from time to time establish rules and regulations which shall be applicable to any and all aspects of the operation and maintenance of Hasley Cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 3272, § 1, 10-8-02) 
Secs. 5-2005-5-2020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - HASLEY CEMETERY TRUST (TEXT) 

Sec. 5-2021. - Established. 
(a)  In accordance with Article A of this chapter, there is hereby established, as set forth in this Article B, a trust to be known as the "Hasley Cemetery Trust for the City of West Monroe, Louisiana," referred to in this article as the "trust." 
(b)  There is hereby delivered to the trustees, to hold in trust on the terms and conditions more fully set forth below the following described property, to wit: All the real property, structures located thereon and appurtenances thereto which constitute that property known as the Hasley Cemetery and located within the city limits as per plat thereof in Plat Book 5, Page 23, of the records of Ouachita Parish, Louisiana, less and except all plats, parcels and pieces previously sold or alienated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § I, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2022. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the trust is to establish a system by which the city can insure an adequate and effective method in perpetuity of financing and operating those cemetery facilities presently owned by the city and any such facilities which the city may hereafter decide it is necessary to acquire or create. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § II, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2023. - Duration. 
    The trust is to be perpetual in existence except and only insofar as same may be terminated as outlined under section 5-2036. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § III, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2024. - Use of property under trust. 
(a)  As to those pieces or parcels of immovable property transferred to the trust or as may hereafter be acquired by the trust for use as cemetery facilities, the board shall develop a plan providing that all or any portion of said land is divided into burial plots of a size and character to be determined by the board. 
(b)  The board may also designate parts of the land to be used for sidewalks, aisles, gardens, lighting, storage facilities, chapels, sexton or caretaker buildings, streets, outside fences, drainage or other buildings, structures or uses as the board deems necessary for the proper operation and maintenance of a cemetery facility. 
(c)  The burial plots shall conform to any and all valid laws, ordinances or regulations concerning the size, depth, spacing and other safety or health characteristics of burial plots located in cemeteries in the state. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § IV, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2025. - Sale of burial plots, interment service and care. 
    The board shall endeavor to sell either the burial plots or interment permits to members of the general public, at rates established by the board. The board may also enter into contracts designed to provide purchasers of an interment permit or the owners of burial plots with an interment service and the maintenance of the gravesite including provisions for perpetual care. The consideration and terms of such contracts shall be established by the board. Further, the board may establish any type of installment, cash discount or other payment plans or programs as it deems in the best interest of the successful operation of the cemetery facilities; said board shall possess all powers necessary to carry out the terms of this trust, including the power to compromise any and all claims and to judicially enforce any claims. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § V, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2026. - Use of funds derived from sales. 
    The funds and fees generated or derived from the sale of burial plots, interment permits, interment and care services shall be devoted exclusively to the administration and maintenance of the trust. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § VI, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2027. - Establishment of trust fund and investment thereof. 
(a)  The board shall deposit no less than seventy-five (75) percent of any and all funds or fees from the sale of each interment permit or burial plot or contract for interment or care services into a special account established by the board to be known as the "Hasley Cemetery Trust Fund," hereinafter referred to as the "trust fund." 
(b)  The trust fund shall be invested by the board in securities of the United States government, any state, parish, county or municipality, or shares of any savings and loan association located within this state whose share accounts are insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation having a fair market value equal to said amount of cash on the date of deposit. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § VII, § 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2028. - Purpose of trust fund; restrictions on use of principal. 
(a)  It is the purpose and intent of establishment of the trust fund that there by created a certain principal sum or corpus of funds which may be invested and generate a constant source of income to defray the expenses incurred by the board in the operation and maintenance of the cemetery facilities under this direction. 
(b)  That part of the trust funds constituting the principal of said fund shall not be withdrawn, expended, donated or otherwise diminished by the board. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § VIII, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2029. - Other funds; creation of trust fund administration account. 
    The remaining twenty-five (25) percent of funds and fees derived from the sales and contracts as set out in sections 5-2021 through 5-2034 is intended to cover the costs associated with the administration of the trust fund created by sections 5-2030 and 5-2031, and shall be deposited in an account, hereinafter referred to as the administration fund. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § IX, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2030. - Types of expenses. 
    Illustrative of those expenses which it is contemplated will be covered from the administration fund are the following: 
(1)  Costs relating to meetings of the board of trustees. 
(2)  Dues, fees and other costs of participation or membership in various groups or organizations relating to the operation of cemetery facilities, trust funds, etc. 
(3)  Reasonable expenses incurred by board members or other properly authorized representatives of the board in attending workshops, management sessions, seminars, conferences, etc., relating to the operations or management of a cemetery trust. 
(4)  Any taxes of other charges imposed upon the trust. 
(5)  Costs incurred in hiring a professional trust fund manager or securing advice on the operation or investment of the trust. 
(6)  Legal fees incurred in relation to the operations of the investments or management of the trust. 
(7)  Bank or financial institutional charges for investment of the trust funds. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § X, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2031. - Special uses of administration fund. 
    The board may designate that all or any part of said administration funds described in section 5-2029 may also be used to defray the costs of maintaining and operating those cemetery facilities operated by the board when circumstances are such that either the income generated by the investment of the trust funds are insufficient to cover operating maintenance cost or the income from the trust fund described in section 5-2032 is not presently available for payment of expenses or costs which the board deems necessary to pay. In either case, there shall be a reimbursement, as soon as practically possible, of the administration fund for any and all amounts expended out of the administration fund, which expenditures would normally be covered by income from the trust fund. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § XI, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2032. - Transfer of funds from administration fund to trust fund. 
    The board may transfer funds from the administration fund to the trust fund. Upon such transfer, the funds so transferred shall constitute and become part of the trust fund subject to the uses and restrictions upon said trust fund contained in this trust agreement. Such permanent transfer of funds from the administration fund to the trust fund are contemplated when the board is of the opinion that the administration fund has reached an amount which is more than adequate to cover the reasonably foreseeable future expenses to be paid from the administration fund and taking into consideration new monies reasonably expected to become part of the administration fund by the future sale of burial plots and contracts for interment and care services. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § XII, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2033. - Transfers of income from trust fund; records. 
(a)  The board shall establish a system for the transfer of income, interest, dividends, fees or other monies generated by the investment of the trust fund to such accounts as the board deems necessary to defray the costs of operating and maintaining those cemetery facilities under the board's control. 
(b)  The board may designate the frequency and amount of any such transfers and may establish whatever checking or saving accounts the board deems necessary to the effective fulfillment of its responsibilities. 
(c)  The board shall maintain an accurate financial record of all income, interest, dividends, fees and other monies generated by investment of the trust fund. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § XIII, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2034. - Excess income from the trust fund. 
    If the costs, for any particular year, of operating and maintaining those cemetery facilities under control of the board should be less than the income, interest, dividends, fees or other monies generated by investment of the trust fund, the board may either reinvest said excess income into the trust fund, thus making such reinvested monies part of the trust fund and subject to all restrictions and conditions placed upon the trust fund, or the board may retain the excess in those accounts established by the board to defray the operating and maintenance expenses of the cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part A, § XIV, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2035. - Board of trustees. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby created and established a board of trustees for the Hasley Cemetery Trust for the city, referred to in this section as the "board." 
(b)  Composition; officers; minutes of meetings. The board shall consist of the mayor and board of aldermen and their legally appointed or elected successors. The mayor shall be the executive director of the board and shall preside at all meetings of the board. The clerk of the city shall maintain an accurate record of the minutes of the meetings of the board. 
(c)  Terms. Each member of the board shall serve as a trustee of the trust so long as he shall occupy the position of mayor or a member of the board of aldermen. Upon his vacating said position, his membership as a trustee of the trust shall terminate and his successor in the position of mayor or member of the board of aldermen shall assume the office of trustee of said trust. 
(d)  Compensation. The members of the board of trustees of the trust shall serve without compensation or pay and shall be entitled only to reimbursement for reasonable and legitimate expenses incurred in the performance of their duties as trustees of the trust. 
(e)  Meeting; quorum; majority needed to act. The board shall meet in regular session at least once every three (3) months. The board may adopt rules or regulations calling for more frequent meetings. The initial meeting of the board shall be held at a time and place to be decided by the executive director of said board, but not less than seven (7) days from the establishment of this trust. The executive director of the trust may call the board into special session at any time upon giving the members of the board at least twenty-four (24) hours notice of such a meeting. A quorum of the board shall be necessary to transact any business of the board. A quorum of the board shall consist of a majority of the members of the board. A majority vote of a quorum shall be necessary in order for the board to exercise any of the powers vested in said board. Each member of the board shall have a single vote, excluding the executive director, who shall be entitled to cast one vote in the event of a tie vote. Except as above enumerated, the board shall provide for its organization and working procedure. 
(f)  Powers. The board is hereby vested with the general power to direct the operation and maintenance of those cemetery facilities under its control and the operation of the trust fund including, but not limited to, the following powers: 
(1)  To sell, hypothecate, alienate, transfer or lease any and all real or movable property transferred to or acquired by the trust. 
(2)  To enter into any and all manner of contracts. 
(3)  To purchase or lease any and all manner of property, both movable and immovable, machinery, tools, supplies, goods and services which the board deems necessary to the proper and efficient maintenance and administration of the trust. 
(4)  To procure insurance or indemnity agreements. 
(5)  To pay all reasonable and legitimate expenses incurred by board members in connection with the managing of cemetery facilities. 
(6)  To hire and pay the wages of employees to maintain, care for or administer the property subject to the trust. 
(7)  To accept donation of real or movable property or services made to the trust, provided there is no condition thereto inconsistent with the purposes herein set forth. 
(8)  To borrow money. 
(9)  To request and decline funds, goods or services appropriated to the trust by any governmental authority. 
(10)  To administer and supervise the investment of any funds, accounts or other investments, mandated or permitted in this trust, including the hiring of professional investment managers and banking trust officers. 
(g)  Assumption of prior obligations. Within a reasonable period after its initial meeting, the board shall endeavor to develop and implement a plan whereby the board would undertake to assume the responsibility for those contracts, obligations and agreements which presently exist between the city and other persons in relation to the operations or maintenance of cemetery facilities by the city. The board shall develop whatever system to accomplish this that it deems in the best interest of the trust and the continued operation of the cemetery facilities. 
(h)  Financial records. The board shall cause to be maintained a set of financial records showing in detail the receipts and expenditures or disbursement of funds by the board. 
(i)  Budget. Within thirty (30) days prior to the end of a current fiscal year, the board shall develop and adopt a comprehensive budget covering the forthcoming fiscal year. 
(j)  Annual report. The board shall file, in writing, an annual report including the financial condition of the trust fund with the governmental authority of the city. The annual report shall be filed within ninety (90) days after the end of the fiscal year. The annual report shall include the following: 
(1)  A summary of the activities of the board over the period covered; 
(2)  Any recommendations for changes or modifications in the trust document; 
(3)  Any recommendations for actions by the governmental authority of the city in relation to the trust or to the acquisition, funding or operation of cemetery facilities by the city; 
(4)  A copy of the financial reports for the immediately preceding year; and 
(5)  An itemized budget prepared by the board outlining the anticipated revenue and expenses covering the year immediately following that period covered by the last annual report. 
(k)  Annual accounting and audit. The board shall cause to be prepared an annual accounting of all funds received and disbursed by the board. This accounting shall be conducted within sixty (60) days of the end of the fiscal year of the city and shall cover a period of one year and same to coincide with the fiscal year employed by the city for accounting purposes. The annual accounting shall contain a detailed statement of all income, interest, dividends or fees generated or earned during the immediate preceding fiscal year by the investment of all funds held by the board and the manner, amount and ultimate deposit and expenditure of such income, interest, dividends or fees by the board and all other financial attributes engaged in during the period covered by the accounting. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part B, §§ I-XI, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2036. - Modification, termination of trust. 
(a)  Modification. The provisions of the trust document in this article may be modified, new parts, sections or subsections added or current parts, sections or subsections eliminated only by means of an ordinance enacted by the governmental authority of the city at a meeting legally convened and with prior notice of the time and place of such meeting. 
(b)  Termination. It is the intent of the governmental authority of West Monroe, Louisiana that this trust shall be maintained in perpetuity. Upon the termination of the trust, the governmental authority of the city shall cause to be conducted a final audit and accounting of all assets and liabilities of whatever nature held by the trust at the time of termination of the trust, and the assets therefrom shall become the property of the city. 
(c)  Liability of trust and trustees. Neither the trust nor the trustees shall be under any liability or responsibility to the city, nor to owners of lots or properties in those cemetery facilities under their administration, for any action or inaction in the conduct, administration or management of the trust, or for funds or properties of the trust, save and except only for willful misconduct or bad faith. There shall be no liability or responsibilities for errors of judgment or depreciation of investments. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part C, § III, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 5-2037. - Severability. 
    It is intended that the provisions, parts, sections and subsections of the trust document in this article be severable in character. If any provision, part, section or subsection or application thereof is declared invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions, parts, sections or subsections, or the trust document which can be given effect without the invalid provisions, parts, sections or subsections, or applications, and to that end the provisions of this trust agreement are to be considered severable. 
(Ord. No. 1637, Exhibit "A," Part C, § IV, 2-8-77; Ord. No. 2366, § 2, 9-11-90) 
Part 6 - PARKS, RECREATION AND CULTURAL AFFAIRS 
Chapter 1 - PLAYGROUNDS AND RECREATION 

Sec. 6-1001. - Playground and recreation board-Established. 
    There is created a playground and recreation board to consist of five (5) members to be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1001) 
Charter reference- Mayor as member of boards and commissions, § 307. 
Cross reference- Government and administration, Part 2. 
State Law reference- Playground and recreation board, R.S. 33:4553 et seq. 
Sec. 6-1002. - Same-Membership. 
(a)  The members of the playground and recreation board shall serve without compensation and their term of office shall be five (5) years and until their successors are appointed and qualified, except that the members first appointed shall be appointed for such terms that the term of one member shall expire annually after the creation of the board. 
(b)  One member of the board shall be the city clerk, who shall be the treasurer of the board. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1002) 
State Law reference- Membership of playground and recreation board, R.S. 33:4554. 
Sec. 6-1003. - Same-Duties. 
    The playground and recreation board shall have control of and supervision of all public recreation and playground facilities and it shall be its duty to plan and formulate an adequate recreation program for the youth of the city and may recommend the hiring of personnel to carry the program into effect, all subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1003) 
Sec. 6-1004. - Director. 
    The director of the department of community services and recreation shall supervise all park and recreational activities and programs of this city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1004) 
Charter reference- Director of community services and recreation, §§ 403, 405. 
Chapter 2 - PARKS 
ARTICLE A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-2001. - Commercial access for concession purposes. 
    The Mayor of the City of West Monroe shall be authorized from time to time to establish rules and regulations which shall provide for the standards under which commercial vendors may provide food services on a non-exclusive basis within the confines of some or all city recreational facilities. This authority shall include, but not be limited to, the designation of the type and manner of providing services, the designated area in which that service may be provided, the times and dates of operation (including the right to only allow operations and access during certain periods of use or certain events, and to exclude operations and access during certain periods of use or during certain events) establishing requirements for licensing, insurance, accountability and all such other provisions or limitations as the mayor shall determine appropriate, and further including but not limited to the right to exclude certain persons and entities from further access for violation of these provisions, or the violation of the rules and regulations relating to the city recreational facilities or other violation of local, state or federal law. Except as expressly authorized by the rules and regulations established, no commercial venture shall be authorized within city recreational facilities. 
(Ord. No. 3469, § 1, 5-10-05) 
Secs. 6-2002-6-2030. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - KIROLI PARK[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2195, adopted April 14, 1987 did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-20 as § 6-2031 comprising Art. B of Ch. 2, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 6-2031. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  Firearms; hunting, trapping and possessing. No firearms, guns, pistols, air rifles, explosives or traps shall be possessed, carried or utilized in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. It shall be unlawful to hunt, kill, track, take possession of or remove any animal, bird, reptile, insect or amphibian from the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. 
(b)  Fishing. All fishing in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area will follow Louisiana Wildlife and Fisheries Rules and Regulations, and the rules and regulations of the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. The use of nets, yo-yo's or trot lines in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area is prohibited. 
(c)  Boating prohibited. All boats and other aquatic recreational equipment are prohibited in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. 
(d)  Archery prohibited. Bows and arrows, cross-bows and all similar instrumentalities are prohibited in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. 
(e)  Swimming prohibited. All swimming is prohibited within the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. 
(f)  Motor vehicles. All motor vehicles utilized in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area must meet all motor vehicle standards of the State of Louisiana and the City of West Monroe, including those regarding licensing of vehicles, lighting, inspection and safety stickers, and licensing of drivers. Speed limits and other traffic control devices shall be established within the Kiroli Park Recreational Area in the same manner as established throughout the City of West Monroe, and shall have the same force and effect. 
(g)  Restriction of operation of vehicles. Operation and parking of motor vehicles, motorized bikes and bicycles shall be restricted to designated parking areas and hard road surfaces (excluding walkways and trails). The use of any motorized or unmotorized vehicle of any type is prohibited on walkways or trail areas except when utilized by authorized park personnel. 
(h)  Operation of vehicles. No person shall operate any motor vehicle, motorized bike or bicycle in a careless, negligent or reckless manner so as to endanger any person or property. All persons operating a vehicle must abide by all signs and notifications, including those which indicate direction of traffic flow, speed limits, parking areas, and handicapped parking restrictions. 
(i)  Horseback riding. Except as provided by the rules and regulations of the Kiroli Park Recreational Area, horses, mules, donkeys and similar livestock are prohibited in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. 
(j)  Restriction on fires. Fires shall be confined to fireplaces, grills or other facilities designated for this purpose. Open camp fires or bonfires are prohibited. 
(k)  Sanitation. It shall be unlawful to dump or deposit refuge in or around the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. All trash must be deposited in garbage or trash containers provided for that purpose, or removed from the Kiroli Park Recreational Area premises. 
(l)  Protection of vegetation. No wildflower, tree or shrub in the Kiroli Park Recreational Area shall be picked, cut, broken or otherwise damaged in any way. The destruction, injury, defacement or removal of any object, natural or manmade, from within the Kiroli Park Recreational Area is strictly prohibited. 
(m)  Damaging public property prohibited. No person shall willfully deface, destroy or attempt to deface or destroy any structure or other public property in Kiroli Park Recreational Area. 
(n)  Noise, improper conduct prohibited. Loud or intrusive noise, music or conduct which is dangerous or annoying to any person is prohibited. The determination of loud or intrusive noise, music or conduct shall be made by park personnel. 
(o)  Alcoholic beverages. Except as expressly provided by the rules and regulations of the Kiroli Park Recreational Area, possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages within the Kiroli Park Recreational Area is strictly prohibited. 
(p)  Fees. It shall be unlawful to avoid or attempt to avoid payment of any or all fees charged for entrance into the Kiroli Park Recreational Area, or for the use of the Kiroli Park Recreational Area or any of its facilities. 
(q)  Interference with park employees. Any interference by any person with the actions of the employees of the Kiroli Park Recreational Area, including but not limited to the enforcement of the rules and regulations of the Kiroli Park Recreational Area, is unlawful. 
(r)  Additional rules and regulations. Additional rules and regulations and exceptions to the rules established in this section may be established from time to time by the mayor, or his designee. 
(s)  Penalties. All crimes and offenses established by the State of Louisiana and by the City of West Monroe shall apply within the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. However, in addition thereto and not in limitation of those crimes and offenses of general applicability, any person or persons violating any provision of these rules or of the rules and regulations for the Kiroli Park Recreational Area established by the Mayor of the City of West Monroe and duly posted within the Kiroli Park Recreational Area shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00), or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both. Park personnel shall additionally be empowered to immediately eject any person from within the Kiroli Park Recreational Area for the violation of any provision of these rules, or of the rules and regulations of the Kiroli Park Recreational Area. Any person resisting such ejectment, or thereafter returning to the Kiroli Park Recreational Area without express permission to do so, shall be deemed guilty of criminal trespass. 
(Ord. No. 2195, § 1-20, 4-14-87; Ord. No. 248, § 1, 4-1-95) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention code, § 4-2021 et seq.; boating, § 6-3001 et seq.; municipal utilities, Pt. 7; health and sanitation, Pt. 8; motor vehicles and traffic, Pt. 9; alcoholic beverages, § 10-2001 et seq.; crimes and offenses generally, Pt. 11; air guns, 11-4001; discharging firearms, § 11-4002; trash fires, § 11-4004; defacing buildings, § 11-4009; illegal carrying of weapons, § 11-4010; display of dangerous weapons, § 11-4011; negligent operation of a vehicle, § 11-4012; disturbing the peace, § 11-4014; unnecessary noise, § 11-5020. 
Secs. 6-2032-6-2050. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 2833, § 1, 5-13-97)

(Ord. No. 2833, § 1, 5-13-97)

ARTICLE F. - PROHIBITION OF SMOKING IN CITY PARKS AND RECREATIONAL AREAS 

Sec. 6-2076. - Smoking prohibited. 
    No person shall engage in smoking or other use of tobacco, and smoking or other use of tobacco shall be prohibited, other than in those areas, if any, expressly designated by the city for use of tobacco products. 
a.  Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) upon the first offense conviction. 
b.  Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) upon the second or subsequent offense conviction, and may be prohibited from entering the boundaries of a city park for a period of one year following a second or subsequent conviction. 
c.  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the immediate expulsion of a person when smoking in a city park even if not arrested, cited or summoned for a violation of this section. Upon a second expulsion within a period of six (6) months, a person may be prohibited from entering the boundaries of all city parks for a period of up to one year from the second expulsion. 
d.  Smoking shall be defined as inhaling, exhaling, burning, carrying or possessing any lighted tobacco product, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, together with any other combustible plant material. 
e.  Any reference to a "city park" shall include all areas within the boundaries of Kiroli Park, Lazarre Point Recreation Area, Restoration Park and all neighborhood parks owned by the city (Facen Park, Bryan Smith Park, and any other similar neighborhood parks), all ballparks (including, but not limited to, Brady Field), and all other public recreational areas. 
f.  Any city employee authorized by the mayor shall have the authority to cite any person who violates this section. 
(Ord. No. 4089, § 1, 10-9-12)

Chapter 3 - BOATING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boating on Kiroli Lake, § 6-2031(g). 

Sec. 6-3001. - Maximum speeds for boats or other motorized water vehicles. 
A.  It shall be unlawful to operate any boat or other motorized water vehicle in the Ouachita River at a speed in excess of idling speed for such vehicle within the following areas: 
1.  An area bounded on the north by the north line of Otis Street extended, on the east by the centerline of the Ouachita River, and on the south by the south line of Claiborne Street extended; 
2.  An area bounded on the north by the north line of Pine Street extended, on the east by the centerline of the Ouachita River, and on the south by the south line of Natchitoches Street extended; and 
3.  An area bounded on the north by the north line of the I-20 bridge, on the east by the centerline of the Ouachita River, and on the south by the south line extended of the concrete boat launch at Lazarre Park. 
B.  The mayor shall have the authority to suspend the limitations above as respects participants in certain organized events as to certain dates and/or times, all subject to such conditions and provisions as he shall determine appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 2304, 6-13-89; Ord. No. 3475, § 1, 6-14-05; Ord. No. 3573, § 1, 6-13-06) 
Chapter 4 - AGREEMENTS 

Sec. 6-4001. - Authorization. 
    The mayor is authorized to establish a system or systems of lease and/or rental of city facilities, including, but not limited to, the West Monroe Convention Center, the Ike Hamilton Expo Center, Kiroli Park, Lazarre Point Recreation Area, Restoration Park, city recreational facilities such as ball parks, the Farmer's Market and other city facilities held out for use by the public under such terms and conditions as he determines from time to time are appropriate, further authorizing the establishment of a system or systems of contractual rental agreements relating to such facilities or areas which bind the city to their terms and provisions, including a commitment for future recurring use, and further authorizing the mayor to delegate to the various department heads, supervisors and/or employees the right to negotiate and execute such agreements and certain of their terms and conditions, but all subject to such limitations as he may from time to time establish. 
(Ord. No. 3835, § 1, 7-14-09) 
Part 7 - MUNICIPAL UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:
