If, during the course of the permittee's construction, installation, or maintenance of the system, there occurs a disturbance of any city property by the permittee, the permittee shall immediately contact the department of public works for the city, which shall determine whether the disturbance is such that the permittee shall be required to replace and restore such city property to a condition reasonably comparable to the condition of the city property existing immediately prior to such disturbance; or whether the need to replace and restore (which shall also include the obligation to repair) shall be undertaken and completed by or on behalf of the city, at its direction and under its control, but which replacement and restoration shall be at the sole cost of the permittee, which shall promptly pay and/or reimburse that cost to the city upon receipt of an invoice for the replacement and restoration. The obligation to immediately contact the department of public works for the city shall be the obligation of the permittee, and of any and all supervisory persons on site; and of any and all persons in a further supervisory position of the persons on site, regardless of where these persons in a further supervisory position are actually located, if they know or should have known of the disturbance of city property by permittee. 
c.  Relocation at request of the city. If the city shall lawfully elect to vacate, relocate, abandon, alter, reconstruct or change any city property, the permittee, upon thirty (30) days' written notice by the city via certified or registered mail or national or regional delivery service providing proof of delivery to the permittee, shall remove, re-lay and relocate its structure, equipment, and facilities at its own expense. Should the permittee refuse or fail to remove system within thirty (30) days after written notification, the city shall have the right to remove the component parts of the system and charge the permittee for the costs of removal. 
d.  Relocation at request of third party. The permittee shall, on the request of any person holding a lawful building moving permit, protect, support, raise, lower, temporarily disconnect, relocate in or remove from any city property, as necessary, any property of the permittee provided: (i) the expense of such is paid by said person benefiting from the relocation, including, if required by the permittee, making such payment in advance; and (ii) the permittee is given reasonable advance written notice to prepare for such changes. For purposes of this section, "reasonable advance written notice" shall be no less than thirty (30) days in the event of a temporary relocation, and no less than one hundred twenty (120) days for a permanent relocation. 
e.  Interference with use of right-of-way; disturbance/damage to property of third persons. When working within city property, permittee shall not unreasonably interfere with public uses of said city property and the safety, health, and convenience of the public and the public's use thereof for ordinary travel. Permittee shall promptly repair and restore all property belonging to a third person located on or under city property which is damaged by permittee, including, but not limited to, driveways, curbs, private drainage, landscaping, signage, and similar improvements. If permittee shall damage any lines, cables, equipment or related property belonging to any other persons or entity, Permittee shall promptly notify such person or entity of that damage. 
(7)  No less than three (3) business days prior to commencement of construction, installation or maintenance activities within city property, the permittee shall notify the city of the specific locations and beginning and ending dates of said construction, installation, or maintenance project and shall provide current, accurate contact information for both the permittee and the contractor as outlined in subsection (4). Upon receipt of this notification, the city shall determine whether the proposed construction, installation, or maintenance activities shall pose an unreasonable inference with public uses. If the city determines the proposed activity presents no such unreasonable interference, it shall issue the permittee a notice to proceed. If the permittee receives no written notification from the city within twenty-four (24) hours of the proposed commencement of activities, the proposed activities may be deemed approved. This section shall not apply to emergency repair projects or utility service extension projects which the permittee could not have anticipated. 
(8)  The permittee shall keep all of the information required by subsection (4) current at all times by immediately providing the city written notice of changes in the manner indicated by city. 
(9)  Any person or entity: 
a.  Whose system occupies city property for business operations without obtaining the permit required in this article; 
b.  Who fails to provide the seventy-two-hour notice prior to commencement of construction, installation, or maintenance activities as required in subsection (6); or 
c.  Who fails to maintain current, accurate information required by subsection (4) concerning any system occupying city property may have any permit granted pursuant to this article revoked and may be denied future authorization for construction, installation, or maintenance activities for a period of two (2) years. 
(10)  Any violation of this article shall afford the city the full range of remedies available under any applicable law or regulation including the levying of fines. The election of one (1) or more remedies shall not be construed as a waiver of any other legal and/or equitable remedy including, but not limited to, the city's right to seek injunctive relief, damages, and attorney's fees as the law might allow. 
(11)  The provisions in this section shall be applicable to any and all activities relating to any and all systems which now occupy city property, regardless of when the system, or any portion, was first constructed or installed. 
(12)  It shall be unlawful for any person having the obligation to immediately contact the department of public works for the city in the event of a disturbance of any city property, as required by subsection (6)b., if the disturbance affects or affected any of city's water, sewer or stormwater drainage lines or equipment, and each and all such persons shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-1008. 
(Ord. No. 4641, § 1, 2-12-19; Ord. No. 4651, § 1, 3-12-19) 
Part 8 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Government and administration, Part 2; public safety, Part 4; public works, Part 5; parks, recreation and cultural affairs, Part 6; municipal utilities, Part 7; motor vehicles and traffic, Part 9; licensing and regulation, Part 10; planning and development, Part 12; private ambulances, § 10-3001 et seq. 

Chapter 1 - SANITARY CODE AND REFUSE COLLECTION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Chapter 1, previously "Sanitary code; refuse," was renamed by § 1 of Ord. No. 2367, adopted Sept. 11, 1990. 
Cross reference- Nuisances to the public, Part 8, Ch. 2. 

ARTICLE A. - SANITARY CODE 

Sec. 8-1001. - Adoption. 
    The city hereby adopts, and incorporates in this section by reference, the sanitary code of the state as prepared and promulgated by the state health officer in accordance with R.S. 40:3 et seq., insofar as the same is applicable to the city, and is more stringent than the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1001) 
Secs. 8-1002-8-1010. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - GARBAGE AND TRASH[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3676, § 1, adopted July 10, 2007, effective July 11, 2007, amended Article B in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, said Article pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1976, §§ 8-1011, 8-1012; as subsequently amended by Ord. No. 2908, § 2, adopted April 14, 1998. 
Charter reference- Utilities and maintenance department, §§ 403, 409. 
Cross reference- Litter, § 8-2031 et seq. 
State Law reference- Collection and disposal of garbage and trash, R.S. 33:4169.1; Louisiana Environmental Quality Act, R.S. 30:1051 et seq.; Louisiana Litter Control and Recycling Commission, R.S. 30:1150.41 et seq. 

Sec. 8-1011. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply: 
    Garbage: All solid kitchen refuse subject to decay or putrefaction, tin cans, bottles, paper, cardboard boxes, usual household containers (consumer-sized), putrescible vegetable matter, animal offal, animal carcasses, animal and vegetable waste matter from animal quarters and all market waste of animal or vegetable matter which was intended to be used as food. It includes all putrescible waste matter except sewage and industrial byproducts. 
    Prohibited items: Sewerage, industrial by-products, appliances (including but not limited to those utilizing Freon), batteries, chemicals, concrete and cinder blocks and bricks, construction and remodeling materials (including but not limited to lumber and plaster), explosives (including but not limited to rifle and pistol bullets, shotgun shells, and any other item containing gun powder or explosive material), furniture, pieces of glass exceeding six (6) inches in length or width (and which shall be itself safely contained), red garbage bags, tree trunks and/or limbs weighing more than thirty (30) pounds or more than sixty (60) inches in length (and any tree trunks and/or limbs of any size cut by any commercial service or arising from any commercial enterprise), roofing or shingles, metal items (other than ordinary household food containers), oil or other petroleum products, paint or paint cans, tires, furniture, or earth/dirt/soil. 
    Trash: Any horticultural products other than garbage or putrescible material. It shall include but not be limited to cuttings of grass and weeds, fallen leaves, branches, ashes, vines, cardboard boxes and containers, shrubbery trimmings and similar debris or other like materials not included under the definition of "garbage." 
    Additional prohibited items: Subject to review by the mayor, the department of public works shall have the authority to further define and determine allowable garbage and/or trash items, or to further prohibit and/or exclude certain types, kinds and/or sizes or quantities of items from being placed with garbage or trash, or to define the manner of its disposition, such as requiring certain types of items be individually bagged or otherwise secured (which shall be considered as prohibited items for all purposes of this article), including the ability to determine that certain items are not to be collected by the city or will only be collected for an additional charge for such collection if collection by the city is desired by the owner. 
    Owner: Use of the term "owner" shall include an owner, lessee, tenant, other occupant, or their agents, invitees or permittees. Any financial responsibility established in this article shall be borne by the person or entity in whose name the trash and/or garbage account is listed. If no account is established, any owner, lessee, tenant or other occupant of the parcel shall all be solidarity liable. 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07) 
Sec. 8-1012. - Accumulation; collection. 
(a)  (i)  Every owner of any public, commercial or private property or premise, including residential property, shall place all garbage in containers supplied by the city, except that this shall not apply to commercial establishments which have contracted with a garbage or trash disposal company other than the city. 
(ii)  Garbage and trash containers shall not be filled with dishwater or other liquid or semi-liquid kitchen wastes which are properly disposable down sanitary drains. The containers shall be kept at all times in a sanitary condition with the outside thereof clean and free from accumulative grease and decomposing material. The lid or cover must be closed on garbage containers at all times when not being filled. 
(iii)  Containers supplied by the city shall remain the property of the city and if damaged, destroyed or stolen through abuse, neglect or improper use of the owner shall be replaced by the city at the expense of the person or entity who is the responsible person on the account. Containers which are damaged in the course of normal and reasonable usage or which are damaged, destroyed or stolen through no abuse, neglect or improper use of the owner shall be repaired or replaced by the city at no charge. The container shall not be damaged, destroyed, defaced or removed from the premises by any person other than the city; markings and identification devices on the containers, except as placed or specifically permitted by the city, are expressly prohibited and shall be regarded as damage to the containers. 
(b)  Garbage and trash shall not be allowed to remain in any house or other building, cellar or other structure, or on any premises long enough to cause a health hazard or become a nuisance of any type or nature. 
(c)  Garbage for collection shall be placed in container(s) which are located a distance not to exceed one hundred fifty (150) feet from the street or dedicated alleyway which is utilized by the city as its usual route for garbage collection. All garbage must fit within the container with the lid closed. No garbage will be picked up by the city that is not properly contained within the garbage container. All garbage not placed within a container (whether supplied by the city or by a separate commercial establishment) may be subject to a separate charge, to be established from time-to-time by the mayor as am amount that will reimburse the city for the expense of being required to manually retrieve such items, such charge to be not less than five dollars ($5.00) per pickup and not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) per pickup. In addition, all garbage not contained securely within closed and sealed plastic bags or sealed cartons, neatly stacked, shall in addition be declared to be "litter" for all purposes of this Code, and the person or entity in whose name the account is held shall be subject to the fines and penalties otherwise provided by this Code in addition to the administrative fee provided for the retrieval of the items above. 
(d)  All trash collected from residences such as pine straw or leaves, shall be separated from tree limbs or other bulky material, and stacked as near to the curbline as possible, and must be secured (bagged or other method, as appropriate) to insure it is not scattered by wind, animals, or other cause. All limbs, stumps and other bulky material must be stacked conveniently in such a manner that one person can handle and load it. No trash of any type may be placed in an open drainage ditch or otherwise placed in a manner to impede drainage at that or any other location. 
(e)  Earth, trees, wallpaper, roofing material, plaster, concrete, paint buckets, lumber, or other substances that may accumulate as a result of repairs to land or buildings or as a result of initial clearing of lots, or as a result of building operations, as well as any types of old discarded furniture, appliances, discarded toys, bicycles and wagons shall not be considered as trash and will not be picked up by the city, but the proper disposal thereof shall be the responsibility of the owner. However, upon approval by the mayor, the department of public works may establish a program to retrieve items not otherwise collectable by the city upon payment of a fee to be established and which is reasonably appropriate to offset the overall cost of that collection by city. 
(f)  No person shall throw or deposit or allow to fall upon any walkway, street, thoroughfare or private property any dead cats, dogs, chickens, rats or other animals, tainted meat, decayed or decaying fruits or vegetables, human or other excrement, or any garbage or trash of any nature and kind whatsoever. 
(g)  With regard to new construction and repairs to buildings, ditches must be kept open and free from trash and debris at all times and pipe laid in ditches before construction starts. Any ditches stopped up by a contractor or other person undertaking the construction or repair shall be cleaned out by the city and billed to the property owner. If the bill is not paid within forty-eight (48) hours after the property owner is notified in writing, all services furnished by the city to the property owner will be discontinued and disconnected until so paid. 
(h)  All owners of any building, house, structure or grounds shall be held strictly responsible for the cleanliness of their premises and property and of alleys and neutral ground immediately adjacent thereto; and all business owners and managers of stores, restaurants, markets, stands or other commercial establishments shall be responsible for keeping the sidewalks in front of their business buildings or structures so occupied by them in a clean condition. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, blow or otherwise cause any grass clippings, paper, trash, dirt, garbage or other material to be placed into the streets, sidewalks, ditches, or the culverts, grates, drains or other components of the city's stormwater drainage system of the city, or in or on other public ways. 
(j)  Except as provided by section 4-2032, it shall be unlawful for any person to burn any paper, grass, leaves, limbs, trash, debris, garbage or other substance or material within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07; Ord. No. 4222, § 1, 10-14-14; Ord. No. 4520, § 2, 4-10-18) 
Sec. 8-1013. - Commercial accounts. 
(a)  Any business or commercial pickup which generates an accumulation of garbage and/or trash between collections which exceeds the three (3) non-metal containers furnished by city will be required to utilize solid-weld metal body containers provided by the city, or by the private contractor who shall service the container(s). Each business must provide ample parking space whereby the loading truck can easily gain access to the container. No business will be served either by the city or by private contractors which generates more than the hereinabove stated amounts of garbage and/or trash without use of the specified container. Any public and/or private contractor who services a business without the specified container shall be held in violation along with the business served. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to place any metal or wood or other object, including but not limited to furniture, appliances or equipment that cannot be easily compressed or crushed by city equipment, into any container supplied by the city for disposal. In addition, if an improper item is placed into a container and damages the collection vehicle, the cost of repair or replacement shall be charged to the account holder for the premises unless established by the account holder that it was placed in the container by an unauthorized and unaffiliated person. 
(c)  City shall have the right to determine the number and type of containers to be utilized by a commercial account which is serviced by the city, and to determine the frequency of pickup required by that account. City shall further have the right to decline to provide service to any commercial location based upon any cause city determines to be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07) 
Sec. 8-1014. - Equipment. 
    All vehicles used for the purpose of transporting garbage within the city must have a completely enclosed, packer type body, and be kept in a sanitary condition. All commercial containers used for the purpose of containing garbage must be of a solid-weld metal body, equipped with lids, with the lids kept closed. All items intended to be disposed of shall be kept and held within a container. All containers must be kept in a sanitary condition, and it shall be the responsibility of the owner to see that this is done on a regular basis. Any container found to be leaking refuse will be repaired or replaced immediately by the responsible person. 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07) 
Sec. 8-1015. - Collection charges. 
    The monthly charge for garbage service for customers using containers furnished by the city shall be as follows: 
(a)  Residential accounts: Sixteen dollars and fifty cents ($16.50) per month, with the container to be furnished by the city; if additional containers are needed for a residence, those containers will be supplied by the city, with additional collection charges at the rate of thirteen dollars and sixty cents ($13.60) per month per additional container. 
(b)  Commercial accounts: Twenty dollars and ten cents ($20.10) per month per container; if the need of the commercial premises exceeds four (4) containers, then the owner, lessee, or their agents or occupants must instead utilize an independent collection service for their garbage service. 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07; Ord. No. 3745, § 1, 6-10-08; Ord. No. 3746, § 1, 6-10-08; Ord. No. 4536, § 1, 5-8-18; Ord. No. 4653, § 1, 3-12-19) 
Sec. 8-1015.1. - Payment of bills; late penalties. 
    The provisions of section 7-1020 shall govern the payment of bills and late penalties. 
(Ord. No. 3972, § 1, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 8-1016. - Unlawful use of the container of another. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of garbage or trash in any container which belongs to or has been provided to another, whether with or without the permission of that other person. 
(b)  The existence of garbage or trash in a container belonging to or provided to another shall, without more, give rise to the presumption that such garbage or trash was placed in such container with the knowledge and consent, or at the direction of the person to whom such garbage or trash previously belonged. 
(c)  Upon first conviction, the offender shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Upon a second or any subsequent conviction for a violation occurring within five (5) years of the first violation, the offender shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07) 
Sec. 8-1017. - Unlawful utilization and maintenance of containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place any prohibited items in any garbage container or sanitation can provided by the city, or to place any prohibited items curb-side for city trash pickup. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person receiving garbage service from the city to fail to comply with the provisions of this article, or with all rules and regulations from time-to-time established by the department of public works of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07) 
Sec. 8-1018. - Use and maintenance of containers. 
(a)  Other than those who are handicapped or are otherwise physically limited and who have notified and established such limitations to the department of public works, shall return the garbage container servicing their residence or business to its usual location within twenty-four (24) hours of the time the garbage has been emptied by the city. Any person who fails to do so on repeated occasions shall be warned in writing of their failure and, upon their next failure to replace that container within the prescribed time limit, shall be subject to an administrative fee of five dollars ($5.00) for the cost of a city employee returning that container to its proper location, and for each time thereafter, until no such occasion shall occur within a period of twelve (12) months (at which time all such persons shall be entitled to be again notified prior to the fee being imposed). 
(b)  All persons, other than those who are handicapped or are otherwise physically limited and who have notified and established such limitations to the department of public works, shall maintain their garbage container in a reasonably clean and sanitary state, and free from accumulated food wastes or other residue that produces odors, attracts vermin, breeds insects, creates a nuisance or unsanitary conditions. Any person who continues to fail to do so shall be warned in writing of their failure and, upon their next failure to clean such garbage container within three (3) days following such notice, shall be subject to an administrative fee of five dollars ($5.00) for the cost of a city employee cleaning that container. 
(c)  Any administrative charge under subsections (c) and (d) above, or any charge for any garbage container which is damaged, destroyed or stolen through abuse, neglect or improper use of the owner, lessee, their agents or occupants shall be added to the utility bill of the premises serviced and shall thereafter be an indivisible part of that bill for all purposes thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 3676, § 1, 7-10-07) 
Sec. 8-1019. - Authorization for code enforcement officers. 
    The mayor is authorized to designate one or more code enforcement officers of the city to enforce the provisions of this Article B, including the ability to issue citations and to otherwise initiate action for civil and criminal violations of these provisions, and to utilize the abatement provisions of section 8-2001, et seq., as are applicable to this Article B. 
(Ord. No. 3683, § 1, 8-14-07) 
Chapter 2 - NUISANCES TO THE PUBLIC[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 2367, adopted Sept. 11, 1990, amended Ch. 2 to read as set out in Arts. A-C. Prior to amendment, Ch. 2 contained §§ 8-2001-8-2006, which pertained to grass and weeds and derived from Code 1976, §§ 8-2001-8-2005, Ord. No. 2093, § 17, adopted Mar. 12, 1985; and Res. No. 168, adopted July 12, 1983. 
Charter reference- Utilities and maintenance department, §§ 403, 409. 
Cross reference- Refuse collection and disposal, Part 8, Ch. 1. 
State Law reference- Weed cutting, R.S. 33:5062. 

ARTICLE A. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 8-2001. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to prevent accumulations of noxious materials or other health and safety hazards so as to protect the safety and general welfare of the public, and to provide for the prompt abatement of violations. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2002. - Abatement procedures in general. 
    In the event any person shall fail or neglect to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the city is authorized and empowered to cause the violation to be corrected and to assess all the charges and expenses incurred by the city for abatement and corrective actions against the person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2003. - Abatement notice. 
(a)  If the city undertakes abatement action, the owner of the property where the violation occurs shall be notified of the city's intent to abate and shall be given no less than five (5) days after the date of notice to voluntarily abate the violation. The city may serve notice on the owner by registered or certified mail (which shall be considered as received by the owner three (3) business days after mailing), through personal delivery by an employee of the city, or as otherwise allowed by law. Notice shall be given at the address reflected on the tax rolls of the city. 
(b)  Notice may also be given by advertising for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official journal of the city for violations of section 8-2012. 
(c)  The city may extend the time limit for compliance or voluntary abatement through the execution of an abatement contract, signed and duly executed, which specifies the actions to be taken and the time limit allowed. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3499, § 1, 9-13-05) 
Sec. 8-2004. - City to specify conditions. 
    The notice of the city's intent to abate a violation shall identify the nature and location of the violation, description of the property containing the nuisance, the owner thereof and the length of time allowed for voluntary correction. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2005. - Abatement charges. 
(a)  All charges, costs and expenses for abatement or correction of the violations incurred by the city shall be assessed to the person responsible; and, if the person refuses to reimburse the city's costs, the amount thereof may be collected through civil proceedings directed against such person. 
(b)  In the case of abated noxious weeds regulated in Article B of this chapter, if after cutting, destruction, or removal by the city, the cost or expense thereof has not been paid within ten (10) days, the tax collector of the city shall furnish the owner, as shown on the last assessment roll, by registered mail, a written statement showing the cost or expense incurred for the work, and the place or property on which the work was done. If the statement is not paid within one month thereafter, the amount thereof shall be included in and form part of the taxes due by the owner of said property and, when collected, shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(c)  Charges for abatement of junk and debris as regulated in Article C of this chapter, may not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00); and, if unpaid after thirty (30) days, the amount thereof shall constitute a special lien collectable in the same manner as special assessments are collectable by law. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2006. - Criminal penalties not precluded; certain fines. 
(a)  Abatement actions taken by the city under this chapter shall not preclude the imposition of criminal penalties as otherwise provided by law. 
(b)  Any fines collected for violations of section 8-2031 shall be used to further the abatement of litter according to Louisiana Revised Statutes 25:1112, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 2368, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2007. - Emergency abatement. 
    Whenever the appropriate municipal official determines that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, he may, without prior notice, issue an order that such emergency exists, requiring that such action be taken as deemed necessary to meet the emergency and such order shall be effective immediately. Failure of the responsible party to immediately abate violations of this section shall be unlawful and subject to the remedies and penalties of this chapter; and the city, without further notice, may institute action to relieve the public of any threat. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2008. - Applicability to Part 8, Chapter 1, Article B. 
    The provisions of this Article A shall also apply to actions which are prohibited by the provisions of Chapter 1, Article B, except that instead of the five (5) day prior notice which is required by Section 8-2003(a), notice prior to abatement of violations under Chapter 1, Article B shall require only no less than thirty-six (36) hour notice if notice is personally delivered to the owner of the premises, or to any occupant or employee at the premises of suitable age and understanding, or otherwise to the violator. 
(Ord. No. 3684, § 1, 8-14-07) 
Secs. 8-2009-8-2010. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - NOXIOUS WEEDS AND GROWTH 

Sec. 8-2011. - Noxious weeds declared nuisance. 
    Growths of weeds and other deleterious vegetation in the city as defined in this article are hereby declared a nuisance and shall be removed by the owner as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3499, § 2, 9-13-05) 
Sec. 8-2012. - Height and character. 
(a)  No owner of property in the city shall permit any grass or weeds or other deleterious, unhealthful, or noxious growths to grow or remain on such property, or on any sidewalk or banquette contiguous to such property, in excess of ten (10) inches in height, to emit unpleasant or obnoxious odors or pollen, or to conceal any filthy deposit. 
(b)  No owner of property in the city shall permit any weeds or other deleterious vegetation to encroach into public areas adjacent to their property such as sidewalks and banquettes which interfere with public access or passage, restrict the clear view of vehicle operators, or inhibit storm water drainage. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3499, § 3, 9-13-05) 
Sec. 8-2013. - Owners' responsibilities. 
    Owners' responsibilities are not abridged by the occupancy of others or nonoccupancy on the property. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2014. - Annualized growth abatement bidding. 
    The appropriate city official shall have the authority to advertise for and award bids on an annualized basis to have noxious growths abated. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2015. - Weeds abatement, procedures for multiple cutting. 
(a)  The city may undertake the cutting, destruction, or removal of noxious weeds or grass or other deleterious, unhealthful, or noxious growths on a monthly basis without the notice required in sections 8-2003 and 8-2004 if: 
(1)  The property owner liable has been notified pursuant to such sections at any time during the immediately preceding twelve (12) months, and 
(2)  The owner has failed to do the work after opportunity to do so. 
(b)  Prior to undertaking such work, the city shall file and record at West Monroe City Hall, an affidavit, signed by the mayor, such affidavit shall include the following: 
(1)  A description of the property sufficient to identify it; 
(2)  A photograph of the property to reasonably identify its unsafe and unsanitary condition and to justify the necessity for cutting, destroying, or removing weeds, grass, or other noxious growths; and 
(3)  A statement that the property owner liable has within the immediately preceding twelve (12) months failed to do such work after notification and opportunity to do so pursuant to sections 8-2003 and 8-2004. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3499, § 4, 9-13-05) 
Secs. 8-2016-8-2020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - JUNK, DEBRIS AND LIQUID WASTES 

Sec. 8-2021. - Junk and debris prohibited. 
(a)  No owner or occupant of property in the city shall permit the abandoning or storage of all junk items, including discarded or abandoned major appliances, such as refrigerators, freezers or ranges; all furniture not intended for outdoor use, and other furniture not now capable of reasonable usage in the manner originally intended; or machinery (including, but not limited to, lawn mowers of all types, tractors, motor vehicles not licensed for on-road use, and bicycles); or dilapidated and/or unsafe fencing, or fencing which contributes in any way to another violation of this chapter; or other metal, tin or other discarded items or yard debris on their premises which is perceptible from beyond the property. The term "junk items" shall include boats and accessories; boat, utility or other trailers; travel trailers and mobile homes; and similar items which, although titled or registered with the State of Louisiana, are not motor vehicles. The term "yard debris" shall include fallen trees or limbs, unless cut and neatly stacked for use as firewood, as well as accumulations of grasses, weeds, branches, limbs and other vegetable matter, whether alone or mixed with other items. All such accumulations described above are hereby declared a nuisance and shall be removed by the owner of the property. "Dilapidated" shall, as respect to fencing, include use of an apparent accumulation of materials not originally intended for the purpose for which they are used. 
(b)  As an alternative to removal, complete enclosure of such materials or items in buildings or within solid fences which totally obscure them from view are required, and such fences cannot be constructed of dilapidated material, and must be maintained in good repair. 
(c)  Factors which may indicate that a junk item is a nuisance include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The junk item is partially dismantled, partially disassembled or wrecked, or lacks major mechanical or structural parts; 
(2)  The junk item is not now capable of reasonable usage in the manner in which it was originally intended; 
(3)  Based upon the records of the city or from the condition of the junk item it is readily apparent that it is and has remained inoperable and/or unused for a period in excess of ninety (90) days; 
(4)  The junk item is inoperable, and no significant on-going efforts have been undertaken with regard to restoring it to reasonable operability within the last sixty (60) days; 
(5)  The junk item is located in an area of a growth of weeds, grass or other noxious vegetation over six (6) inches in height; 
(6)  The location or condition of the junk item makes it a possible breeding ground or harbor for mosquitos, other insects, rats, snakes or other vermin; 
(7)  The junk item is a point of collection for pools or ponds of water; 
(8)  The junk item is point of collection of garbage, food waste, animal waste or other putrescent matter, or of trash, junk or similar collection of items, alone or in the aggregate; 
(9)  The junk item has sharp or jagged parts, or has sharp or otherwise dangerous edges or points of metal, plastic or glass; 
(10)  The junk item has areas of confinement which cannot be operated from the interior of those areas; 
(11)  The junk item has been utilized by minors for recreational activities within the pervious sixty (60) days; 
(12)  The junk item is situated or located haphazardly, or is in danger of falling or turning over; 
(13)  The junk item has an accumulation of factors that make it a health or safety hazard; and 
(14)  There exists other factors which would cause a reasonable person to believe that the item is not capable of being safely and/or legally used in its intended manner. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3489, § 1, 8-9-05; Ord. No. 4411, § 1, 9-13-16) 
Sec. 8-2022. - Vermin. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 8-2021, no owner or occupant of property in the city shall permit the accumulation of items or materials on their property, which (either visible or obscured) forms an acceptable habitat or breeding area for mosquitos and other insects, rodents, snakes, or other vermin. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3489, § 2, 8-9-05) 
Sec. 8-2023. - Abandoned motor vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle is found to be abandoned, a notice shall be posted on the windshield of the vehicle directing that the vehicle is to be removed from that location within forty-eight (48) hours, not to include weekends or legal holidays, and shall direct that the failure to remove the vehicle may result in the vehicle being removed by the city, or by a tow truck operator on behalf of the city. 
(b)  If the abandoned motor vehicle is not removed within forty-eight (48) hours, not to include weekends or legal holidays, from date of posting notice, the motor vehicle may be removed and disposed of by a tow truck operator on behalf of the city, with all costs of towing and storage to be collected from the owner or lienholder retrieving the vehicle, or from the sale or disposition of the vehicle, as otherwise provided by law. 
(c)  "Abandoned", for the purposes of this section, shall mean a motor vehicle that is left unattended on public property for more than three (3) days, or is left unattended on the shoulder or right-of-way of an interstate or a four-lane highway for more than three (3) days, or a motor vehicle that has remained illegally on public property for a period of more than three (3) days, or a motor vehicle that has remained on private property without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property for more than three (3) days. 
(d)  In addition to the notification to be placed upon the windshield of the motor vehicle, as provided above, notice shall also be provided to the registered owner of the motor vehicle and any registered lienholders (if such owner and/or lienholders can be reasonably determined) by US mail, certified or registered mail, at the address reflected by the records of the Louisiana Department of Motor Vehicles. 
(e)  This provision shall not limit the authority granted in section 8-2024 nor the authority granted in section 9-1006, et seq., nor otherwise limit the ability of the city to proceed under the authority of any other provision of this Code, or of Louisiana law. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3413, § 1, 6-8-04) 
Sec. 8-2024. - Nuisance motor vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any nuisance motor vehicle is found, a notice shall be posted on the windshield of the vehicle directing that the vehicle is to be removed within five (5) days, not to include weekends or legal holidays, and shall direct that the failure to remove the vehicle may result in the vehicle being removed by the city, or by a tow truck operator on behalf of the city. 
(b)  If the nuisance motor vehicle is not removed within five (5) days, not to include weekends or legal holidays, from date of posting notice, the motor vehicle may be removed and disposed of by a tow truck operator on behalf of the city, with all costs of towing and storage to be collected from the owner or lienholder retrieving the vehicle, or from the sale or disposition of the vehicle, as otherwise provided by law. 
(c)  A "nuisance motor vehicle", for the purposes of this section, shall mean and include a motor vehicle where any one or more of the following factors are present and which, in the aggregate, evidence that the motor vehicle is not being used and maintained as an operating motor vehicle and the condition of the motor vehicle and/or the surrounding area does not indicate that active on-going efforts are underway to return the motor vehicle to operating condition within the immediate future. The factors which may indicate that a motor vehicle is a nuisance motor vehicle include the following: 
(1)  The motor vehicle is partially dismantled, partially disassembled or wrecked, or lacks major mechanical or body parts; 
(2)  The motor vehicle is not capable of movement under its own power in the manner in which it was originally intended, or is otherwise inoperable for use as a motor vehicle; 
(3)  Based upon the records of the city or from the condition of the motor vehicle it is readily apparent that it is and has remained inoperable for a period in excess of thirty (30) days; 
(4)  The motor vehicle is inoperable, and no significant on-going efforts have been undertaken with regard to restoring it to reasonable operability within the last thirty (30) days; 
(5)  The motor vehicle has one or more tires missing or not reasonably inflated to the extent they are useable, or has one or more broken or severely cracked windows; 
(6)  That the motor vehicle does not have a current license plate, registration, motor vehicle inspection sticker and/or is not currently insured to the extent required under R.S. 32:861 shall all be factors tending to evidence that the motor vehicle is not currently operable in a legal manner and is not intended to be operating in a legal manner within the immediate future; 
(7)  The motor vehicle is located in an area of a growth of weeds, grass or other noxious vegetation over six (6) inches in height; 
(8)  The location or condition of the motor vehicle makes it a possible breeding ground or harbor for mosquitos, other insects, rats, snakes or other vermin; 
(9)  The motor vehicle is a point of collection for pools or ponds of water; 
(10)  The motor vehicle is a point of concentration of quantities of gas or oil or other flammable or explosive materials; 
(11)  The motor vehicle is point of collection of garbage, food waste, animal waste or other putrescent matter, or of trash, junk or similar collection of items, alone or in the aggregate; 
(12)  The motor vehicle has sharp or jagged parts, or has sharp or otherwise dangerous edges or points of metal, plastic or glass; 
(13)  The motor vehicle has areas of confinement which cannot be operated from the interior of those areas; 
(14)  The motor vehicle has been utilized by minors for recreational activities within the previous sixty (60) days; 
(15)  The motor vehicle is situated or located haphazardly, or is in danger of falling or turning over; and 
(16)  The motor vehicle has an accumulation of factors that make it a health or safety hazard. 
(d)  In addition to the notification to be placed upon the windshield of the motor vehicle, as provided above, notice shall also be provided to the registered owner of the motor vehicle and any registered lienholders (if such owner and/or lienholders can be reasonably determined) by U.S. mail, certified or registered mail, at the address reflected by the records of the Louisiana Department of Motor Vehicles. 
(e)  This provision shall not apply to any motor vehicle: 
(1)  Which is stored in such a manner that it is not visible from a street, or from any other public or private property (whether or not that property adjoins the property on which the motor vehicle is located); 
(2)  Is stored in a neat and orderly manner and in a location such that, as to essentially all outward appearance, the motor vehicle appears to be an operating motor vehicle, and which motor vehicle does not otherwise appear to constitute a hazard to health and safety, directly or indirectly; or 
(3)  Is lawfully located on the business premises of a commercial establishment, operating within an appropriate zoning district, and properly licensed and operated as a commercial enterprise, one of the primary purposes of which enterprise is the repair, maintenance or restoration of motor vehicles, and the vehicle has not been located or otherwise upon such property for a period in excess of six (6) months. 
(f)  Any registered owner or registered lienholder of a motor vehicle shall have the right the appeal an order of removal for the longer of: 
(1)  A period of seven (7) days from posting of the order of removal on the windshield; or 
(2)  Any period prior to actual removal of the motor vehicle. 
An appeal is initiated by filing a written objection to the removal with the Police Chief of the City of West Monroe, or his designee, by completing an appeal form (to be available from the chief of police), and depositing the cash amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), which amount shall be applied toward the cost of towing should the appeal ultimately be rejected. Should the owner or lienholder wish to further appeal the decision of the chief of police, or his designee, written notice shall be provided to the office of the city attorney within five (5) days of the decision of the chief of police on appeal, and such appeal shall be heard by the board of aldermen at their next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(g)  This provision shall not limit the authority granted in section 8-2021, the authority granted in section 8-2023, nor the authority granted in section 9-1006, et seq., nor otherwise limit the ability of the city to proceed under the authority of any other provision of this Code, or of Louisiana law. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3413, § 2, 6-8-04) 
Sec. 8-2025. - Dumping; responsibility. 
(a)  No person shall dump, deposit, or leave garbage, trash, junk, litter or other deposits on the property of another without the consent of the owner, leasee, or other person lawfully in possession of such property. 
(b)  Where the offender is not known, the owner of the property containing the deposited debris shall be held responsible for abatement and correction. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2026. - Chemical and liquid waste. 
(a)  No owner or occupant of property in the city shall allow the accumulation of water, sewage, petroleum, or other liquid wastes which may serve as breeding areas for insects or animals, exude obnoxious odors, or otherwise may threaten or impair the public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  Discharge of oil and other petroleum products or chemicals and chemical compounds of any kind, nature or description into the open ditches or sewer lines of the city or onto the property of another is prohibited. 
(c)  Each owner shall make adequate provision for the prompt discharge of stormwater directly into the city's storm drainage system. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 3, 9-11-90) 
Secs. 8-2027-8-2030. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - LITTER 

Sec. 8-2031. - Litter prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall: 
(i)  Throw, drop, deposit, discard or otherwise dispose of litter, trash, refuse or garbage; 
(ii)  Permit any person to throw, drop, deposit, discard or otherwise dispose of litter, trash, refuse or garbage; or 
(iii)  Create a condition that they know or should have known would likely result in the deposit, discard or other disposal of litter, trash, refuse or garbage upon any public or private place except in proper receptacles intended for that purpose, or in a manner otherwise authorized by this chapter. 
(b)  Operators of businesses where gatherings of people result in accumulations or scattering of litter beyond their business premises onto any street, sidewalk, or other public right-of-way shall be responsible for its collection. 
(c)  For purposes of this chapter, in addition to the definitions contained in section 8-1011, the following definitions shall apply: 
Litter is garbage, refuse, and rubbish, as defined herein, and all other waste materials which, if thrown or deposited as herein provided, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. Litter is also any used or unconsumed substance or waste material which has been discarded, whether made of aluminum, glass, plastic, rubber, paper, or other natural or synthetic material, or any combination thereof, including, but not limited to, any bottle, jar or can, or any top, cap or detachable tab of any bottle, jar or can, any cigarette or cigar or portion thereof (including the butt or other remainder after use). 
Refuse is all solid wastes liable to decay, spoil or become putrid or solid wastes no liable to decay, spoil or become putrid, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
Rubbish is all solid wastes not liable to decay, spoil or become putrid, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, accumulations of leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, property and similar materials. 
(d)  The abatement provisions of article A of part 2 and/or part 4 of this chapter shall be applicable to this section. A violation of this section, with or without abatement by virtue of those provisions, shall be supplementary to the crime established in section 11-4019. 
(Ord. No. 2368, § 1, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 8-14-07; Ord. No. 4412, § 1, 9-13-16) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 3682 provided for an effective date of August 15, 2007. 
Sec. 8-2032. - Litter receptacles-Placement requirements. 
(a)  Any owner or person in control of any property which is held out to the public as a place for parking consisting of fifteen (15) or more parking spaces shall be responsible for the procurement, placement, and maintenance of litter receptacles according to the following: 
(1)  Parks, recreation areas, campgrounds, and transient vehicle parks-One at each restroom, concession stand, picnic pavilion, and trailhead; 
(2)  Retail stores, shopping centers, and theaters-One for the first fifteen (15) parking spaces, plus one for every fifty (50) additional parking spaces; 
(3)  Gasoline service stations-One per pump island with a minimum of one on each side of the station where pumps are located; 
(4)  Restaurants, drive-ins, fast-food outlets, taverns and convenience stores-One per establishment; 
(5)  Marinas or piers-One per pier, plus one additional for each fifteen (15) boat slips; 
(6)  Festivals and other outdoor events-One for each special restroom, one every two hundred (200) feet of walking area, one for each special parking area of one hundred fifty (150) spaces, and one at each food service area; 
(7)  Construction sites-Contractors engaged in new construction or substantial rehabilitation of buildings or other large scale public works projects shall provide at least one litter receptacle at the construction site with additional receptacles as needed to prevent scattering of litter by workers. 
(b)  Parking facilities utilized on a shared basis by more than one business, person, group or institution consisting of thirty (30) or more parking spaces shall be provided with receptacles by those entities on a shared basis, with responsibility falling jointly upon them regardless of proximity. 
(Ord. No. 2368, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2033. - Same-Design standards. 
    Litter receptacles procured and placed in public places as required by this article shall meet the following minimum standards: 
(1)  General specifications. 
a.  The body of each litter receptacle shall be constructed of a minimum of twenty-four-gauge metal or other material of equivalent strength, that will withstand wear and tear and reasonably resist corrosion and acts of vandalism. 
b.  Receptacles should be constructed, covered, or used in such a manner as to prevent or preclude the blowing of litter from the receptacle. 
c.  Openings in covered litter receptacles shall be readily identifiable and readily accessible for the deposit of litter. 
d.  Construction and general configuration of litter receptacles shall be in conformance with all pertinent laws, ordinances, resolutions or regulations pertaining to fire, safety, public health, or welfare. 
e.  Litter receptacles shall have a fifteen-liquid-gallon capacity. 
(2)  Color and marking. 
a.  The entire outer surface of each litter receptacle shall be white, navy blue, dark brown, or tan, if painted, however, if construction consists of aggregate concrete or wood, its natural color is acceptable. 
b.  Each litter receptacle may bear the official Louisiana antilitter logo as described in section 8-2034. 
c.  When the official state logo is used, no commercial advertisement shall be placed on any litter receptacle within eight (8) inches of the official logo; and any such advertising may not exceed the logo in area. The owner of the receptacle may place a single line on the receptacle identifying ownership, and a single credit line designating any donor of the litter receptacle other than the owner. That lettering may not exceed one-half (1/2) inch in height and may not interfere with or distract from the prominence of the antilitter symbol. 
(3)  Maintenance. 
a.  Compliance with these minimum standards shall include disposal of waste matter deposited, proper upkeep, maintenance and repair of litter receptacles sufficient to permit such receptacles to serve the functions for which they were designed and to prevent the appearance of such receptacles from becoming unsightly. Inadequately maintained or unsightly litter receptacles shall be a violation of these minimum standards. 
b.  Whenever litter receptacles are placed in any public place other than where required by these rules and regulations, such receptacles shall conform to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2368, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2034. - Antilitter symbol. 
(a)  All outdoor or public area litter receptacles so placed as to meet or exceed the provisions of this article may bear the official state antilitter symbol as prescribed by the Louisiana Litter Control and Recycling Commission under authority of LRS 25:1115D, such logo being available at no charge to the receptacle owner from the state. 
(b)  The symbol shall be colored medium blue, bright gold, and white. When emblazoned, it shall be twelve (12) inches high by ten (10) inches wide for side mounting and five (5) inches high by four (4) inches wide for top mounting. It shall be permanently painted onto the receptacle or applied as a heat activated decal designed for exterior use. 
(c)  Litter receptacles shall not be used in lieu of normal collections of refuse as required in Chapter 1 of this part. 
(Ord. No. 2368, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2035. - Conformity of older receptacles. 
    All litter receptacles in use in public places governed by this article prior to the passage of this article shall be modified or replaced so as to fully conform to the requirements herein within one year after passage of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2368, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2036. - Posters and temporary signs. 
(a)  It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to drive any nails or tacks into utility poles, trees, fences, sign columns, or building walls without the prior permission of the owner. 
(b)  Campaign posters and other temporary notices or signs placed on rights-of-way, streets, alleys, servitudes, or other public property, whether freestanding or attached to existing structures, shall be considered litter. 
(Ord. No. 2368, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-2037. - Adopt-a-Spot program. 
    The mayor, or his designee, is authorized to establish, administer and promote an "Adopt-a-Spot" program whereby businesses and civic organizations agree to maintain certain designated city streets, intersections or designated locations in the city by removing litter, cutting weeds or similar activity for a designated time and under certain standards of participation, to provide for limitations on and/or waiver of liability in favor of the city, its employees, agencies and contractors, and otherwise providing for the establishment, operation and promotion of such voluntary program. 
(Ord. No. 3018, § 1, 6-8-99) 
Chapter 3 - ANIMALS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Parks, recreation and cultural affairs, Part 6; health and sanitation, Part 8; motor vehicles and traffic, Part 10; cruelty to animals, § 11-5011. 
State Law reference- Animals generally, R.S. Title 3; dogs, regulation by local authorities, R.S. 3:2731 et seq.; dog license tax, R.S. 3:2771 et seq.; rabies control, R.S. 40:1275 et seq.; seizure of dogs running at large, R.S. 3:2773. 

ARTICLE A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-3001. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Animal: Any living creature, domestic or wild. 
    Cat: Any cat, whether male, female or altered. 
    Dog: Any dog, and any member of the canine family or species, whether male, female or altered. 
    Officer: Any health officer, police officer or a duly authorized representative thereof. 
    Owner: Any person, having a right of property in an animal, or who keeps in his care or harbors an animal, or who acts as its custodian, or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises. 
    Running at large: Any animal not on the premises of the owner or other authorized person, or not accompanied by and under the control of a responsible person. 
    Vaccination against rabies: The injection, subcutaneously or otherwise by a licensed veterinarian or a person under his supervision, of animal anti-rabies vaccine, as approved by the health officer. 
    Vaccination certificate: A serially numbered certificate, on a form approved by the health officer, countersigned by the veterinarian or person administering the vaccination, giving the name of the owner and a description of the vaccinated dog, indicating the year for which issued, certifying that the dog was inoculated or vaccinated against rabies, and giving the date thereof. 
    Vaccination tag: A suitable tag, approved by the health officer, bearing the same number as the vaccination certificate, and indicating the year for which issued. 
    Veterinarian: Any person licensed by the state board of veterinary medicine examiners to practice veterinary medicine in the state. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3001) 
State Law reference- Veterinarians, R.S. 37:1511 et seq.; approval of anti-rabies vaccine by state department of health and human resources, R.S. 40:1276. 
Sec. 8-3002. - Officers to exercise care. 
    Every officer shall exercise every reasonable care to prevent the injury, illness, death, escape or pilfering of any animal with which he deals in carrying out the provisions of this chapter, but he shall not be responsible for any such occurrence. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3002) 
Sec. 8-3003. - Officers to enforce provisions. 
    Any health officer or his representative, or any code enforcement officer, animal control officer or police officer shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3003; Ord. No. 3836, § 1, 7-14-09) 
Sec. 8-3004. - Animals running at large; impoundment. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner of any animal or any other person having charge of the animal to permit the animal to remain or run at large: (i) On the public streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public places within the city limits, or (ii) on property belonging to anyone other than owner or other person having charge of the animal. No person shall hitch any animal to any object in such a manner that the animal is free to go across or on: (i) The streets, sidewalks, alleys or any other public place within the city limits, or (ii) on property belonging to anyone other than owner or other person having charge of the animal. It shall be an affirmative defense that the owner or other person having charge of the animal had the approval, permission, or consent of: (i) The owner of the property, or (ii) as respects property on which is located only a one-family or two-family residence, a lawful resident of that property. This affirmative defense must be timely asserted by the person charged with the violation, who shall have the burden of proof to establish such approval, permission, or consent. 
(b)  When any animal is found to be running at large within the city limits, it shall be the duty of the police to impound the animal. 
(c)  Any policeman impounding any animals shall advertise the fact by posting notices at three (3) different places within the city. The notices shall describe the animal or animals impounded by their sex, color and natural and artificial marks. If, within two (2) days after notices have been posted, no person claims the animals, the policeman, after ten (10) days' notice of sale, which notice shall be given by posting it on the front door of the city hall with the description of the animal to be sold, the time when the animal was impounded and the terms of the sale, shall sell every animal so impounded, at the principal front door of the city hall, to the highest bidder. At any time before the sale the owner may reclaim and recover his property by proving ownership and paying all costs and charges. 
(d)  In cases having to do with a violation of this section or section 8-3021, the charges, fees and cost are fixed as follows or as may hereafter be changed by ordinance or resolution: 
(1)  The impoundment of an animal on the first occasion shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
(2)  In the event the animal has been impounded under this chapter once previously, the charges for impounding the animal shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(3)  In the event the animal has been impounded under this chapter twice previously, the charges for impounding the animal on the third occasion and on each subsequent impoundment shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) on each occasion. 
(4)  For feeding and watering any animal impounded under the provisions of this chapter the charge of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per day shall be made. 
(5)  The owner shall further pay to the city, all expenses incurred by the city in preparation for the sale referred to herein. 
(e)  All collected costs of impounding the animals shall be paid into the general fund of the city, and the police department shall make a written report to the clerk of the facts, and shall specify all costs and charges with the amount for which the animal or animals were sold. Any excess over costs and charges may be drawn from the treasury of the city by the owner of the property sold upon warrant of the mayor. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any cow, horse, mule, goat, sheep or hog, or to cause any animals to be driven from outside the city limits into the city limits, for the purpose of impounding or causing to be impounded any of the animals, or for any person to wantonly or maliciously open any yard, stable or enclosure for the purpose of setting free the animals therein. 
(Code 1976, §§ 8-3004, 8-3021; Ord. No. 1982, § 1, 7-12-83; Ord. No. 4582, § 1, 9-11-18) 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of livestock running at large, R.S. 3:2531 et seq. 
Sec. 8-3005. - Prohibition against attracting non-owned, wild or feral animals; recovery of costs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to provide food outdoors or otherwise undertake any action or activity which would tend to attract non-owned, wild or feral animals (excluding squirrels and birds other than pigeons), whether or not those animals are commonly considered as domestic animals. For purposes of this section, non-owned means any domestic cat or dog whose individual owner is not known. Violators of this provision shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense or incarcerated for not more than ten (10) days, or both. 
(b)  In addition to but separate from the criminal penalty provided above, should the city determine that any person has provided food outdoors or otherwise undertaken any action or activity which tends to attract non-owned, wild or feral animals (excluding squirrels and birds other than pigeons), whether or not commonly considered as domestic, to an extent that the city determines it must undertake remediation efforts in order to remove and/or relocate the offending animals, then city shall be entitled to recover all direct and indirect costs incurred with respect to the trapping or other remediation/enforcement activities from the person(s) considered as responsible as long as the property owner, as reflected by the records of the tax collector for the City of West Monroe, has been warned of a violation of these provisions within the previous twelve (12) months. For purposes of this provision, any non-owned, wild or feral animal (excluding squirrels and birds other than pigeons) which are obtained by trapping or other remediation/enforcement action within six hundred (600) feet of the property line of the property where food has been provided outdoors, or where other action or activity was undertaken to attract such animals shall be presumed to have attracted or enticed those animals by such feeding or other improper activity. The property owner and all adult residents are each considered to be offending persons at any residence where outdoor feeding or other prohibited action or activities occur, and shall be liable both individually and in solido for recovery of these costs. 
(Ord. No. 3836, § 2, 7-14-09) 
Sec. 8-3006. - Keeping within the city limits. 
(a)  No person shall establish or maintain any animal pen, stable, barnyard, rabbit hutch, chicken house or other place for the raising or breeding of livestock as defined in section 12-5006, except as provided in section 12-5017 or 12-5018. 
(b)  Any place for the keeping or housing of animals shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times, such that no vermin, insects, or other pests will find it a suitable habitat within which to propagate. 
(c)  Any place where animals are kept or housed shall not exude any unpleasant odors. 
(Code 1976, §§ 8-3005, 8-3006; Ord. No. 2093, § 19, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 2369, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 8-3007. - Suspected rabid animals. 
(a)  Any animal having rabies, or suspected of having rabies, or any animal which has attacked or bitten a person, shall be confined in a place and in a manner approved by the health officer or his representative. 
(b)  The animal shall be kept under observation for a period of ten (10) days. If the animal becomes ill or dies from any cause within the observation period, it shall be the duty of the owner to notify the health officer. If the animal dies it shall be the health officer's duty to have the animal's head submitted to a health department laboratory for examination for rabies. 
(c)  No person shall aid or abet the hiding of an animal which has attacked or bitten any person. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3007) 
Sec. 8-3008. - Vicious animals. 
(a)  Any animal that has bitten or attacked any person is hereby deemed and declared to be a vicious animal and shall be kept effectively yarded and controlled at all times by the owner or other person having the custody thereof. 
(b)  Any animal roaming at large, whether licensed or not, shall be picked up and impounded by the proper officer and confined until and unless the owner shall pay the impounding fee and cost of boarding and maintaining the animal, so long as the animal is impounded. 
(c)  In the event of a second offense, after release to the owner, the animal shall be deemed a public nuisance and shall be killed promptly in a humane manner; provided, however, that the animal may be released to any responsible person, conditioned upon proof that he will protect the public from the animal. 
(d)  If a dog is maintained as a watch dog and is effectively yarded at all times, the provision for destruction of the animal will not apply if the animal bites a person trespassing upon the property of the owner or custodian. Property shall be posted if the animal is considered vicious, with a sign bearing the words "bad dog," which signs shall be available at the police department. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3008) 
Sec. 8-3009. - Owners to prevent nuisances. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner to exercise proper care and control of his animals to prevent them from becoming a public nuisance. Excessive or continuous barking; or animals causing noises, molesting passers-by, chasing vehicles or habitually attacking other domestic animals; female dogs or cats at large in season; dogs running at large; or any animal trespassing upon school grounds or trespassing upon private property in such a manner as to damage property shall constitute a public nuisance and shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of section 8-3008. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3009) 
Sec. 8-3010. - Animals to be treated humanely. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner to provide animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering and with humane care and treatment. It shall be unlawful for the owner of an animal to abandon the animal for any cause and in any manner whatsoever. 
(b)  Animals confined shall be kept behind or within a suitable enclosure, suited to the size and number of animals, providing the animal within the enclosure with proper protection from the elements of cold, heat, sun and rain. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to restrain an animal by tying the animal on a rope, a chain or a leash of any description wherein tying the animal in such manner permits the animal to wind itself around any object, thereby becoming restrained to the extent that the restraint becomes cruel or inhumane. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leash any animal in any manner wherein the length of the leash restrains that animal in a way that the restraint is cruel or inhumane. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3010) 
Sec. 8-3011. - Noisy animals. 
    Any animal that whines, howls or barks or creates or causes other unnecessary noise to the disturbance of the neighborhood, may be impounded as a nuisance under this chapter. 
Secs. 8-3012-8-3020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - DOGS 

Sec. 8-3021. - Ownership, possession and keeping of dogs; impoundment; disposition. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess or keep about his premises any dog which is not vaccinated against the disease of rabies, to be evidenced by an appropriate tag, or to permit such dog to stray, run, roam or to create a nuisance within the city limits. Any person who owns, has in his possession or keeps about his premises any dog which is not vaccinated against rabies, or who permits any dog to stray, run, roam or be at large, or permits any dog to bark, whine, howl or growl, or otherwise disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood shall be held responsible for the creation of a nuisance. 
(b)  When any dog is found to be creating a nuisance within the city limits, it shall be the duty of the police to impound the animal. When any dog has been impounded by the city, this fact may be advertised by the city by posting a notice at the police department, which notice shall give a description of the dog impounded by sex, color or marks, natural or artificial, and if no person comes forward within three (3) days after the notice has been posted to claim the animal, the city shall have the right to dispose of the dog. 
(c)  In cases having to do with the violation of this section, the charges, fees, and costs are fixed as follows: 
(1)  Impoundment of dog ..... $25.00 
(2)  In the event the dog has been impounded under this section previously, the charges for impounding the dog and a like sum for each subsequent impoundment ..... 75.00 
or as may hereafter be changed by ordinance or resolution. 
(d)  All collected costs of impounding these animals shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3021; Ord. No. 2093, § 20, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 3256, § 1, 7-9-02) 
Sec. 8-3022. - Vaccination. 
    Prior to March 1 of each year every owner of a dog two (2) months of age or over shall have the dog vaccinated against rabies. The owner of a dog that is less than two (2) months of age on March 1 of any year shall have the dog vaccinated against rabies when it reaches two (2) months of age, and the dog shall be vaccinated against rabies again before attaining the age of six (6) months. The dog shall be vaccinated thereafter the same as any other dog. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3022) 
Sec. 8-3023. - Tag to be worn. 
(a)  At the time of the vaccination of a dog, the owner shall be issued a vaccination certificate and a vaccination tag. It shall be a violation of this chapter for the owner of the dog to fail to keep the tag securely fastened to the collar or harness of the dog at all times, or to fail to keep the collar or harness on the dog at all times. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this chapter for the owner of any dog to permit the dog to wear any vaccination tag not issued to that particular dog. 
(c)  Upon a written statement to the health officer or his representatives by the owner that a tag has been lost, and upon presentation of the original vaccination certificate, a duplicate vaccination tag will be issued. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3023) 
Sec. 8-3024. - Enclosure kept clean. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog pen, house, or other type of enclosure where any dog or dogs are kept, in a wet, unclean condition or in such a condition that flies may breed therein. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3024) 
Secs. 8-3025-8-3030. - Reserved. 
Chapter 4 - OTHER ABATEMENT PROCEDURES 

Sec. 8-3031. - Adoption of additional abatement programs. 
    In addition to the specific procedures otherwise provided in this Code, the mayor shall be authorized to develop and adopt a program or programs of abatement of improper litter, trash, garbage, yard debris, junk and junk autos which provide for: 
1.  Offenses. Describe the types of offenses which are subject to the program, including, but not limited to, litter, trash, garbage, yard debris, junk and junk autos. 
2.  Responsible persons. Provide for persons responsible to undertake the abatement or, if none undertaken, for the repayment of the abatement costs. A landlord shall usually be liable for violations by tenants in addition to the responsibility of the tenant. Violations on any property rented or leased are presumed to be the violation of the tenant/resident, if any, and of the landowner. 
3.  Cost. The cost of any cleanup/disposal/abatement shall be calculated as the reasonably estimated cost incurred by the city, including both direct and indirect administrative and support costs, and may be collected against the offender, if known, or other responsible person (including the property owner), or assessed in rem against the property. 
4.  Notice. Provide for notice to either or both of an offender or a responsible party (such as an owner of a property where an offense exists), the type and nature of such notice to be as determined as the appropriate notice after taking into account the urgency of the cleanup/disposal/abatement and type or nature of the violation. Acceptable forms of notice include personal notice, domiciliary notice, notice by posting at the location of the offending property or the residence of the offender or of the responsible person, notice by mail at the residence of the offender or of the responsible person (with any address listed in the records of the tax assessor of Ouachita Parish, Louisiana being presumed to be the proper address of the owner of the property), or by public notification through the Ouachita Citizen and/or the News Star, and which program may contain provisions such that repeat or ongoing offenders or other responsible parties may not be required to be again notified in advance for ongoing or repeat violations requiring cleanup/disposal/abatement of the violation. 
5.  [Penalties.] The provisions for abatement adopted pursuant to this section shall not preclude the use of additional methods provided in this code, nor shall it provide the imposition of criminal charges or other fines and penalties imposed by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4135, § 1, 5-14-13) 
Chapter 5 - SMOKE FREE AIR 

Sec. 8-5001. - Prohibition on smoking. 
a.  Prohibition: Smoking shall [be] prohibited within the municipal limits of the city to the full extent now provided by R.S. 40:1300.251 et seq. (as from time to time hereafter amended), and particularly by R.S. 40:1300.256A. The exemptions provided by R.S. 40:1300.256B shall likewise be exemptions under this section, except that the following exceptions shall not be applicable within the city: 
1.  R.S. 40:1300.256B(5) [any bar] 
2.  R.S. 40:1300.256B(8) [gaming operations, including bingo halls] 
3.  R.S. 40:1300.256B(13) [any outdoor patio where food or beverages are served] 
For the purposes of this section, the definition of "smoking" shall also include use of any electronic oral device, such as one composed of a heating element, battery, and/or electronic circuit, which provides vapor of nicotine or any other substances, and the use or inhalation of which simulates smoking. This term shall include any such device, whether manufactured, distributed, marketed, or sold as an e-cigarette, e-cigar, e-pipe, or under any other product name or descriptor. 
b.  Fines: 
1.  Any person who is guilty of a violation of the prohibitions in this section shall, upon a first offense, be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
2.  Any person who is guilty of violating any of the prohibitions in this section a second time within a period of five (5) years shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00). 
3.  Any person who is guilty of violating any of the prohibitions in this section a third or subsequent time within a period of five (5) years shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
4.  Each day on which a violation of this section occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
c.  Enforcement:
