1.  A person shall be cited for an offense by means of a citation, summons, or other means provided by law or ordinance. In addition, mailing by certified mail of such process to an alleged violator's last known place of residence, or to an alleged violator's business location (but only as to violations by an employer), shall be deemed as personal service upon the person or entity charged. 
2.  Enforcement of this section shall be implemented by the West Monroe Police Department, with the prosecution by the city attorney's office in West Monroe City Court. Police officers, city marshals, Code enforcement officials, and other expressly designated by the mayor are empowered to issue citations to persons violating any of the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 4152, § 1, 10-8-13) 
Part 9 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1]

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 9-1001. - Motor vehicle and traffic law adopted. 
(a)  This part shall be known, shall constitute and may be referred to as the "West Monroe Highway Regulatory Act," and any and all additions and amendments to this part, whether by way of ordinance duly passed by the governmental authority of West Monroe, Louisiana or by amendments or addition to Title 32 of Louisiana Revised Statutes duly enacted by the state, shall become part hereof, and be deemed incorporated therein so that a reference to the "West Monroe Highway Regulatory Act" shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
(b)  The city, pursuant to the authority invested therein, does hereby declare its intent and desire to adopt and enact, and does hereby adopt and enact, Title 32 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes, insofar as the same may be applicable to the regulation of vehicles and persons upon the streets or highways of the city, together with any revisions and amendments thereto, and as same is from time to time amended by the laws of the state, and as same may hereafter from time to time be amended by the state. 
(c)  Title 32 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes in all of its provisions, parts and particulars, sections, subsections, words, clauses and phrases, including appendixes and indexes, is hereby adopted as the "West Monroe Highway Regulatory Act," as herein set forth. 
(d)  The operation of vehicles and the regulation of persons upon the streets and/or highways of the city shall be conducted in accordance and conformity with all of the provisions of said Title 32 as the same is now effective and as the same may be from time to time hereafter amended. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1001; Ord. No. 1630, §§ I, II, VI, VII, 9-14-76; Ord. No. 2093, § 21, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 9-1001.1. - Additional violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle if the vehicle is in violation of any one or more of the following, each of which shall be considered as a separate violation: 
(a)  R.S. 47:501. Owner to secure registration. 
(b)  R.S. 47:505D. Number plates. 
(c)  R.S. 47:506. Registration certificates. 
(d)  R.S. 47:508. Registration; commercial vehicles; exemption. 
(e)  R.S. 47:513. Vehicle of nonresident owner used regularly in business in Louisiana. 
(f)  R.S. 47:519. Temporary registration plates issued by dealers. 
(g)  R.S. 47:536.8. Violations of registration provisions. 
(Ord. No. 4314, § 1, 9-8-15) 
Sec. 9-1002. - Penalty for violation. 
    In addition to any other penalties set forth in this part, it shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provisions of this part, or any amendments hereto, and where no specific penalty is provided, therefor, the violation of or failure to comply with any provisions of this part or any amendments hereto shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) and confinement for a term not exceeding six (6) months, or both, such fine and confinement to be within the discretion of the court, together with court costs. Each day any violation of or failure to comply with this part or any provision hereof continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 1630, § IV, 9-14-76) 
Sec. 9-1003. - Supervision, regulation, etc., by police chief. 
    The chief of police shall supervise and regulate all traffic on the public streets of the city to the full extent authorized by R.S. 32:41; enforce the provisions of this part; establish speed limits; establish school and other zones as appropriate which shall further include the right to establish reduced speed limits and other restrictions during certain hours and or certain days; investigate the public highways and effect methods and practices relative thereto as in his judgment and experience he deems advisable; and enforce them as an exercise of the police power of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1003; Ord. No. 4219, § 1, 10-14-14) 
Cross reference- Police protection, Part 4, Ch. 1. 
Sec. 9-1004. - Making and enforcing regulations, permanent and temporary. 
    The chief of police is hereby empowered to make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this part and to make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies and special conditions. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1004) 
Sec. 9-1005. - Authority to place signs, signals and markings. 
    The chief of police is authorized, and as to those signs and signals required herein, directed to place and maintain, or cause to be placed and maintained, all appropriate traffic signs and signals. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1005; Ord. No. 4219, § 2, 10-14-14) 
Sec. 9-1006. - Seizure of vehicle-Authorized. 
    The chief of police and his officers hereby are authorized and directed to seize or take into their custody any vehicle operated or parked in violation of law where, in the discretion of said officers, to do so appears necessary to promote the public welfare or safety. 
(Ord. No. 1839, § 1, 10-14-80) 
State Law reference- Impounding of vehicles authorized, R.S. 32:392, 32:471 et seq. 
Sec. 9-1007. - Same-Storage; cost. 
    A seized vehicle shall be stored at the expense of the owner of said vehicle at a location to be determined by the chief of police. The expense or cost to be paid by the owner shall be determined by the chief of police, which cost shall cover all charges for removing the vehicle to the place of holding, together with all costs incurred during the period of holding. 
(Ord. No. 1839, § 2, 10-14-80) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:472. 
Sec. 9-1008. - Same-Notification of owner. 
    The chief of police or his officers shall notify the registered owner of a vehicle seized with reasonable promptness that the vehicle has been seized and how the owner may regain possession in accordance with regulations promulgated by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1839, § 3, 10-14-80) 
State Law reference- Notification of owner of abandoned vehicle, R.S. 32:475. 
Sec. 9-1009. - Reserved. 
Sec. 9-1010. - Traffic offenses; written agreement to appear; payment of fine by mail. 
(a)  Except as provided below, or as otherwise provided by law, any alleged offender charged with violation of section 9-1001, or Title 32 of the Revised Statutes, or any other traffic violation may promise, in writing (in a form approved by the city attorney), to appear in court to answer those charges. That written promise to appear shall be accepted in lieu of posting bond or depositing a driver's license. 
(b)  The City Marshal of the City of West Monroe shall accept a plea of guilty to any of the alleged offenses encompassed within subsection (a), and shall allow payment of the fine by mail. However, the city marshal shall be entitled to designate the type of payments which shall be allowable. 
(Ord. No. 2816, § 1, 3-11-97; Ord. No. 3605, § 1, 10-10-06) 
Chapter 2 - TRAFFIC 

Sec. 9-2001. - Free flow of traffic; obstruction prohibited. 
    All persons are prohibited from engaging in driving procedures which obstruct the free flow of traffic in, around, over and through the streets, alleyways and other public ways of the city. Any person is prohibited from stopping his vehicle (except at a stop signal or stop sign, or to honor another driver's right-of-way, or in an emergency situation) in a manner as to obstruct the free and orderly flow of traffic by the maneuver, or to engage in unduly slow driving procedures so as to obstruct the free flow of traffic or to needlessly "circle the block" or dawdle, or make unnecessarily rapid accelerations and decelerations or to in any other manner constitute a traffic nuisance or hazard. 
(Code 1976, § 9-2001) 
Sec. 9-2002. - Speed limits. 
    The speed limits for the streets or portions of streets within the city are hereby established as indicated by officially posted signs designating the maximum vehicular speed upon the streets of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 9-2002) 
Sec. 9-2003. - Traffic signs, signals and markings. 
    All traffic shall obey and be directed by official traffic control signals, signs and markings erected at street intersections and other locations nor or hereafter approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Code 1976, § 9-2003) 
Sec. 9-2004. - One-way streets established. 
    Upon those streets and parts of streets and in those alleys designated by the mayor and board of aldermen, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1976, § 9-2004) 
State Law reference- Power of city to designate one-way highways, R.S. 32:41. 
Sec. 9-2005. - Truck routes. 
    The following streets are hereby designated as truck routes, to wit: 
Arkansas Road from Warren Drive to North Seventh Street. 
Bridge Street. 
Coleman Avenue from South Second to and including Montgomery and Reagan Streets. 
Cypress Street from Wood to the city limits on the west. 
McMillan Road No. 2. 
Natchitoches Street from Cypress to the city limits on Jonesboro Road. 
North Seventh and White's Ferry Road from Wood Street to Tupaw (Tupar) Bayou. 
Plum Street. 
Thompson Street to Mitchell Lane; thence east on Mitchell Lane to the intersection of South Second; thence north on South Second to Wood; thence west on Wood to Cypress. 
(Code 1976, § 9-2005; Ord. No. 1657, § 1, 9-13-77) 
State Law reference- Power of city to designate routes for freight-carrying vehicles, R.S. 32:41. 
Sec. 9-2006. - Tracked vehicles; metal wheels. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate any tracked or other vehicle having metal tracks or wheels upon the city streets. 
(Code 1976, § 9-2006) 
State Law reference- Tire equipment, R.S. 32:362. 
Sec. 9-2007. - Reserved. 
Sec. 9-2008. - Approaching fire. 
    No person or persons shall approach in any vehicle within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the scene of a fire that is being combatted by the fire department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2014) 
Chapter 3 - PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Parking in mobile home parks, § 12-3011. 
State Law reference- Parking, standing and stopping, R.S. 32:141 et seq.; 32:471 et seq.; power of city to regulate the standing or parking of vehicles, R.S. 32:141. 
Annotation- An ordinance prohibiting parking on certain streets that constituted a part of a national thoroughfare did not violate Art. 1, § 2, of the Louisiana Constitution and was not unreasonable, arbitrary, unjust or oppressive, Scott v. City of West Monroe, 95 So.2d 343 (1957). 

Sec. 9-3001. - Vehicles to be parked within marked spaces. 
    Whenever a space is marked off on any highway for the parking of an individual vehicle, every vehicle there parked shall be parked within the lines bounding that space. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3001) 
Sec. 9-3002. - Prohibited in certain locations. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle or other vehicle to park the vehicle in any of the places on the streets and alleys of the city specifically designated by posted signs indicating such prohibited parking. 
(b)  It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle or other vehicle to park the vehicle in any of the places on private parking lots within the city specifically designated as fire lanes by posted signs indicating such prohibited parking. After the state fire marshal has designated said fire lanes, it shall be the responsibility of the owners and operators of private parking lots to pay for and erect suitable signs notifying everyone that there shall be no parking within the specified area by order of the state fire marshal. 
(c)  (1)  All law enforcement officers of this city who are invested by law with authority to direct, control, or regulate traffic are authorized to enter upon private property within the city to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(2)  a.  The law enforcement officer shall be authorized to issue a citation or take whatever law enforcement action is deemed necessary or both. Furthermore, when an individual found to be in violation of these provisions refuses a request by a law enforcement officer to move the vehicle found in violation, the officer shall be authorized to have such vehicle towed. 
b.  The citation shall contain information concerning the nature, date, time, and location of the alleged violation, the state vehicle license plate number, and the make of vehicle. In those cases where a license plate is not visible or legible, the vehicle identification number shall be used in lieu of the state vehicle plate number. The citation shall also contain information advising the person charged of the manner and the time in which he may contest the violation charged in the citation. The citation shall also provide that a failure to timely answer or appear before a court of competent jurisdiction shall be considered a prima facie admission of the violation set forth in the citation, in which the court may assess the appropriate fine or fines and all penalties incidental thereto. 
c.  The citation issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be personally served upon the operator of the vehicle by affixing the parking citation to the vehicle in a conspicuous place thereon. The original parking citation shall bear the name or initials and identification number of the issuing officer who shall affirm the truth of the facts set forth therein. An operator of a vehicle who is not the owner, but who uses or operates the vehicle with permission of the owner, expressed or implied, shall be considered the agent of the owner to receive the citation required to be served upon the operator or registered owner of a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this section. When a citation is issued for an alleged violation of the laws governing parking in a fire lane, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a person in whose name the vehicle is registered was the operator of the vehicle when the alleged violation was committed. 
d.  In the event that the registered owner or operator of a vehicle drives the vehicle away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation while the issuing officer is preparing the citation, or refuses service of the parking citation and drives away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation, this fact shall be duly noted on the original and all copies of the parking citation. This original and all copies of a parking citation shall constitute a business record of the West Monroe Police Department and shall constitute prima facie evidence that the citation was issued and that an attempt at service was made in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3002; Ord. No. 1760, 8-14-79; Ord. No. 4316, § 1, 9-8-15) 
State Law reference- State fire marshal, R.S. 40:1561 et seq. 
Sec. 9-3003. - Prohibited in certain locations, certain days and hours. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle or other vehicle to park the vehicle in any of the places on the days and between hours indicated and specified by posted signs indicating such prohibited parking. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3003) 
Sec. 9-3004. - Limited in certain locations, certain days and hours. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle or other vehicle to park the vehicle or allow the vehicle to remain parked in any of the places on the streets and alleys of the city, at any time on the days and between the hours indicated and specified by posted signs limiting parking time in certain locations on certain days and hours. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3004) 
Sec. 9-3005. - Special purpose parking zones. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to park the vehicle or allow the vehicle to remain parked in any locations on the streets and alleys of the city in established and designated special purpose parking zones except as indicated and specified by posted signs. 
(Code 1976, § 9-3005; Ord. No. 1761, 8-14-79) 
Sec. 9-3006. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 8 of Ord. No. 2366, adopted Sept. 11, 1990, repealed former § 9-3006, which pertained to inoperative motor vehicles and derived from Code 1976, § 9-3006, and Ord. No. 1762, adopted Aug. 14, 1979. 
Sec. 9-3007. - Reserved. 
Sec. 9-3008. - Mobility impaired persons. 
(a)  The chief of police, or his designee, is hereby authorized to designate areas on public streets and in publicly owned parking facilities which are to be reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles bearing a special license plate or displaying a parking card. 
(b)  Owners, lessees, or their designees, of privately owned parking areas may designate certain spaces within those parking areas which are to be reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles bearing a special license plate or displaying a parking card. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle other than one bearing a special license plate or displaying a parking card in an area, either publicly owned or privately owned, which has been designated as being reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles bearing a special license plate or displaying a parking card, or for those who are mobility impaired. 
(d)  Any person who parks in an area, either publicly or privately owned, which has been designated for the exclusive use of the mobility impaired person, and who does not have a special license plate or parking card, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition to such fine, the offender shall also be required to pay the towing fee and any storage costs which are incurred if the vehicle is towed. 
(e)  Any person who utilizes a parking card or a vehicle bearing a special license plate or parking card to obtain handicapped parking privileges but who has not transported a mobility impaired person in that vehicle prior to parking the vehicle, may be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or may be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both, and on the second and subsequent offense, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days, or both. 
(f)  Any mobility impaired person who allows his parking card or vehicle bearing a special license plate to be used, when said card or vehicle is used to illegally access special handicapped parking privileges by an individual not entitled to such special handicapped parking privileges, shall have his handicapped parking privileges suspended for six (6) months and shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both, for the first offense. On the second and subsequent offenses, such suspension shall be for one year, and the individual shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), in addition to suspension of such privileges, or shall be imprisoned not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(g)  Any mobility impaired person who has a special license plate or a parking card shall also have a picture identification card in his possession when using handicapped parking privileges. Any person who utilizes handicapped parking privileges without such identification may be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(h)  For purposes of this section a "special license plate" or a "parking card" is defined as a special license plate or hang tag issued to persons with mobility impairment pursuant to R.S. 47:463.4, or other applicable law, or comparable governmental issuing authority outside the State of Louisiana, or a properly displayed parking card issued to a person with mobility impairment pursuant to R.S. 47:463.4.1 or other applicable law, or comparable governmental issuing authority outside the State of Louisiana; "handicapped parking privileges" are defined as the right to park a vehicle in an area designated as reserved for the exclusive use of a person with a mobility impairment. 
(i)  A motor vehicle bearing a special license plate or displaying a parking card may be parked for a period of two (2) hours in excess of the legal parking period permitted, except where the motor vehicle is parked in such a manner as to clearly be a traffic hazard. 
(j)  (1)  All law enforcement officers of this city who are invested by law with authority to direct, control, or regulate traffic are authorized to enter upon private property within the city to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(2)  a.  The law enforcement officer shall be authorized to issue a citation or take whatever law enforcement action is deemed necessary or both. Furthermore, when an individual found to be in violation of these provisions refuses a request by a law enforcement officer to move the vehicle found in violation, the officer shall be authorized to have such vehicle towed. 
b.  The citation shall contain information concerning the nature, date, time, and location of the alleged violation, the state vehicle license plate number, and the make of vehicle. In those cases where a license plate is not visible or legible, the vehicle identification number shall be used in lieu of the state vehicle plate number. The citation shall also contain information advising the person charged of the manner and the time in which he may contest the violation charged in the citation. The citation shall also provide that a failure to timely answer or appear before a court of competent jurisdiction shall be considered a prima facie admission of the violation set forth in the citation, in which the court may assess the appropriate fine or fines and all penalties incidental thereto. 
c.  The citation issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be personally served upon the operator of the vehicle by affixing the parking citation to the vehicle in a conspicuous place thereon. The original parking citation shall bear the name or initials and identification number of the issuing officer who shall affirm the truth of the facts set forth therein. An operator of a vehicle who is not the owner, but who uses or operates the vehicle with permission of the owner, expressed or implied, shall be considered the agent of the owner to receive the citation required to be served upon the operator or registered owner of a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this section. When a citation is issued for an alleged violation of the laws governing parking in an accessible parking space, loading and unloading areas, access aisles, access ramps, and curb cuts, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a person in whose name the vehicle is registered was the operator of the vehicle when the alleged violation was committed. 
d.  In the event that the registered owner or operator of a vehicle drives the vehicle away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation while the issuing officer is preparing the citation, or refuses service of the parking citation and drives away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation, this fact shall be duly noted on the original and all copies of the parking citation. This original and all copies of a parking citation shall constitute a business record of the West Monroe Police Department and shall constitute prima facie evidence that the citation was issued and that an attempt at service was made in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(k)  Designation of an area as reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles bearing a special license plate or displaying a parking card shall be by signage showing the symbol of accessibility and/or contain the written designation of "handicapped" or any similar word or phrase commonly understood as indicating mobility impairment. Such signage may also contain a phrase indicating the vehicle is subject to being towed if it is not properly parked in such area, such as "Tow Away Zone," "Unauthorized Vehicles Will Be Towed," or similar phrase. 
(l)  No provision of this section shall be construed as superseding, amending or in any other way affecting any other section or provision of this Code which requires provision for or designation of areas reserved for exclusive use of vehicles bearing a special license plate or displaying a parking card. 
(m)  For purposes of this section, the term "law enforcement officers of this city" shall encompass all such persons who are invested by the chief of police of the city with the authority to enforce the provisions of this section, whether or not such person would otherwise be considered as a "law enforcement officer" under the provisions of this Code or under state law. 
(n)  In addition to all fines, fees, costs and punishment prescribed by law for violations of mobility-impaired parking restrictions established above, the court shall impose an additional feet of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each such violation pursuant to the provisions of R.S. 46:2583A(2). All monies collected from such additional fees shall be forwarded by the officer of the court who collects the same to the state treasurer within thirty (30) days after such penalty or forfeiture is collected. 
(Ord. No. 1914, 4-13-82; Ord. No. 2093, § 22, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 2376, § 1, 8-14-90; Ord. No. 3203, § 2, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 4315, § 1, 9-8-15) 
Chapter 5 - RAILROADS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Railroad grade crossings, R.S. 32:168 et seq.; municipal powers as to railroads, R.S. 33:403; railroads generally, R.S. 45:321 et seq. 

Sec. 9-5001. - Crossings-Installing; maintaining. 
    The owner of any railroad track or tracks, occupying any portion of any street within the city, shall install, occupy and maintain, in an efficient, proper, safe, suitable and good condition, appropriate crossing or crossings of the tracks of such railroad. The installation, occupation and maintenance of such crossings shall be at all times at the expense of the owner of the railroad track or tracks, and the type of construction, material, width and other specifications for such crossings shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79) 
Sec. 9-5002. - Same-Order to construct; notice; performance of work by city. 
    Whenever it is deemed necessary by the board of aldermen that a crossing be installed, or that any existing crossing be repaired, renewed or replaced, the mayor shall give notice to the owner of the railroad track or tracks to do the work deemed necessary, as aforesaid, such notice to be in writing and to set forth the work deemed necessary, as aforesaid, and in the event the owner of the railroad track or tracks aforesaid fails to comply with the requirements of such notice within the period of time prescribed in such notice, the board of aldermen shall have the work done, at the expense of the owner or owners of the railroad track or tracks aforesaid. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79) 
Sec. 9-5003. - Same-Signals and flagging when switching over. 
(a)  No cars shall be shoved, kicked, or dropped over a public crossing within West Monroe, Louisiana. 
(b)  When cars are shoved, kicked, or dropped in a switching movement over a public crossing, a member of the crew must protect the crossing from a point on the ground near the center of the crossing and each movement over the crossing shall be made only on his signal except: 
(1)  When crossing is protected by manually controlled gates, watchman, or manually controlled crossing signals and they are functioning (automatic flasher lights and automatic gates are not within this exception); 
(2)  When cars are shoved over crossing and lead car is occupied by a member of the crew and the movement is made only on his signal, and when the lead car is equipped with the breakhose or pipe and air whistle form which brakes can be applied and whistle blown. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79; Ord. No. 1757, § 1, 8-14-79) 
Sec. 9-5004. - Same-Obstructing; time limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railway company to obstruct or cause to be obstructed the public street crossing and causeways, within the city limits, with cars or engines of any description whatever, and they are hereby required to clear such crossing within five (5) minutes after the obstruction is so placed. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79; Ord. No. 1757, § 2, 8-14-79) 
Sec. 9-5005. - Same-Plankings. 
    All railway companies operating their respective lines on, over or along any of the streets or alleys of the city are required to plank all crossings of their respective lines with good and sound oak lumber, or other suitable material approved by the city engineer, such crossings to continue between the rails and two (2) feet outside of each rail, and to maintain such crossings at all times, keeping same in first class condition, subject to the approval and satisfaction of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79) 
Sec. 9-5006. - Drains and ditches-Maintenance. 
    All railroad companies operating within the corporate limits of the city are required to keep all drains and ditches along both sides of their right-of-way, within the corporate limits, open and in such condition that they will carry off all water flowing into them, and shall not permit water to stand in the same. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79) 
Sec. 9-5007. - Same-Clearing of obstructions by city. 
    Whenever any drain or ditch of any railroad company within the city shall become filled up or obstructed, so that it will not permit water to flow along the same, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to give written notice, by service thereof by any police officer, to the section foreman in charge of the track in the city, which notice shall direct that the ditch or drain shall be opened or cleaned out or the obstruction removed within the ten (10) days from the service of the notice; and in the event of the failure of the company to open or clean out such drain or ditch or to remove the obstruction without delay, the city shall cause the same to be done at the expense of the railroad company, to be recovered by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79) 
Sec. 9-5008. - Speed limit. 
    The maximum rate of speed at which any railroad locomotive train, car or handcar may be driven or run by any person or persons along and on any railroad or tracks within the corporate limits of the city shall not exceed thirty (30) miles per hour; and any railroad engineer or engine-driver or conductor or other person who shall drive or run, or cause the same to be done, any railroad locomotive, train, car or handcar at a greater rate of speed than thirty (30) miles per hour within the city limits shall be responsible and punishable for such violation. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79) 
Sec. 9-5009. - Penalty. 
    Any conductor, flagmen, engineer or other person in charge of any train, engine or cars of any railroad within the limits of the city who shall violate the provisions of this chapter, shall be punished as provided in section 1-1008 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1733, 4-10-79) 
Part 10 - LICENSING AND REGULATION[1] 
Footnotes:

No. 704, requiring the closing of businesses on Sunday, had a proper title; contained only one subject; intended to include moving picture show in the word "theaters"; was not discriminatory; and did not deprive the owner of a moving picture show of his property without due process of law, City of West Monroe v. Newell, 163 La. 409, 111 So. 889 (1927). 

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 10-1001. - Annual license tax. 
    There is hereby levied an occupational license tax for the year 1988 and for each subsequent year, upon each person pursuing and conducting any business, trade, calling, profession or vocation, within the corporate limits of the city subject to license under the Louisiana constitution and the laws of this state. The due date for such tax, its application and manner of calculation, exemptions, deductions, penalties and manner of administration shall, except as provided otherwise in this chapter, be in accordance with the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 47, Chapter 3, sections 341, et seq., as it has, from time to time, been amended and is, from time to time, amended in the future, and all other applicable laws, all of which for all purposes of this chapter are made a part hereof by reference as if written herein in extenso. 
(Ord. No. 1892, § 1, 11-10-81; Ord. No. 2183, 5-12-87; Ord. No. 2406, § 1, 3-12-91) 
Sec. 10-1002. - State law adopted. 
(a)  Amount of tax. The amount of the annual license tax levied in each case under this chapter is hereby fixed, determined and ordained to be the same as the maximum amount fixed, levied and collectible by the governing authority under, and shall be in accordance with the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 47, Chapter 3, sections 341, et seq., as it has, from time to time, been amended and is, from time to time, amended in the future, and all other applicable laws, all of which for all purposes of this chapter are made a part hereof by reference as if written herein in extenso. 
(b)  Peddlers, et al. All peddlers, hawkers, itinerant vendors, every person who displays samples, models, goods, wares or merchandise on a temporary basis in any hotel, motel, store, storehouse, house, vehicle or any other place, for the purpose of securing orders for the retail sales of such goods, wares, or others of like kind or quantity, either for immediate or future delivery, shall obtain an annual license, for which there is hereby imposed and levied an annual license tax of two hundred dollars ($200.00), provided that an itinerant vendor of agricultural products purchased directly from farmers or an itinerant vendor of seafood products who has either harvested the seafood himself or has purchased the seafood directly from commercial fishermen or shrimpers shall obtain a license, for which there is hereby imposed and levied an annual license tax of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Such license taxes levied herein shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year and all unpaid license taxes shall come delinquent on the 1st day of March thereafter. The collection of all delinquent accounts shall be enforced in accordance with sections 10-1001 and 10-1002, or the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes 47:1601 and 47:1602, or both. 
(c)  Manner of enforcement. The city clerk or his designated assistants, as tax collector under this chapter, shall receive and collect the license taxes dues to the city under this chapter, and may enforce the collection of any and all taxes due under this chapter. 
(d)  Taxpayers required to keep records. Each person shall keep complete records of gross receipts, capital, sales, premium, commissions and earnings. These records shall be kept separately for each place of business, and shall be subject to examination and inspection by the city clerk or his duly designated assistants or by an authorized accountant appointed by the city. 
(e)  Applications for licenses. 
(1)  Contents. Every person subject to a license tax levied by this chapter shall apply to the city clerk for a license before the same becomes delinquent, as provided in this chapter. This application shall state all facts necessary to determine the amount of taxes due under this chapter. 
(2)  Audit and inspection of records. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the facts set forth in the application, or for any reason desires to audit the books and records of the taxpayer, the city clerk, or any of his authorized assistants, may audit and inspect all records of the taxpayer that would have any bearing upon the amount of taxes due under this chapter. 
(3)  Who may sign. Where an individual is an applicant for a license required by this chapter, the application must be signed by him; where a partnership or an association of persons, by a member of the firm; and where a corporation, by the proper officer thereof. 
(4)  Intentional false statements; misdemeanor; fine. Any intentional false statement as to any material facts in the application for a license under this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor and any persons convicted thereof shall be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or both. 
(f)  Posting of license, penalty. Each person required to take out a license under this chapter shall be required to post the same in a conspicuous place, in his place of business, under penalty of not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), recoverable by the city clerk before any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(g)  Evidence of payment of license. The only legal evidence that a license has been paid shall be the appropriate form of license issued by the city clerk, provided that nothing herein contained shall be construed so as to exclude oral evidence of a lost or destroyed license. 
(h)  Interest, penalties and costs. All unpaid license taxes shall bear a interest at the rate of one and twenty-five one-hundredths (1 25/100 ) percent per month from the first day of March. All unpaid license taxes shall additionally bear a penalty of five (5) percent per month, up to a maximum of twenty-five (25) percent, from the first day of March. In addition, should judicial proceedings for collection of license taxes be instituted, said delinquent taxpayer shall pay the additional sum of ten (10) percent of the aggregate amount of license taxes, interest and penalties due by said delinquent as attorney's fees to the city attorney instituting such proceeding, plus all court costs incurred. 
(Ord. No. 1892, §§ 2, 3, 11-10-81; Ord. No. 2183, 5-12-87; Ord. No. 2218, 10-13-87; Ord. No. 2273, 12-13-88; Ord. No. 2406, § 1, 3-12-91; Ord. No. 2490, § 1, 10-13-92) 
Editor's note- Subsections (d)-(f) derive from Ord. No. 2273, adopted Dec. 13, 1988, which added such subsection to § 10-1002. Ordinance No. 2490, amending subsection (b), became effective Jan. 1, 1993. 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, R.S. 47:341. 
Sec. 10-1002.1. - Annual license tax on insurers. 
(a)  Imposed. There is hereby imposed and levied annual license tax on any insurer engaged in the business of issuing any form of insurance policy or contract, which may now or hereafter be subject to the payment of any license tax for state purposes, all as authorized by Section 1076 of Title 22 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950 on risks located in this municipality as follows: 
(1)  On any insurer engaged in the business of issuing life or accident or health insurance policies, other than programs of benefits authorized or provided pursuant to the provisions of Parts I and II of Chapter 12 of Title 42 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, or other forms of contracts or obligations covering such risks, or issuing endowment or annuity policies, or contracts, or other similar forms of contract obligations in consideration of the payment of a premium or other consideration for the issuance of such policies, contracts or obligations, whether such insurer is operating in this state or through an agent or other representative or otherwise; 
a.  Ten dollars ($10.00) on gross annual premiums up to two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) and an additional license thereafter of seventy dollars ($70.00) on each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or fraction thereof, of gross premiums in excess of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
b.  The maximum license on such business, payable to this municipality by any one insurer, shall be twenty-one thousand dollars ($21,000.00). 
(2)  On any insurer, engaged in the business of issuing policies, contracts, or other forms of obligations covering the risk of fire, marine, transportation, surety, fidelity, indemnity, guaranty, worker's compensation, employers' liability, property damage, livestock, vehicle, automatic sprinkler, burglary, or insurance business of any other kind whatsoever in this state, whether such insurer is operating in this state through agents or other representatives or otherwise, not more than the following: 
a.  First Class: When the gross receipts are not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), the license shall be forty dollars ($40.00). 
b.  Second Class: When the gross receipts are more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), and not more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00), the license shall be sixty dollars ($60.00). 
c.  Third Class: When the gross receipts are more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00), and not more than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), the license shall be eighty dollars ($80.00). 
d.  Fourth Class: When the gross receipts exceed six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), the additional license thereafter shall be seventy dollars ($70.00) for each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or fraction thereof, in excess of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00). 
e.  The maximum license tax on such businesses, payable to this municipality by any insurer, shall be nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00); and further provided, that plate glass and steam boiler inspection insurers shall pay only one-third ( 1/3 ) of the above rates provided in subsection (2). 
(3)  The amount of license payable to this municipality as fixed by this chapter, shall be one-third ( 1/3 ) of the amount so fixed if the payer shall file a sworn statement with the annual report required by R.S. Title 22, Chapter 1, Part XXIII, showing that at least one-sixth ( 1/6 ) of the total admitted assets of the payer, are invested and maintained in qualifying Louisiana investments as defined in R.S. 22:1068(C). 
(b)  Due date; penalties. All license taxes levied herein shall be due and payable on January 1st of each year and all unpaid license taxes shall become delinquent on June 1. A penalty of five (5) percent per month shall be added to the amount of tax due and payable to this municipality along with the tax due. The monetary penalty assessed pursuant to this section shall not be greater than twenty-five (25) percent of the total amount of the tax due. The collection of delinquent accounts shall be enforced in accordance with R.S. 22:1076 and 47:1601. 
(Ord. No. 2198, 5-12-87; Ord. No. 2348, § 1, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 2721, § 1, 1-9-96; Ord. No. 3205, § 1, 11-13-01) 
Sec. 10-1002.2. - Issuance of license. 
    Upon payment of the tax due as reflected on the application filed by the taxpayer, the city shall issue the license applied for and shall have no authority to deny, refuse to issue, or revoke any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. After audit or examination of a taxpayer's books and records the collector shall have authority to adjust or amend the application and license to reflect the correct amount of gross receipts, tax due, or the correct class of business for which the license tax shall be computed and shall so notify the taxpayer in writing of the amount of taxes owed to the city or owed by the city to the taxpayer, which amounts shall be paid within ten (10) days of the receipt of said written notice by the taxpayer. 
(Ord. No. 2218, 10-13-87) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2218, adopted Oct. 13, 1987, amended the Code by adding thereto a § 10-1002.1. Inasmuch as there already existed a § 10-1002.1, the provision of Ord. No. 2218 was redesignated by the editor as § 10-1002.2. 
Sec. 10-1003. - Failure to pay tax; effect of judgment. 
    Failure to pay the tax levied under authority of this chapter shall ipso facto, without demand or putting in default, cause the tax, interest, penalties and costs to become immediately delinquent. The tax collector or other tax collecting official is hereby vested with authority, on motion in a court of competent jurisdiction, to take a rule on the delinquent taxpayer to show cause in not less than two (2) nor more than ten (10) days, exclusive of holidays, why the delinquent taxpayer should not be ordered to cease from further pursuit of the business taxed under authority of this chapter. This rule may be tried out of term and in chambers and shall be tried by preference. If the rule is made absolute, the order therein rendered shall be considered a judgment in favor of the city prohibiting the taxpayer from the further pursuit of the business therein until he has paid the delinquent tax, interest, penalties and costs, and every violation of the injunction shall be considered a contempt of court, punishable according to law. 
(Ord. No. 1892, § 6, 11-10-81) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2183, adopted May 12, 1987, repealed former §§ 10-1-003 and 10-1004 in their entirety and renumbered former § 10-1005 as § 10-1003. The repealed provisions pertained to due and payment date for license tax and separate license tax for each class of business at each location, and derived from Ord. No. 1892, §§ 4, 5, adopted Nov. 10, 1981. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 47:401; punishment for contempt of court, R.S. 13:4611, Code of Civ. Proc., Art. 227. 
Sec. 10-1004. - Exempt businesses. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, no provision of this chapter shall be construed as requiring any person or entity engaged in conduct protected under the First Amendment of the Constitution of the United States of America, including, but not limited to, any editor or publisher, to apply for or to obtain a license or to pay the tax levied by this chapter as a condition to engaging in such business, profession or conduct. 
(b)  Any person or entity engaged in conduct protected by the First Amendment of the Constitution of the United States of America, including, but not limited to, any editor or publisher, upon notification in writing to the city of the name and place of business of such person or entity, shall be issued a license forthwith. In the event the city disputes whether said person or entity is actually engaged in conduct protected by the First Amendment of the Constitution of the United States of America, the city shall file a petition for declaratory judgment against said business or entity, in a court of competent jurisdiction, for determination of whether said business or entity is one that is actually engaged in conduct protected by the First Amendment of the Constitution of the United States of America, but until there is a final judgment rendered in said suit, the pendency of said suit shall not be grounds to deny the issuance of said license to said person or entity. 
(Ord. No. 2218, 10-13-87) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2218, adopted Oct. 13, 1987, amended the code by adding thereto a § 10-1006. In order to maintain the order of section within the chapter, the editor has redesignated the provision of Ord. No. 2218 as § 10-1004. 
Sec. 10-1004.1. - Activities not requiring an occupational license. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, activities with a duration of five (5) days or less and which are conducted at or upon the grounds of any city facility or recreational area, including but not limited to the Ike Hamilton Expo Center, the West Monroe Convention Center, the West Monroe Recreational Complex, Kiroli Park and Lazarre Point Recreation Area, and which involve either conducting an event, or which involve an activity operating in conjunction with a larger event, which event has rented or leased all or a portion of either of such facilities or areas shall be considered as an activity which is not required to obtain an occupational license for activities within the city during such time period. 
(Ord. No. 3204, § 1, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 3644, § 1, 2-13-07) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 3644 provided that this amendment shall be effective on and after February 14, 2007. 
Sec. 10-1005. - Video draw poker devices. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed and levied an annual license tax on every person engaged in the business of operating video draw poker devices or similar devices, licensed and permitted pursuant to Louisiana Revised Statutes 33:4862 et seq., of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such device. 
(b)  All license taxes levied herein shall be collected in the same manner as the occupational license tax levied pursuant to sections 10-1001 and 10-1002. The taxes shall be due and payable upon initial installation of each such device, or on January 1 of each year, whichever shall first occur, and all unpaid license taxes shall become delinquent on the first day of March thereafter. The collection of delinquent accounts shall be enforced in accordance with sections 10-1001 and 10-1002, or the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes R.S. 47:1601 and 47:1602, whichever shall be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2492, § 1, 10-13-92) 
Sec. 10-1006. - Home solicitation permit. 
    At least ten (10) days prior to beginning of solicitation, an applicant for a home solicitation permit shall apply to the city, and shall: 
(1)  Have obtained an appropriate occupational license for the city; 
(2)  Complete and submit an application which shall include the applicant's name, permanent mailing address, local address, local telephone number(s), and other identifying information as the city shall determine appropriate, and which shall include the business purpose/affiliation and nature of the solicitation, and such other information as is appropriate for the verification of the identity of the applicant as may be requested, or as is appropriate in order to verify qualification under this provision; 
(3)  Provide a general description of the neighborhood areas to be solicited, and the intended dates of solicitation; 
(4)  Pay a forty-five dollar ($45.00) registration fee; 
(5)  Be fingerprinted, and provide a criminal background investigation as designated by the city; 
(6)  Not have ever been convicted or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere (or "no contest" or similar plea) to a felony, not have been convicted or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere (or "no contest" or similar plea) to any crime, other than a misdemeanor traffic offence, within the prior ten (10) years, and not have any pending charges against them for any crime other than a misdemeanor traffic offense; 
(7)  Carry the issued home solicitation permit and a photo identification at all times while soliciting. The photo identification shall be openly displayed on the person of the solicitor during all periods of active solicitation. The issued home solicitation permit and the photo identification shall be displayed upon request of any person. 
    The failure to maintain all requirements set forth above shall be grounds for immediate revocation of the home solicitation permit. Any person aggrieved by the revocation of a home solicitation permit shall be entitled to file an appeal with the office of the city attorney within fifteen (15) days of the revocation, and this appeal shall be heard by the Board of Aldermen of the City of West Monroe at its next regular scheduled meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2411, § 1, 6-8-04; Ord. No. 4378, § 1, 6-14-16) 
Chapter 2 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Intoxicated offender, § 11-1011; alcoholic beverages and minors, § 11-5009.1 et seq.; alcoholic beverages in recreational facilities, § 11-5028. 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, R.S. 26:1 et seq.; wholesale dealers in alcoholic beverages exempt from municipal license tax, R.S. 47:396; local permits, R.S. 26:73, 26:273; local taxation and regulation, R.S. 26:491 et seq. 

ARTICLE A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-2001. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms have the respective meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Alcoholic beverages: Any fluid or solid capable of being converted into fluid, suitable for human consumption and having an alcoholic content of more than one-half (1/2) of one percent alcohol by volume, including malt, vinous, spirituous, alcoholic or intoxicating liquors, beer, porter, ale, stout, fruit juices, cider or wine. 
    Beer outlet: A place where any person draws or removes any malt beverages from containers for sale or consumption on the premises. 
    Beverages of high alcoholic content: Alcoholic beverages containing more than six (6) percent alcohol by volume. 
    Beverages of low alcoholic content: Alcoholic beverages containing not more than six (6) percent alcohol by volume. 
    Dealer: Any person who, as a business, manufactures, blends, rectifies, distills, processes, imports, stores, uses, handles, holds, sells, offers for sale, solicits orders for the sale of, distributes, delivers, serves or transports any alcoholic beverage in the state or engages herein in any business transaction relating to any such beverage. 
    Liquor: Any distilled or rectified alcoholic beverage. 
    Liquor manufacturer: Any person who directly or indirectly, personally or through any agent whatever, engages in the making, blending, rectifying or processing of any alcoholic beverages in the city. 
    Off-premises consumption: In a closed container, prepared for transportation and actual consumption of the beverage other than on the licensed premises. A beverage covered or sealed with a closed top or cap, even though temporary in nature, shall be considered as a closed container. 
    Outlet: A place where any person draws or removes any alcoholic beverage from its container for consumption on the premises. 
    Package house: A place where a person sells alcoholic beverages in closed containers, prepared for transportation and consumption off the premises. 
    Regulated beverage: Any alcoholic beverage. 
    Restaurant establishment, for purposes of this chapter, shall mean an establishment: 
(1)  Which operates a place of business whose purpose and primary function is to take orders for, prepare and serve food and food items on the premises; 
(2)  Which serves alcoholic beverages in conjunction with meals; 
(3)  Which serves food on all days of operation; 
(4)  Which grosses sixty (60) percent of its average monthly revenue from the sale of food and food items; 
(5)  Which maintains separate sales figures for alcoholic beverages; and 
(6)  Which operates a fully equipped kitchen used for the preparation of uncooked foods for service and consumption of such food on the premises. 
    Retail dealer: Every person who offers for sale, exposes for sale, has in his possession for sale or distribution or sells alcoholic beverages in any quantity to persons other than licensed wholesale or retail dealers. 
    State board: The Louisiana Board of Alcoholic Beverage Control. 
    Wholesale dealer: Those persons who sell alcoholic beverages to licensed wholesale dealers or licensed retail dealers exclusively, within the city or to any person for delivery beyond the borders of the state and who conduct a bona fide wholesale business and maintain a warehouse or warehouses for the storage and warehousing of alcoholic beverages in the city and licensed by the state, and conduct and maintain systematic and regular solicitations, distribution, deliveries and sales of said beverages to licensed retail dealers located within the boundary of each parish and municipality in which the wholesale dealer makes any sale or delivery. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2001; Ord. No. 2091, § 1, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 2309, § 1, 7-11-89; Ord. No. 2655, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 10-2001.1. - Gallonage tax-Levied. 
    By virtue of authority granted by Louisiana law, there hereby is levied, in addition to all other excises, licenses or privilege taxes presently imposed, a tax on all beer, porter, ale, fruit juices and/or wine, having an alcoholic content of not less than one-half (1/2) of one percent nor more than six (6) percent by volume, of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per standard barrel of thirty-one (31) gallons, or any like rate of any other quantity, or for the fractional parts of such barrel sold for consumption in the city within the meaning and intent of the provisions of R.S. 26:493 and of related law. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 1, 9-8-81) 
Sec. 10-2001.2. - Same-Collection. 
    The tax levied in this article shall be collected by any and all Louisiana wholesale dealers from their vendees purchasing for consumption in the city on each sale and shall be remitted by said wholesale dealers to the collector of revenue of the state for each month, on or before the twentieth day of each succeeding month, respectively, all in accordance with rules and regulations promulgated by the collector of revenue and as provided by R.S. 26:345 and by related law. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 2, 9-8-81) 
Sec. 10-2001.3. - Same-Penalty. 
    If a dealer in beverages of low alcoholic content fails to file a return and pay the tax due on the beverages within the time provided in R.S. 26:345, he shall be subject to a penalty of five (5) percent on the amount of the tax if the period of delinquency is ten (10) days or less, or twenty (20) percent on the amount of the tax if the period of delinquency is greater than ten (10) days. If an attorney is called on to assist in collection, there shall be an additional sum due equal to ten (10) percent of both the amount of the penalties and tax due. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 3, 9-8-81) 
ARTICLE B. - PERMIT 

Sec. 10-2002. - Required; fees; exception. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter before engaging in the business of dealing in alcoholic beverages, any person or persons shall obtain from the city, annually, dating from January first of each year a permit to conduct to each separate business and shall pay the city therefor according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Liquor manufacturers, for each establishment in the city ..... $500.00 
(2)  Wholesale dealers, in beverages of high alcoholic content ..... 500.00 
(3)  Wholesale dealers, in beverages of low alcoholic content ..... 100.00 
(4)  Retail dealers, in beverages of high alcoholic content and beverages of low alcoholic content for on- or off-premises consumption ..... 500.00 
(5)  Retail dealers, in beverages of high alcoholic content for off-premises consumption ..... 375.00 
(6)  Retail dealers, in beverages of low alcoholic content for on- or off-premises consumption ..... 75.00 
(7)  Retail dealers, in beverages of low alcoholic content for off-premises consumption ..... 60.00 
(8)  Restaurant establishment Class R license (includes on-premises sale of "light-wine" as defined in R.S. 26:72) (in addition to license fee for that required in either (4) or (6) above) ..... 30.00 
(b)  Any person not otherwise a dealer in alcoholic beverages coming into possession of any alcoholic beverages as administrator, executor, trustee or other fiduciary, as security for or in payment of a debt, or as an insurer (or its transferee or assignee) for the salvage or liquidation of an insured casualty or damage or loss may sell the beverages in one lot or parcel to any licensed wholesale or retail dealer without qualifying as a dealer. 
(c)  If an applicant qualifies for issuance of separate permits under subsection (a)(4) and (a)(8) to the same applicant, or under subsection (a)(6) and (a)(8), the city may issue a combined permit. All requirements of the combined permit and all costs for the combined permit shall be equivalent of all requirements and the total of all costs for each of the individual permits. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2002; Ord. No. 1835, § 1, 9-9-80; Ord. No. 2118, § 1, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 2280, 3-14-89; Ord. No. 2390, § 1, 11-13-90; Ord. No. 2491, § 1, 10-13-92; Ord. No. 2655, § 2, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 4117, § 1, 4-9-13) 
State Law reference- Local permit fees, R.S. 26:73, 26:273. 
Sec. 10-2003. - Permittee must hold state and city permit. 
    No person shall do any act for which a permit is required by the Louisiana Board of Alcoholic Beverage Control, acting under its authority, unless he holds a proper state and city permit. Each day's conduct of business by the dealer without such a valid, unsuspended permit constitutes a separate violation under this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2003) 
Sec. 10-2004. - Personal. 
(a)  Permits issued under this chapter are personal to the applicant and are not assignable or inheritable and are good only from the time of issuance to December thirty-first of the year in which issued, unless sooner suspended or revoked. In the event of the dissolution of a partnership by death, the surviving partner or partners may operate under the partnership permit. Receivers and trustees in bankruptcy may operate under the permit for the person succeeded. 
(b)  Where the location of a place of business is changed, the change shall be noted on the permit by the issuing authority and the permit shall be invalid unless the notation is made. 
(c)  All permits issued by the city must be posted in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2004) 
State Law reference- Personal nature of permits, R.S. 26:75, 26:275. 
Sec. 10-2005. - Publication of notice by applicant. 
(a)  Prior to the making of application for a permit, each applicant shall twice insert an appropriate signed notice similar to the following in a newspaper published in this city: "I am applying for a permit to sell alcoholic beverages at (retail or wholesale) at the following address: __________ in the City of West Monroe." 
(b)  The publication of this notice is not required of permittees seeking the renewal of their permits. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2005) 
State Law reference- Notice of application for retail dealer's permit, R.S. 26:76, 26:276. 
Sec. 10-2006. - Contents of application. 
(a)  All applications to engage in any business or operation regulated by this chapter shall be in writing and sworn to, and shall contain the full name of the applicant, his social security number, his federal employer identification number, if applicable, his Louisiana Department of Revenue business account number, if applicable, his correct home address, and an accurate description and correct street address of the premises wherein the business or operation is to be conducted, which address shall be considered the proper address for all notices to the applicant or permittee required by this chapter, and shall be accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant showing that he meets the qualifications and conditions set forth in this chapter. Original and renewal applications shall also be accompanied by a signed sales tax clearance from the secretary of the department of revenue, and the sales tax collection agency or agencies for the city. 
(b)  Unless he is seeking a renewal of his permit, an applicant for a retail dealer's permit shall attach to his application, as a part thereof, a certification of publication by the publisher of the newspaper, showing the publication of the notice required in section 10-2005. 
(c)  The city may require that copies of the application which must be submitted to the State of Louisiana for an alcoholic beverage permit, together with all exhibits, shall also be included as a part of the application to the city, and the city may utilize that submission to establish compliance with those requirements of this chapter as the city determines are appropriate. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2006; Ord. No. 2995, § 1, 4-13-99; Ord. No. 4118, § 1, 4-9-13) 
State Law reference- Contents of application for permit, R.S. 26:77, 26:277. 
Sec. 10-2007. - Time of submitting applications; receipt by clerk; probationary period. 
(a)  All applications for permits shall be mailed or delivered to the clerk within twenty-four (24) hours from the date the applicant has made application to the Louisiana Board of Alcoholic Beverage Control. If he fails to do so, his city application may be withheld and the permit denied. Upon receipt of an application, in proper form and meeting all requirements, the clerk shall stamp the day, month and year received. The city shall make a proper investigation prior to the issuance of any permits. 
(b)  After an applicant has complied with all the requirements of this chapter, and the city has completed such investigations as it determines to be either necessary or appropriate, the permit may be approved by the mayor at any time thereafter. If any permit has not been approved by the mayor within seven (7) days of the completion of such investigations, unless subsequently approved it shall be submitted for approval to the board of aldermen at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(c)  For a period of thirty-five (35) days after issuance of any permit, such permit shall operate on a probationary basis subject to final action on, opposition to or withholding of permits as provided under the terms and conditions of R.S. 26, Chapter 1 (the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law) and this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2007; Ord. No. 2996, § 1, 4-13-99) 
State Law reference- Submission of applications, delay, probation, R.S. 26:78, 26:278. 
Sec. 10-2008. - Qualifications of applicants for permits. 
(a)  Applicants for permits of all kinds shall meet all of the following qualifications and conditions: 
(1)  Be a person of good character and reputation and over eighteen (18) years of age. 
(2)  Be a citizen of the United States and the State of Louisiana and a resident of the State of Louisiana continuously for a period of not less than two (2) years next preceding the date of the filing of the application. However, the requirements as to Louisiana citizenship do not apply to wholesalers or retailers who held permits on or prior to January 1, 1946. 
(3)  Be the owner of the premises or have a bona fide written lease therefor. 
(4)  Have not been convicted of a felony under the laws of the United States, the State of Louisiana, or any other state or country. 
(5)  Have not been convicted in this or in any other state or by the United States or any other country of soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, contributing to the delinquency of juveniles, keeping a disorderly place, or illegally dealing in controlled dangerous substances. 
(6)  Have not had a license or permit to sell or deal in alcoholic beverages, issued by the United States, any state, or by any political subdivision of a state authorized to issue permits or licenses, revoked within two (2) years prior to the application, or been convicted or had a judgment of court rendered against the applicant involving alcoholic beverages by this or any other state or by the United States for two (2) years prior to the application. 
(7)  Have not been adjudged by the state commissioner or by the city, or convicted by a court of violating any of the provisions of this chapter or of Title 26 of the Revised Statutes. 
(8)  Have not been convicted of violating any city ordinances. If the applicant has been so convicted, the granting of a permit or of a renewal shall be within the discretion of the city. 
(9)  Not be the spouse of a person who does not meet the requirements of paragraphs (1) and (3) through (8), and (10) of this subsection; however, in such cases the age of the ineligible spouse shall be immaterial. 
(10)  Not owe the state or the city any delinquent sales taxes, penalties, or interest, excluding items under formal appeal pursuant to applicable statutes. 
(b)  If the applicant is a partnership recognized by Louisiana law, or anyone in such partnership with or financed by another, all members of such partnership, or all the persons furnishing the money shall also possess the qualifications required of an applicant. The application shall name all partners or financial backers and furnish their social security numbers and proper addresses. If a partner of a partnership applying for retail permits is a corporation or limited liability company, the requirements as to citizenship and residence shall not apply to officers, directors, and stockholders of the corporation or members of the limited liability company. The corporation or limited liability company shall either be organized under the laws of the State of Louisiana or qualified to do business within the State of Louisiana. 
(c)  (1)  If the applicant is a corporation or a limited liability company, all officers and directors and all stockholders or members owning in the aggregate more than five (5) percent of the stock or of the membership interest in a limited liability company and the person or persons who shall conduct or manage the business shall possess the qualifications required of an applicant, to be shown by the affidavit of each accompanying the application. Each affidavit shall include the signatory's Louisiana Department of Revenue business account number, his social security number, and his correct home address. 
(2)  The requirements as to citizenship and residence do not apply to officers, directors, or stockholders of corporations or members of limited liability companies applying for retail permits; to officers, directors, or stockholders or members of a manufacturer that does not maintain one or more establishments in this state; or to officers, directors, or stockholders of any corporation which on January 31, 2003, had held a wholesale dealer permit continuously for at least the past three (3) years. The provisions of this paragraph only apply to a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or any other legal business entity either organized under the laws of the State of Louisiana or qualified to do business within the State of Louisiana. 
(3)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of law to the contrary, the city may accept from a publicly traded corporation, other than any gaming entity regulated pursuant to the provisions of R.S. 27:20 et seq., R.S. 27:41 et seq., or R.S. 27:301 et seq., the necessary documentation of those persons described in subsection (d) of this section and three (3) officers of the corporation in full satisfaction of the requirements of this section. 
(d)  If the applicant's business is to be conducted wholly or partly by one or more managers, agents, servants, employees, or other representatives, those persons shall also possess the qualifications required of the applicant and shall furnish their social security numbers and their correct home addresses; however, convicted felons may be employed by an applicant if, in the applicant's business, alcoholic beverages are not the principal commodities sold, handled, or given away. 
(e)  If the applicant, or any other person required to have the same qualifications, does not possess the required qualifications, the permit may be denied; however, if a sales tax clearance is not issued, the permit shall be denied. Nevertheless, if the sales tax clearance request is not processed within the time limitations provided in R.S. 26:78, the permit shall be issued if all other qualifications are met by the applicant. 
(f)  (1)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) and (b), a permit may be granted by the city if the applicant has been pardoned, has had any misdemeanor conviction discharged or dismissed, or the applicant's civil rights have been restored, or, if the applicant is a firm, association, partnership, trust, domestic or foreign corporation, or other legal entity, the applicant has terminated its relationship with the person or persons whose action directly contributed to the applicant's conviction. 
(2)  In the granting of a permit, a conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere by the applicant shall not constitute an automatic disqualification of the applicant as otherwise required pursuant to the provisions of paragraph (a)(4) of this section, if all of the following criteria are met: 
(a)  The felony for which the applicant was convicted is not a crime of violence as defined in R.S. 14:2(13). 
(b)  Ten (10) years or more have elapsed between the date of application and the successful completion of any sentence, deferred adjudication, or period of probation or parole and the final discharge of the defendant. 
(g)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) and (b), the commissioner may grant or continue a permit with respect to an applicant, even though the applicant's spouse has been convicted of a felony, if the applicant: 
(1)  Had state and local permits prior to the spouse's felony conviction, and 
(2)  (a)  Has a regime of separation of property, pursuant to Civil Code Article 2370, and is the owner of the premises or has a bona fide written lease therefor, or 
(b)  Owns the permitted premises as the applicant's separate property, pursuant to Civil Code Article 2341. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2008; Ord. No. 2091, § 4, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 2280, 3-14-89; Ord. No. 3519, § 1, 12-13-05) 
State Law reference- Qualifications of applicants for permits, R.S. 26:79, 26:279. 
Sec. 10-2008.1. - Additional qualifications for restaurant establishment Class R license. 
(a)  In addition to the other requirements set forth in this chapter, an applicant for a restaurant establishment Class R license shall attach to its application: 
(1)  Proof of issuance of a retail dealer's license for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages (of high or low content) from the city (or contemporaneous application for such license); and 
(2)  An affidavit establishing that the applicant is a restaurant establishment and the establishment grosses sixty (60) percent of its average monthly revenue from the sale of food and food items. The city may at any time require that affidavit be supported by copies of actual business records, including sales records, sales tax receipts, receipts for purchases of food, food items and alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  For new restaurant establishments without prior business experience on which to determine the gross revenue from the sale of the items as set forth in subsection (a)(2) above, the affidavit provided in subsection (a)(2) shall provide that based upon the reasonable expectation of applicant, the establishment will meet the requirement, and the restaurant establishment Class R license granted shall be considered provisional for a period of sixty (60) days, and that throughout that sixty-day period the documentation which may be required to be provided in subsection (a)(2) above, may be also required by the city to be submitted, and that if the documentation does not reflect the required percentage of average monthly revenue for the sale of food and food items has been satisfied, or that documentation requested is not provided within five (5) business days of the city's request, then the Class R license which was provisionally granted shall automatically expire. 
(c)  Failure of an establishment to continue to meet the requirements of a "restaurant establishment" shall be sufficient grounds for immediate suspension of the restaurant establishment Class R license. 
(d)  If an applicant for a restaurant establishment Class R license is the holder of a retail dealer's license for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages from the city, the city may issue the restaurant establishment Class R license upon compliance with this section, and without additional approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2655, § 3, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 4120, § 1, 4-9-13) 
Sec. 10-2009. - Location of business. 
(a)  No permit shall be granted under this chapter in contravention of the city zoning regulations. 
(b)  No permit shall be granted to permit the conduct of alcoholic beverage businesses for any premises situated within three hundred (300) feet or less of a public playground or of a building used exclusively as a church or synagogue, public library, or school. The measurement of this distance shall be made as a person walks using the sidewalk from the nearest point of the property line of the church or synagogue, public library, public playground or school to the nearest point of the premises to be licensed, or by such other method as may hereafter be prescribed by state law. 
(c)  No wholesale permit shall be issued or held after issuance by any person unless at all times throughout the license year he meets the standards set forth as follows: 
(1)  Maintains warehouse space either owned or leased by the wholesaler, or dedicated to his use in a public warehouse and the space shall be sufficient to store at one time a stock of liquor equal to ten (10) percent or more of the wholesaler's annual case volume of liquor sales to retailers within this state; or 
(2)  Maintains at all times in the warehouse a stock of liquor owned by him, not consigned, nor then sold, consisting of not less than five (5) percent of his annual sales to retailers, and whose cost of acquisition is fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more; 
(3)  Maintains delivery equipment which shall be leased, owned or dedicated to his use; 
(4)  Maintains brand representation with at least one distillery or liquor manufacturer; 
(5)  Maintains sales of liquor to retailers generally within his immediate trade area, making sales to at least twenty (20) percent of the retailers in said area with separate sales to retailers accounting for at least fifty (50) percent of the gallonage handled by him. 
(d)  No wholesale permit shall be issued or held after issuance by any person who does not in good faith actually carry on or intend to carry on a bona fide wholesale business by sale to retail permittees of the alcoholic beverages on hand, and the board of aldermen may revoke any wholesale permit when the permittee fails for a period of forty-five (45) days actively and in good faith to engage in the wholesale business, and shall revoke any wholesale permit for any other violation of this subsection or the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to the enforcement hereof. 
(e)  Sale by a wholesaler to himself as a retailer, or as a partner in a retail establishment is not a bona fide wholesale transaction. No wholesaler shall store any of his stock on the premises of any retail establishment. 
(f)  Persons engaged primarily in the sale, handling, distribution and storage of alcoholic beverages which are ultimately delivered or transported beyond the borders of the state are exempt from complying with the standards set forth in this section. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2009; Ord. No. 2091, § 5, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 2392, § 1, 12-11-90) 
Cross reference- Zoning, Part 12, Ch. 5. 
State Law reference- Location of business, R.S. 26:80, 26:280. 
Sec. 10-2010. - Interposed persons.
